												Batman: Arkham Asylum is the first batman game I have played of the series, despite the fact that it is the first published. I did enjoy this game, quite a bit, and im not even a batman fan whatsoever. It proved some interesting twists and turns, some real nice combat, combat could easily be turned around onto you. Its a good game for both strategy and tactic gamers, as running in will most likely get you killed. I finished Arkham Origins before this, which improved gameplay for me a bit more, as I started this but never got around to finishing it till not too long ago. In summary, this is a good game. You should get this game, but its not all that hard, which is a problem, though, still a heavy recommendation.

It’s a impressive crafted game with the attention to detail.As for gameplay i found it really entertaining and played it to it’s end. Flying around and beating guys up never gets old. It has a great fighting combo system with the ability to counter punches in the middle of the fight which leads to spectacular looking sequences. Other than this there are tonnes of unlocks, upgrades and achievements to gather if you like those kinds of things.This being the first game in the series, i respect the fact that much really hasn’t changed in the following games. (I still haven’t played the other games but they do look pretty similar.) I fully expect them to be equally entertaining.Previously, the game featured Games For Windows Live and that would have put some people off. But that is now ancient history as the game has been updated and that atrocious system is now removed and replaced with Steamworks.So in closing, if you haven’t picked this game up yet there really isn’t an excuse anymore. This game and the new movies combined have given me hope and new appreciation of the masked man fighting crimes in moody back alleys. A man known simply as…*Suspenseful music*Batman.

Posted: December 2, 2013
												There are no real words to describe this.This game is beyond amazing, it's terrifying, mysterious, puzzling and has a finger biting plotline.Let me review every aspect.Plot: Extremely great, I love the transition between enemies and how this and that happens. Graphics: For it's time, it's really well done.Characters (Im gonna make this subparted.)Batman: He's what he is, in the comics, movies, and the cartoons. A dark, mysterious, yet lonely character.Joker: Nothing new, but nothing bad either. The voice acting is great and his involvement in the plot is well, unexpected at least.Scarecrow: One of my favorite enemies, I love this scarecrow, he's what I expected plus more! He's crazy and terrifying and he reveals a bit of Batman's fears.Bane: Appears during 2 scenes and one boss fight. Great Bane and how he well, is in general.Poison Ivy: Drop-dead gorgeous, Ivy is a cool enemy and brings well a bunch more♥♥♥♥♥♥to the Arkham Asylum facilities.Croc: Great, he wasnt hard per se, but getting in and out was difficult and terrifying.Riddler: He didnt make a physical appearance in the game but he does speak every time you pick up a trophy or solve a puzzle.And last.. Harley (Im not going to include Zsasz) She's ravishing and crazy and well, not much to say.This is one of the few games that even when I get frustrated I always come back to play it.10/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
												I was late to the table where this franchise is concerned. I played Batman; Arhkam City nearly two years after its release, and needless to say I was hooked. I wasn't willing to buy a PS3 or Xbox 360 for one game, and I didn't have a PC capable of handling the game, so I had to wait for a while before I got around to this title. As the title may suggest, Batman; Arkham Asylum (BAA) is a fascinating romp through Gotham's infamous Arkham Asylum. The battle interface used throughout the series makes a very strong debut as you fight hordes of crazed criminals while attempting to regain control of the facility from the Joker. There are several memorable encounters with other well-known characters from the Batman universe along the way. The game very successfully gives the player an opportunity to be the Batman in a variety of situations. One moment you will need to stealthily overtake an area by sneaking through vents and hanging from gargoyles to secure a room full of armed baddies. The next you may be in an all-out brawl with a grundle of thugs. At other times you will use your investigative skills to locate evidence to help you along the way. It is all well done and such a blast! I highly recommend this title to anyone who enjoys a well made game.10/10

												Nanananananana batmens !!!Speli iegadajos jo humbebundle bija akcija un spelei bija loti labs metescore (91). Sakuma domaju ka var but tik labs? Bet kad saku spelet sapratu.  ievads taka bija pa ilgu. Un tad jokers izmuk un sakas terors arkham island.Speles turpinas un ari turpinasies ar banditu sisanu.nosakuma tas skita neinterasnti bet kad sakas upgrade un kombo taisisana aiziet liela azarta.Un tad paradijas riddlera miklas kas man pasam bija viss interesantaka lieta, bet kas ari aiznema speles ilgako dalu.Man patika ka vini betmenu nenosauca par supervaroni bet gan par pasaules labako dektektivu un kas skita pa visam logiski.Speles laika tu iegust visadas papildmantinas un kuras tu uzlabo.Speles minusus uz reiz redzeju jo es tads malacis saku nu ar arkham city. Protams tie bija svarigas lietas ka: lidosanas laika nomerket un izsaut uz vietu kur velies.Saja spelet bija vel leksanas poga(spelejot arkham city tu doma kpc nav),bet izradijas pa tiesam lieka spelejot.Spelet pec iziesana pagarinas ar riddlera miklam kas liek padomat bet saja dala tas ir atri izpildamas.(ja tev vel ir karte).Par atminejumiem to iegusti citu cilveku biografiju un vel 3d telus vari apskatit.Spele vel ir chalange mods kurs ir neliels, bet grutaks neka arkham city. Ir 2 veidi sado visiem pa seju ar lielaku kombo vai ari sado konkreta veida cilvekiem pa mapi ejot abos gadijumos ir ieteicams dabut visus upgrade citadi bus gruti vai nevaresi iziet.upgrade klasts bija loti normala daudzuma.Spele man skita aizraujosa ari tas ka bija bosu rezims.Spele man ilga tikai ap12h izejot SP un ari ridlera miklas visas. Bet vel nav iziets challange mods ta ka es to citigi daru.So spele iesaku visiem un loti rekomendeju nopirkt visas 3 dala.  Mans vertejums 9.1/10

content:

COMPLETED 100%A fine game, typical of Unreal Engine 3 structure, that is flawless in design and gameplay. The fighting mechanics is amazingly fluid and smooth and it's simple for Batman to easily leap around to enemies, even those far away from him, with the press of a button. Game is technically open world; small in size but non-linear with different distinct separate areas to explore. Can't find anything bad to say about the game but it's easy to see why it's rated so highly. IMO The Amazing Spiderman game is better than this though.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												For those who don’t already know about this treasure I only discovered and played recently Batman: Arkham Asylum is an excellent story action/stealth action game, any Batman or DC fan would love.Pros; Nice fighting mechanics (I played Mad Max before this and read many reviews about how the fighting style was similar this is just as good with sometimes better visuals when you unlock the moves), you will take on small to large groups of enemies in a smack/counter moves. For those who enjoy Stealth based games this has plenty, I’m not a big fan of this genre but was pleasantly surprised it didn’t take over and was easy to get into and perform those silent take downs without being seen. Some nice boss/villain fights to keep you entertained. A few minor puzzles and collectables in the form of Riddler riddles, some of which require you to grapple, climb or just scan areas in far off corners. Excellent story as mentioned before as Batman battles an array of villains as well as a nice steady progress as the henchmen themselves get harder to defeat.Cons; Personally the only thing that slightly annoyed me was the Scarecrow sections as the game seemed to switch from 3D to a strange 2D style, this also occurred in a few fights towards the end. Not a big issue but did confuse me as the normal game view and ability to move the camera were just fine.Overall and excellent game that holds up to many even to this date well worth is asking price even more so if on sale, thumbs up!

content:
Posted: August 8, 2016
An excellent game.(Pros/Cons down below if you don't feel like reading it all)I was one, of many, who preordered the, rather dissapointing, Arkham Knight (I got it cheap from a friend, don’t blame me). However, Warner Brothers decided to be a bit empathic and give us all the older Arkham-games, which, to a certain extent, made me forgive them.Enough about that, let’s get to the review. Gameplay The gameplay is really good, flying using the grapping hook is surpringly fun and the combat, while in reality not too advanced and arguably a bit too automated, feels great and is really fun. Batman has a vast arsenal of moves and gadgets to use, many of which need to be unlocked through leveling up, hence keeping the combat fresh and interesting. The game also contains a lot of puzzles, none which are too advanced nor time-consuming to complete, but they do add to the gameplay. Kind of reminds me of the “The Legend of Zelda” games. You might find this comparasion a bit bizarre, and I can’t blame you really. Collectibles are plenty in the game, and while I know that everyone isn’t a fan of them, I find them quite fun to find here, having The Riddler mock you about not having found the rest hardly gets old. That, and the fact many of them require some creativity and/or puzzle solving keeps it interesting. You also get XP from finding them.About XP, as mentioned, the game features a leveling system.It’s quite basic, you gain XP from combat (amount depends on how many moves you managed to do in succession and how varied they were), solving riddles and finding The Riddler’s throphys, plus a few other things.During my playthough I neverfelt like I was under nor overleveled, the game went on at a good pace without any moments were I got stuck.Coming to the controls, I’ve only been albe to try the keyboard/mouse ones, and they work well, could be better, but far from bad. I never felt like they caused any problems, to put it that way. Story/Characters The story is good. Not too advanced so that it gets in the way, nor too mediocre so that everything feels unmotivated. Because it doesn’t, not at all. I’ve played a few games (*cough* Borderlands (1)) where everything simply felt unmotivated and forced, simply because I had no idea on why I was doing this. Before you tell me that I should’ve read the text boxes on the quests, this was co-op. But, enough about that. Where the game really shines is its charatcters, especially the villans. Sure, none of them are original, but they all fit well together in the game, and manages to feel unique, even though they’re high in quantity. While the normal thugs you’ll encounter mostly stay the same, some carry different weapons and/or have armour, which does shake things up a little bit. It’s nothing that ever bothered me playing through the game though. Graphics/Opimisation Runs great on my hardware (specs can be found on profile), for the most part. It does stutter a bit while loading things off the harddrive and one particular scene utilises PhysX a bit too much, leading to a framerate cut in half (from a near constant 62 FPS, which is the cap, to a unstable 30 FPS), and even after the fight it dropped even lower (4-5 FPS). Restarting fixed this though.The graphics hold up well despite their age, and the artstyle is nice. I found no obvious pixelation on any textuers, though you’ll probably be able to find some if you actually look around. The lack of any anti-aliasing aside from MSAA is a bit dissapoining, but not really a problem with today’s hardware. Sound/Audio The soundtrack is good, nothing memorable, but it sets the mood well and does well in the background without disturbing you. Same goes for the voice acting, though perhaps a bit better than the soundtrack, so perhaps I'd go as far as to call it great. No complaints here really.Sounds for actions, such as Batman hitting someone or him grappling up to a ledge are excellent, no complaints here either, not that I'd expect otherwise. Conclusion  Great game, definetly worth playing and buying, even if you aren’t a Batman fan (I wasn’t one before I played this game, to put it that way).8/10 Pros Good story Nice graphics, which still hold up well Good keyboard controlls, haven't tried controller Well optimised The villans are interesting Satisfying combat Cons Some PhysX effects kill the framerate May stutter when loading things off the harddrive Capped at 62 FPS Only anti-aliasing avaible is MSAA

content:
Posted: April 29, 2016
												I know, shocking isn't it? I actually liked a game that everyone else does. (Although, I could talk about why I don't like Arkham City, but let's think about the positives!)Batman: Arkham Asylum was a game that everyone expected would be crappy but it turned out to be good... blah blah blah, everyone knows the stories. And if you've seen anyone's review of Arkham Asylum, my opinions are pretty similar, so for once I'll actually condense my thoughts:PROS:1- Great voice acting from Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill, as expected2- Excellent, intuitive level design and puzzles 3- Well-created world within Arkham Island, that feels very dark and twisted4- Continues telling a story without beating you over the head, like when Ivy takes over, you see all the plants swarm the island5- Fantastic stealth and combat gameplayCONS:1- Uncreative boss fights2- Lots of plot holes3- Sometimes stiff animations (Conversations mainly look very stiff and robot-like)I played this game years ago, and loved it then, so I'm glad to see that my opinion hasn't changed. I planned on taking a break from Steam to try out some Bayonetta and Lollipop Chainsaw on the console, but the temptation was too strong and I gave in. And I actually went out of my way to find out all 240 Riddler Trophies, which (while a little repetitive) was ultimately fun to find. It makes the replay value just a little bit higher.Batman: Arkham Asylum gets an 8/10. With all the things it does so flawlessly well, it's very hard to judge it for its shortcomings. I'm definitely coming back in a few more years to play through a third time. I might even go for 100% completion.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
The Joker has taken over the Asylum and only Batman can put a stop to the madness. I picked this up during the WB Humble Bundle where it lay unplayed in my Steam library for months, mainly due to the fact I had no way of playing it. Now that I finally have a gaming PC I decided to download and try this Dark Knight Simulator.Now I had only ever played bits of this game on console in the past and I never really understood the hype. But after throwing all the settings on max and jumping into this game I finally saw the light (or the Dark, I guess).Arkham Asylum comes complete with a combo/counter/beat 'em up combat system which has you throwing punches left, right and centre with the finese of a Bat. Get your combo building and the Bat becomes quicker and more powerful. But the fun doesn't end at the combat. The Joker has a night of fun in plan for the Batman and it goes from bad (by bad I mean really, really good) to worse (It starts to get really exciting towards the end.) and seeing all the familiar villians locked away in Arkham suddenly freed and hungry for the blood of the Bat leads to some utterly awesome encounters. The Riddler also has you covered if you are looking for a game with an insane amount of collectables, the only dissapointment with this game was the lack of a New Game Plus function, although this did get rectified in the later sequels!Fancy becoming the Bat for a night in the Joker's Funhouse? Pick this up! You know you want to.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Buy This:If you enjoy 3rd person adventure games with hand to hand combat and stealth sectionsIf you want to REALLY feel like the BatmanI played Batman for the first time early in 2014, and absolutely loved the living crap out of it. This game does just about everything right. The atmosphere, music, story and acting are all top notch. The controls feel fluid and responsive. All I can really say to sum it all up is this game makes you feel like the Batman. There were times while swinging above my enemies, slowly dispatching them one after another I found myself giggling with a psychotic glee. "Good luck finding me you brain-dead thugs! I'm  Batman!"Arkham Asylum is a 3rd person Metroidvania styled action game. You play as Batman (of course) and explore an insane asylum that has been taken over by The Joker. You're free to explore the asylum (which is a huge island complex) at your leisure, but you are forced along the correct order of places by slowly unlocking new abilities. Each room in Arkham plays out like one of a few minigames depending on what's going on. Sometimes the room will be filled with armed thugs hunting you, and the game becomes a stealth game. You swing from the rafters slowly dispatching enemies that wander too far into the shadows. It is very fun. As more of the thug's friends vanish, they become more and more fearful for their own hide. By the time you're down to the last thug, they're often crying in a corner or shooting randomly all about the room screaming in absolute terror. The game has some rooms that are filled with packs of unarmed enemies you have to beat down with your bat fists. The hand to hand combat is wildly satisfying, and soon you'll be blocking, counter attacking and vaulting everything in a huge blur of bat punches. There are still other sections that become platformers. These require you to navigate all sorts of crazy structures by jumping, swinging and roping all over. These aren't as strong as platforming in say, Prince of Persia, but they are decent and get the job done. There's all sorts of other ways the game changes itself up for you as you progress, but I don't want to spoil the surprise. Just do yourself a favor and go become the Batman.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2016
												One of the best games of all time, and I cannot believe how I loved this game. I first played it on PS3 back in 2014 and was horrified by how many times I would get lost. However, I must have been stupid! I strongly advise you buy this game, and in my opinion, it is pure gold. While the boss fights could use some work, the game is ultimately still a great experience. This is not exactly something I would call open world, but because it is such a small map it is absolutely CRANKED with detail! There are really nice riddles about the environment in several locations on the map, and figuring those out is one of the best parts of Arkham Asylum. The combat is stellar as you may have heard before, with countless games trying to imitate it but not always reaching their full potential. Well, to say the least, this is one of the most fun combat systems I have ever messed around with. There are gadgets at your disposal which severely impact the flow of combat, in both good ways and bad - depending on how you use them. The story is insanely awesome, and the graphics have CERTAINLY aged well. The story goes that you have captured Joker, and obviously♥♥♥♥♥♥never goes as it should be. Joker is absolutely insane here and is about to... well, I will let you find that out for yourselves. This is a great experience and in some ways better than City, in most ways better than Origins, and story-wise better than Knight. 9/10 from me. Boss fights could be better, but it is a load of fun, and the story is great for any Batman fan to enjoy! Absolutely recommended!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												This... is easily one of the best games I have ever had the pleasure of playing. This game is good. No, this game is downright amazing. Why is it so good? Everything about this game is why. Not a single feature was made poorly. The asylum looks amazing, it almost even has a feel to it like you are actually there. Every single little detail on every thing is very well made. And then there is the story. It's like they took a page out of the Animated Batman series and made a movie based on it, but as a game. It is really well written. And the acting, my god the acting. I can't even begin to describe it, just play it already. The gameplay is also really well made to. There are essentially three aspects to the game. The first is the combat. At first it just seems like you could just mash the attack button but as the game goes on it introduces so many features. Mainly there is a combo system where you have to only hit the button once between hits to keep it going. You want to keep it going so you can use the really good moves that you unlock. Also there are enemies that have to be hit in certain ways or you get hurt. The other aspect is stealth. It's pretty straight forward and that is what works about it. You don't have much to worry about other than staying out of line of sight while picking off the guards one by one. There are also gadgets to use that can let you do some pretty cool things. The third aspect is exploring the island. While the game is pretty much linear there is a bit of a puzzle for how to get to the next area or actual puzzle like sections and even some hidden goodies. Definitely one of the games where it is worth getting all the collectibles in.I give the game 5 batarangs out of 5.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												Here is my review for Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY EditionIntro:   The story places after Batman has finally captured Joker and is transporting him to Arkham Asylum. He senses something bigger is happening, but isn't sure what it is. After entering Arkham Asylum, Batman becomes just another inmate and must battle his enemies and restore order the Asylum.Gameplay / Sound:   Batman AA plays like a super advanced version of crackdown. Don't know crackdown? Well its a action adventure game where you use buttons to chain together attacks and combine with Batman's arsenal. It involves kicks, batarangs, batman's cape, explosive gel and many other items. While in combat you can chain these weapons along with dodge and counter button to quickly wipe out the enemy. The second part is part stealth action game, where you can take down enemies without alerting anyone, in classic Batman fashion. There is great satisifaction from taking on 6-10 enemies and just picking them all off, one by one. The only issue I have with this is that you have to watch "slow mo" kills on the last enemy. Granted you can skip it, it almost doesnt feel really necessary to also cut to that. All the inmates are like mini hulks and just look like the can bash your skull in, luckily Batman is a master of combat.  After about the first couple of hours the combat begins to grow stale and repetitive. If you complete 100 % everything like I do, than it almost becomes a grind. Other than that a normal playthrough will be enough for most players. The sound effects whether you are solving riddler challenges or destroying Joker's toy teeth, each sound is unique that you'll always remember what each sound indicates. The voices of fan favorites shows up in Batman AA and makes the game very nostalgic.Story :   The story of Arkham Asylum revolves around Batman trying to escape from AA and stop the Joker from unleashing a weapon upon Gotham. The story is fleshed out between common knowledge, background audio tapes dubbed "patient reports" and through dialogue. In terms of complete story Batman AA has it all. A clear Beginning, Middle and End. You never are lost and are always free to continue the main story whenever. This means going on "side quests" to collect all the goodies hidden in the asylum. The story mainly focuses on Joker and Batman, but many other villains show up to help move the plot along. The story is almost purely confinded to the island, whether it is above or below, you grow to love the asylum, no matter how many enemies reside within its walls.Replayability:   Batman AA has tons of replayability for players who are looking to collect all the achievements, records, and solve the riddlers questions. Outside of all those things, there isn't any main story to complete after you run through it. Extra modes like the fighting, stealth and reward challenges will keep you busy, but after that the replay value decreases. Batman AA is meant for a story playthrough and includes all these extras to keep you interested. Most people will just complete the story and will be satisfied with their time on Arkham Asylum. Controls:  The controls are fluid and really smooth. Rocksteady worked hard on this and makes it very easy for anyone to pick and a play. There is no big learning curve which makes this a very attractive game to new users and veteran players.Conclusion: If you are looking into buying Arkham Asylum or a Batman fan, this is the game for you. It has tons of juicy story content, great characters and voice acting, and a great open world system. The combat can get reptitive and some tasks might repeat themselves, but overall Batman Arkham Asylum is a great addition to everyone's collection.Final Score: 9 out of 10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												nanananananaBATMAN!At first, I was disappointed that instead of making a game based off the gritty Chris Nolan 'Dark Knight' movies, they decided to base the new Batman games off the "wimpy, lame" comics. Oh boy, how I was wrong.This game does everything about Batman just right. The non-lethal, combo-based combat is the most satisfying action combat gameplay I have ever experienced. Skulking around rooftops, being perched on gargoyles and unexpectedly swooping down on henchmen oddly satisfies my inner Bat-like instincts. And of course, Batman is nothing without his awesome array of gadgetry. Arkham Asylum feels large and open, but that illusion shatters after you finish the story and start hunting down unlocks and map secrets. The story is rather interesting and features many of Batman's stalwart enemies; Joker, Scarecrow, Harley Quinn et al. Although the story takes a decent amount of time to finish and there are many extras and challenge modes to occupy you after concluding the story, I was still left with a bat-sized hole in my heart; I still need to satisfy my inner Bat urges.Arkham Asylum is a very strong first entry into Rocksteady's Arkham series.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ARBITRARY NUMBER RATING : 9.5/11~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
												One of the greatest video games I've ever played. Batman: Arkham Asylum GOTY Edition kept me playing it for hours, beating it far more than once, and spending hours into the night simply attempting to find all the collectibles and secrets. Most games ruin themselves with a boring collectibles hunt, but Arkham Asylum brilliantly mixes the need for analyzing the setting as well as fighting off enemies to get to some, and simply manages to keep the game fun even while you're slaving away looking for them. Outside of that, the game is freaking fantastic as well. Taking place all in one night, the Joker has taken over Arkham Asylum, and you have to stop him. It may seem a simple, clishe story, but the introduction of many loved characters from the Batman universe spices up the story a lot, and will keep you on your toes throughout the game. On top of all this, the Tapes system and Character Bios teaches you more than you ever knew about the Batman Universe, letting you delve deeper into the lore of the game, and into the mind of a lunatic. 9.5/10.

												One of the best games of all time, and I cannot believe how I loved this game. I first played it on PS3 back in 2014 and was horrified by how many times I would get lost. However, I must have been stupid! I strongly advise you buy this game, and in my opinion, it is pure gold. While the boss fights could use some work, the game is ultimately still a great experience. This is not exactly something I would call open world, but because it is such a small map it is absolutely CRANKED with detail! There are really nice riddles about the environment in several locations on the map, and figuring those out is one of the best parts of Arkham Asylum. The combat is stellar as you may have heard before, with countless games trying to imitate it but not always reaching their full potential. Well, to say the least, this is one of the most fun combat systems I have ever messed around with. There are gadgets at your disposal which severely impact the flow of combat, in both good ways and bad - depending on how you use them. The story is insanely awesome, and the graphics have CERTAINLY aged well. The story goes that you have captured Joker, and obviously♥♥♥♥♥♥never goes as it should be. Joker is absolutely insane here and is about to... well, I will let you find that out for yourselves. This is a great experience and in some ways better than City, in most ways better than Origins, and story-wise better than Knight. 9/10 from me. Boss fights could be better, but it is a load of fun, and the story is great for any Batman fan to enjoy! Absolutely recommended!

content:
Posted: April 16
												Arkham Asylum is one of the best games of all time. The first of Rocksteady's trilogy of Batman games, Asylum is perhaps the most clean-structured of them. Small area, vibrant foes, and one big plot in the background. Add to it the voices being those from the Animated Series and it just... fits. Seriously, Kevin Conroy as Batman, Arleen Sorkin as Harley Quinn, and the greatest Joker of them all, Mark Hamill... Yeah... just perfection.Add in the combat system (which took a little time to get used to) and it is excellent.The visuals are also striking... though you might miss most of it with detective vision having such an appeal to it. Which brings me to the gadgets, Batman's stock in trade. They are effective in their own way. And this game does set the stage for what comes after.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												It's hard to find any flaws in Arkham Asylum.  It's a solid action/adventure game that is very successful in making the player feel like they are Batman.  This is something just about every Batman game released before Arkham Asylum failed to do.  It manages to achieve this through a perfect combat system that allows you to utilise gadgets while throwing enemies around.  I couldn't find any faults in the control system or combat mechanics.  The game offers fantastic voice acting, great graphics, enjoyable story, an upgrade system that flows well with the story, the combination of puzzle and stealth elements.  Then when you are finished with the story, you can spend time collecting trophies within the game.  Collecting these trophies never even felt like a chore.  You can then test your combat skills in the challenge section, as well as your stealth instincts in the predator challenge section.  You have plenty to discover in the game, with many villains making appearances, full bios, hidden recordings, riddler trophies and many hidden areas within the map.  If you combine everything I have mentioned, you have an unforgettable experience and a game that is quite possible (at the time of writing) the best comic game ever made.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Man this game. Where do I begin?The atmosphere just gets you right in the gut from the beginning of the game. Filling you inside this disturbed and twisted asylum filled with the beloved Batman characters we all know today. It's pretty damn good for just the beginning of the game. It starts already with you capturing Joker, which is a change in pace of the typical Batman stuff we know. However it has, dare I say, realism aspects in the game. This changes the overall mood and pace; this game wants you to take it seriously and they convey a good job of that.The controls are tight and compact. I rarely have issues with them other than some hiccups here and there, but it's rare. It feels very comfortable and smooth, where even the most basic of games like Left 4 Dead have some problems with gamepad support, dispite the limitations. I was playing with a gamepad this run, so the keyboard and mouse may have more polished controls than the standard, though I digress.The characters have, duh, character. The basic batman shows and comics have the same idea, though this game makes it all well and good. I was wondering what character would act like what, and it just left me guessing over and over.My favorite part was the scarecrow sequences. It was just plain brilliant. It had some scare factor, and a level of difficulty to the game. It breaks the action from the typical game and throws you for a loop each sequence: even going as far to break the 4th wall entirely.The ending, however wasn't very polished. For the sake of people wanting to know themselves, I won't spoil this. Though I admit it could be done a little better.Overall, give this game your money. I mean it. It deserves it. And it deserved Game of the Year. Get it. Now.

content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If you haven't picked up Batman: Arkham Asylum, you're a crazy person. The game came out about a year ago and I declared that it was the best comic book game of all time. What's your deal? Get it. However, if you ignored me, Batman: Arkham Asylum (Game of the Year Edition) has come along and it's a worthy addition to your videogame collection.Batman GOTY is the original game I loved along with four additional challenge maps and the newfound ability to play in 3D. Basically, it's more bang for your buck.Now, before visions of Avatar-like 3D go running through your head, it's important to point out that the 3D in Batman GOTY is super-basic. You turn on the 3D filter from the main menu, pop on a pair of paper glasses with pink and green lenses, and play. It works – the HUD is at the forefront and there's definitely a depth of field effect – but it's not amazing and the glasses wash the color out of the game. That sucks seeing as how the environments and action look so good in Arkham Asylum. The challenge maps are cool. Crime Alley is a fist-fighting challenge where you need to beat four waves of the Joker's men, and it's set in the very alley where Bruce Wayne's parents were killed. Nocturnal Hunter is a silent challenge where you need to take out a bunch of guards and complete some objectives. Meanwhile, Totally Insane and Scarecrow Nightmare throw enemies at you until you fall. All are fun and welcome additions to the regular game's challenges.If you haven't picked up this game, you should have no qualms about grabbing Batman: Arkham Asylum (Game of the Year). If you already own Batman, the 3D and challenge maps (a few of which you can just download) really don't warrant you plunking down your pocket change to buy this one again.Batman: Arkham Asylum is a third-person action game casting you as -- you guessed it, chum -- the Dark Knight himself. The title opens with Batman racing back to Arkham, Gotham's home for the criminally insane, with the Joker in tow. Seems the Clown Prince of Crime broke out a few weeks ago, but Batman was able to track him down and re-apprehend the baddie. However, things are never what they seem with the Joker, so after getting the wiry maniac back into the building -- a building stocked with hundreds of the Joker's goons after a "mysterious" fire at their prison -- Mr. J breaks free with the help of Harley Quinn, takes control of the penitentiary, and releases all the inmates.Holy plot twist, Batman!From there, you're off on an adventure that ranks right below The Dark Knight movie in terms of awesome Batman experiences. The actual Arkham campus is a loony bin spread across multiple buildings on one massive rock. With the Joker in charge you're going to have to swing over rooms filled with gas, save doctors, rip vent covers off the walls so you can make a path around locked doors, and move as fast as Batman can to stop the Joker from releasing an army of monsters on the people of Gotham City.Now, that might sound like your typical Batman story -- and it kind of is -- but it's important to point out that this is a fairly adult title. Yeah, some of the folks from Batman: The Animated Series are back to reprise their roles (Mark Hamill is the Joker, Kevin Conroy is Batman, and Arleen Sorkin is Harley Quinn), but this isn't the cartoon. Harley's wearing a fairly skimpy outfit that shows off her lady parts, Poison Ivy's in some painted-on panties, colorful language like "♥♥♥♥♥quot; and "♥♥♥♥♥" is peppered in, and there are people getting murdered left and right. Arkham itself is a dark and dingy place that just had every psychopath housed there run through the halls tearing the building apart. Dead guards are laid out on the floor, papers are strewn about, and the facilities have seen better days.These adult themes tied in with a very, very Batman-looking world really drive home your connection to the story. I don't think I'm ever going to forget Mr. Zsasz holding a knife to a female doctor, her screaming for me to save her, the Joker screaming at Zsasz to kill her, and Zsasz screaming at me to stay back. After years of the Riddler being goofy, I realized Arkham's version of the character was on a different level when he told a Riddle that ended in dismembering a baby. Plus, the segments where you're under the Scarecrow's influence and Batman's worst fears are realized are some of the coolest, most cerebral parts of the game. These are the moments that wrapped me up in the experience and made me feel like Batman on the longest night of his life.Gameplay in this dark, creepy world breaks down into three main portions -- fist fighting, attacking from the shadows, and exploration. As you move from room to room chasing Harley or Commissioner Gordon's kidnapper, you're going to run into bad guys. Lots of times, you'll find a crew milling about or the Joker will spring a trap with handfuls of guys who are ready to kill you. This is when you'll make use of your straight hand-to-hand moves.Fist fighting in Arkham Asylum is pretty much the definition of an easy to learn/hard to master combat system. The game allows Batman to move faster than his enemies (He's a trained ninja, people!) and engage them in 360 degrees. You just point your left stick towards whatever enemy you want to attack and Batman follows suit. Through four buttons -- strike, reverse, jump, and stun -- you'll unleash Mr. Wayne's fury on the scum of the Earth. Obviously, you can just mash the strike button and take down the bad guys with a healthy set of animations -- dropkicks, elbows, punches, and more are peppered in -- and reverse when you see the spider-sense icon pop-up above a bad guy's head, but there's a sweet science to this madness.

												Surprisingly good game. I wasn't interested at first, but it turned out to be one I'll never forget. Think something inbetween God of War and Hitman, only with Batman as the main character and a backstory for everyone you encounter, even meaningless NPCs. The climate and voice acting is exceptional, it looks much better than your average unreal engine game.What surprised me the most was the sheer amount of extra content: character summaries, challenges, every batman costume you could think of in 3d, galleries, the riddler taunting you to find his hidden packages... it never stops.Whether or not you like/know anything about the bat, this game is an absolute must, especially when you can find it for £2.50 at a Tesco discount. You'd be mad not to give this a try.

content:
Posted: February 6
												One of the best games of its time. SO much to do in this game. We can start by saying YOU ARE THE ***-****ED BATMAN! It makes you feel like batman for sure. I walked around for days speaking in a gravelly voice, saying nothing but "I'm Batman". First off, the cinematic entrance and cutscenes are pure movie quality and totally get you into the immersion. Fighting is SO intuitive on computer! You CAN finesse it for sure...or you can just button mash most of it and win. And that's equally as fun and rewarding. At least until it gets harder toward the end. Then it takes more accuracy in moves and hits. The skill advancement system is topnotch. The game constantly rewrads you for progressing by giving you more and more toys to play with and more and more supermoves. And what's cool is that it is TOTALLY UP TO YOU what you spend your upgrades on. So if you want to get a zipline now, do so. You wanna pull down walls NOW okay. You want super armor. GIMME IT NOW. You want more batarangs. OKAY! So it let's you upgrade how you want to custom the gameplay toward how you want to play. I like the basic fighting but what I really like to do is obsessive-compulsively collect things. So this game was SO for me. You have to collect all the riddler trophies which are hidden in secret tough to get to spots. THis can mean figuring out how to get to them. Can also mean pulling walls down. Can also mean ...well you get the idea. You can also kill ALL the joker teeth you see. You can also find ALL the secret scarab plaques and listen to alfredlike voice drone on...you can also find all of the recordings about the Batvillains there are. You can also solve all of riddlers riddles. There is SO MUCH STUFF in this game to do. And there are nice maps you can find in each area to help you keep track of approzimately where the remainers are. And boy....the moves. Grappling up to high building ledges is SO wonderful. Beast feeling though is running off the side of a tall building and gliding forever through the night breeze, moon on your wings. Or swinging from gargoyle to gargoyle, then dropping and enveloping some thug below you and hanging him up. You FELL LIKE BATMAN in every inch of this game. Actually the feeling of this game is how I felt wandering about the world of Thief: the Dark Project by Eidos. That same kind of "solve the missions, upgrade how you want, wander around the world how you want, do things in the order you want in a mission, freeplay in this world" way. And the voice acting is topnotch. If there's any game I'd give a 10 it's this one. I guess my only criticism is the boss battles, though I don't really like boss battles in any game. They boil down to figure out why you are dying repeatedly. Find the move that keeps you from dying for a few seconds...then try the next move , etc rinse repeat until you figure out how to do damage...then grind through trying to do that until you kill the boss...suffering through dying 100 times. Yeah. Not EVERY boss fight is like that but there are a few doozies that made me give up for a long while. But really...this is a totally immersive and rewarding experience on many levels. What games should strive for.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I'm not one for superhero games, in fact, I don't really care much for superheroes in general. I'm a hipster, I like Spawn! But that's beside the point. Batman Arkham Asylum is beat-em'-up kind of game that moreso tests your reaction timing and ability to adapt moreso than actually beating up the enemies compared to Bayonetta or Devil May Cry. The music is a little on the bland side, its pretty generic.PROS- Arkham Asylum stands out as a game with a simple and easy combat system, terrific voice acting, a decent story, and level design (that more or less infuriates me in how confusing it is sometimes).- Excellent character portrayal, Joker is meant to be crazy while Batman is a brooding intellectual type, and boy, did they nailed it. If you're a big fan of the Batman universe, then you're definitely in for a treat. I'm not, but I still enjoyed it.- A small island with a giant♥♥♥♥♥and needlessly complicated facility  to explore, there's not much to explore, but its there. To, uh, you know, explore. - The Arkham series is the best game to try and make you feel like the Batman, and it does a pretty good job at doing that.CONS- Puzzles! Puzzles! Depending if you love 'em or hate 'em, its pretty well done here. Except the Riddler, that's kind of more annoying and tedious than anything else. The Riddler's riddles are well done, but the trophy collecting...ugh, remove that and I'd slap this as a pro.- Joker gets caught by Batman, Batman puts Joker in prison, Joker has a plan to break out, Batman screwed up, Joker is free,  Batman tries to stop Joker. This is your typical Batman vs Joker relationship that has been going for decades. Its nothing new, its just normal at this point and it'll never change. Mainly because Batman is against killing people. - For the Batman, you aren't very equipped at the very start to tackle much of anything, its a little sad, considering Batman is supposed to always come prepared for any kind of situations. I'm aware its more for not overwhelming the player all at once, but when its necessary to have those gadget upgrades to go back and hunt Riddler trophies, backtracking becomes a chore to scavenger hunt for those.A very good game that withstood the test of time, most games created during the seventrh generation looks very bad when you go back to it, but not this one! No sir, this game is definitely a good pickup, even if you're not a Batman fan like me.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
In briefStory: 7/10Graphics 7/10Gameplay 10/10Sound 10/10Playing this game for the 100th time on the PC in 2016, the game has lost absolutely none of its charm, it's still excellent. Only in hindsight am I giving this game less than 10/10 because Arkham City improves on the already excellent game.Overall 9/10Full ReviewI owned this game on release back in the day and played the heck out of it. I loved it, it was a revelation back then to play a Batman game...no a SUPER HERO game that didn't suck. Each hit felt like I was a real super hero, the voice acting was stellar, the story was excellent, a real upgrade system and collectibles which added extra layers of story.First of all the story. It's not really a story which will have you on the edge of your seat, the game does an excellent job of weaving a lot of characters into the plot as possible, but you will not really be playing the game for the in depth plot. It's pretty standard fayre for a super hero game, bad guy does bad thing in bad place, beat side bad guys to get to main bad guy to stop bad thing. However what the game excels at, is the amount of sheer effort it puts into character development and little easter eggs of story along the way. Aside from the main plot you will find a sub-plot of collectibles involving the Riddler, he will "challenge" you to find and solve all his riddles. These unlock character bio's for a lot of the Rogues gallery. The story is littered with villains(being set in Arkham Asylum that's no surprise), what I enjoyed was the particular attention paid to the "lesser" villains, not just the major ones. Killer Croc getting a huge look in, The Ventrilloquist having a hand in proceedings through Scarface(allbeit very minutely). The story at the time was excellent, but for those of you playing in 2016 and beyond, Arkham City is the game you want to play for story.How did the voice acting hold up? Amazing. Not much needs to be said about this, its Mark Hammil as the Joker. It's the guy who voiced Batman in the animated series as Batman. It's literal voice acting perfection. The only gripe is during the stealth parts of the game, sometimes the random thugs voices can get a little bland. Not enough to detract from the fantastic performances of Harley Quinn, Batman, Gordon and The Joker.How where the graphics Graphics? I'm not the best person to tell people about graphics, I thought they were all right, obviously not as good as future incarnations. However I'm not a graphics ♥♥♥♥♥, I like games for gameplay, so long as the graphics are decent I'll take it. The characters looked good, it wasn't blocky, I had no frame rate issues.Gameplay? This is where the game excels, and some 10 years later its still amazing to play. Each movement flows with such ease and it involves one button click. The slow addition of extra enemies keeps the gameplay fresh, wanting to add to your combo score keeps you coming back for more. There is slow addition to the maps without you even realising and a decent size for free roaming without the maps becoming dull. There is collectibles galore with interesting riddles along the way. The game is crammed with Batman easter eggs(personally favourite, go find Clayface). If you hate combat, you can try and stealth situations with a very good stealth portion of the game. Bosses feel fresh and have different mechanics to fighting them, not the awful "fight this guy" mechanic that previous super hero titles had given us for years. There is an upgrade system which isn't borderline ridiculous, you never get seriously overpowered but your gadgets slowly unlock portions of the game you wondered what they where for earlier. The main thing this game got right was the combat, beating enemies felt epic but never ridiculous. Too many superhero games get this so very wrong, Iron Man wouldn't struggle to beat a random guy with a gun, Superman shouldn't struggle to beat a generic thug. At the same time, it shouldn't require a 30 button combo for me to feel epic beating them up. Batman Arkham Asylum did it perfectly, LOTs of enemies with easy but satisfying combat. One button hits people, that's it, press x to hurt people. You flow from one enemy to the next, it looks and feels epic. However if you mess up, sheer numbers may hurt you, which is believable, Batman after all is naught but a man and he is often depicted in the comics as being injured after fights.Overall in 2016 I can still suggest this game, after finishing it multiple times years earlier I still went back into it and loved it, getting every achievement. 9/10 a MUST own game. The only reason it doesn't get 10/10 is because Arkham City is better.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												I will make this short and to the point.Storyline: Surprisingly well written considering it could have been another excuse for Batman to hit things. I can say no more (cus spoilers)Combat: Balanced and rewarding. Combo upgrades take a good few hours to unlock. Dodging five assailants attacking at once and still being able to beat them senseless never gets dull.Controls: A little unwieldy with mouse and keyboard. It is obvious from the outset this game was designed for consol controllers. If you don't have one hooked up to your PC I would recommend it to get the most from this game. (Remember, with a bit of work you can get your ps3, or Xbox, controller working using the "better ds3" tool and the right drivers if the steam controller looks too pricey)Graphics: This game has aged well, Would recommend running on highest settings though.Sound: Atmospheric, no catchy recurring theme music sadly.Secrets: My personal oppinion is that this game is all about the secrets. I believe there are over 15 for each map area and over 200 overall. It is easy to spend hours (literally) hunting in detective mode for hidden messages and riddle solutions. If you have intense OCD that you wish to placate and cure once and for all with the king of OCD games, then try to get 100% completion on this. No mean feat by any means.In conclusion... A very solid game which has earned its GOTY title. Expect it to take tens of hours off your life, but not hundreds. The sense that this game IS completable is a very attractive factor. Would recommend. Enjoy!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												So I always heard good things about the Batman Arkham games, but never got to play them. Last week I installed and played the copy of Batman: Arkham Asylum I had lying on my endlessly growing Steam backlog for the first time. After 30 hours of gametime, which included beating the campaign on both normal and hard difficulty, collecting all of the Riddler challenges, getting 3 stars on all the extra challenge mode games, and acquiring all of the achievements, I can confidently say that B: AA is one of the best games I ever played in a long time.I just want to preface the upcoming gushing I'm about to lay down by saying I love metroidvanias, am not very proficient in high execution gameplay, enjoy a good collect-a-thon, and think Batman is the♥♥♥♥♥♥ This game pushed so many of the right buttons for me as a result.The best description I can give for the gameplay is that it’s the perfect Batman experience. You can do most of the typical kind of platforming tricks you see in modern 3D action adventure games like in the Assassin Creed games but as Batman you have a variety of tools like a grappling hook that clings on almost all climbable ledges and a cape that helps you glide over larges distances. I found going around the titular asylum a very enjoyable experience, especially the occasional pure platforming and Scarecrow sections you’re encounter throughout the campaign.  The combat is probably the best part of the game. It really feels like you’re playing out a fight scene in a Batman cartoon or movie. It’s very simple to jump around the area pummeling your foes but you need proper timing and twitchy fingers to avoid getting hit and keeping your combo score up. You get a lot of tools and techniques that make the combat a breeze later on but I found myself being tested in some hard mode gauntlets and the dedicated challenge modes you unlock later in the game. Climbing on the larger titan enemies and forcing them to smack around the smaller goons is always a satisfying experience. The predator sections where you have to stealthily take out a bunch of armed enemies in a huge room is fun. Pure fun. There are so many ways to dispatch them that they made a dedicated game mode for it. And the way the goons start getting freaked out after you pick them off is hilarious as ♥♥♥♥. Like I said, a very Batman-like experience.While the campaign is pretty linear, there are a ton of collectables sprinkled throughout the island. In a way this game is pretty metroidvana-like in that aspect, as you can backtrack to older areas and use the new items you acquire as you progress through the game to find even more secrets.  While the trophy collecting was pretty basic, the riddles sprinkled throughout the world are brilliant. I got a kick out of finding all of the solutions. You’ll also find these little perspective puzzles that require you to find 2 parts of a question mark hidden on the architecture and align them with your camera so they look whole. It’s hard to explain but they were cool.The game is a visual and audible treat. The game looks very good, especially for an early-to-mid last gen game. I love all the minute detail for the world, like how Batman gets more visually damaged and grows a stubble as the campaign goes on. All the classic Batman characters get a gritty look that makes them look pretty badass (even though Batman still is wearing his underwear on the outside).  Getting some of the voices from the old animated series was pretty cool. Can’t say no to Steve Blum either./gushNow, I do have some gripes with the game, though. You more and less fight the same kinds of goons throughout the game. The boss fights aren’t very good either, especially the final boss fight. Spoiler: I don’t like that you’re basically have a generic video game-like fight with a huge monster version of the Joker instead of an elaborate battle of wits that you see in other Batman works. It just felt out of place is all.Anyway, I love this game and I am so looking forward to playing Batman Arkham games in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												Well, I finally played Arkham Asylum, and I'll be damned if that isn't the great video game adaptation of the Batman cartoon from the 90s. We have the most important VAs (Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamil as The Joker), we have a gloomy to creepy atmosphere, and we have a goofy but well-written plot that is dark only for specific values of dark. And that's where it lost me.See, I really like Arkham Asylum: A Serious House On Serious Earth. It's a solid graphic novel with gorgeous, disturbing art and a really interesting set of villains. I love Joker's motivation, to prove to Batman that he is just as crazy as his adversaries and belongs in Arkham right beside them. I love the concept of an Arkham doctor as a malefactor who turns Two-Face into a useless wreck. The game has hints of parts of fragments of the ideas which make the graphic novel so awesome.But it's not fair to judge the game as an adaptation of the graphic novel it's named for, no matter how much the opening credit sequence built my hopes up for a Joker who was as clever as he was wacky.On its own terms, the game is a great adaptation of the 90s Batman cartoon. It feels like it was written by the same team. The character designs range from solid to fantastic, with Scarecrow being a particular standout. The locations are gorgeous and grimy, laid out by a madman who no doubt had Amadeus Arkham and his madness in mind. All of the signs, the lighting, the color palettes come straight out of the 90s cartoon. In terms of gameplay, Arkham Asylum is polished and smooth. The freeflow combat system has that balance of easy to learn/hard to master. The predator missions are unique and enjoyable, compelling the player to find new and different ways to prowl and hunt. Games with an open world element depend on character mobility, and getting Batman where you want him is a satisfying affair. Remarkable, no, but satisfying. The only fault I can make note of in terms of gameplay is the boss fights. The first true boss is satisfying and fun, but using that same mechanic in half the big fight scenes in the game? It rubbed me wrong, though that's a matter of taste. What I consider pretty much unforgivable is using a glorified mook rush as the final boss fight.Overall, I enjoyed the gameplay in Arkham Asylum. The freeflow fighting system has more than taken off in the years since it came out, and the predator sequences are steath combat done well. It's a visually stunning game with great character design and solid, consistent writing. But at the end of the day, I feel like I missed out on something with this. I feel like I'm either too old or not in tune with the nostalgia frequency this game is broadcasting. It's a blast from someone else's childhood. I hope it's yours.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Awesome game. I recommend.The story line is nothing spectacular but is entertaining for Batman fans. Even if your not familiarized with the comic book's universe, as you play, the game provides a huge set of informations about chracters that may or may not appear during the game.On one hand, the combat features are incredible. There is a large amount of moves you can do while in a fight, specially if you make big combos. I don't quite know what it is but there is something about the sound it makes when you hit a thug or break his leg that brings that feeling of accomplishment towards the game and makes you play more.On the other hand, the stealth/predator mode lacks the silence and discretion I expected. The takedowns, except for the silent one are very noisy and attract almost all the prisoners to the location where it happened. There are also a lot of features that in the end make the game to easy in that area. The fact that the sonic batarang always attracts one and only one thug so you can take him down is kind of a buzz kill. In addition to that, if you want, you can easily take down three guys at the same time by using the multiple batarang and the ground pound once they are down, what makes the stealth unchallenging.The challenges are a great feature of the game and are nice to play even after you finished the campaing.To sum up, really good game even with small flaws in some areas.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												First game in the Batman series and it's very wellmade. The story is immense and there's just so much around it. Interviews, background stories and much more.Graphics are good, combat system is good and overall the game is easily one of the best Batman games to date. I finished it in around 11 hours by just doing the story, but there's enough challenges and secrets to last another 10-20 hours easily.So any negatives? The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ unreal engine as well as console base means you can't change sensitivity unless you change it in the config file manually. Also 2 of the bossfights were made with a console controller in mind which is also ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ cause when you play it on a PC it ruins the experience. Imagine playing the game for 10 hours in one way, then you're forced to do a 5 minute fight with the opposite controls. It's doable, but frustrating.Other than those two flaws, I'd class this game a straight 10 and very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Thouroughly enjoyed this game, I had previous experience with this game a few years ago but only now had the motivation to complete the story. The combat is fluent but can be repititive but still manages to stay satisfying, especially when using the batclaw for finishers and extended combos. Graphics are great for the time it was released and showed very little graphical errors (though some pixelation during the final cutscene). The riddler adds a lot of exploration and keeps your eyes open for anything and everything, not to mention spending a hell of a lot of time circling your camera around rooms in detective mode to find riddler trophies. The main plot had little depth but the riddler and the colectibles you gather than tell individual character stories are very promising for anyone who enjoys a thourough story. I'm yet to try any of the other modes but I can definitely recommend the game for its generally satisfying gameplay and interesting start to the Arkham game series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Still the best Batman game in the Arkham series and probably the best Batman game ever made. The story involves Batman catching Joker easily after a recent robbery and, coincidentally, Joker's gang moved to the Asylum because of an issue at the Blackgate Prison - once inside the Asylum, the Joker escapes and taskes control of the Asylum and prepares to unearth something far worse than what you initially suspect. You play as Batman trying to unearth this plot and once again stop the Joker.To this day, this game still has amazing visuals, Batman himself covering around half the screen, looks the part and stands strong and confident as the character should as well as the texture work on his suit are top notch - the rest of the game fairs the same, since the game has been given an outstanding amount of care and work into every area you go through. Not one area in the game feels exactly the same as another even if they look similar. Very stellar work of textures all around overall.I don't say this is the best Batman game out there for no reason - gameplay is pretty basic "Brawler" style with very minor puzzle solving, but what makes this game different, from, say a game like Assassin's Creed - is the "Free Flow combat system" the game has. The combat is slightly similar to the first Assassin's Creed, except - the flow combat system allows Batman to basically jump from one foe to another in a very fast manner, almost rythmically, to get a combo counter to go as high as you can while still making it challenging by giving the foes still standing a fighting chance and implementing counters. You can also explore the entirety of the Arkham Asylum as you unlock areas and you can do a variety of things while exploring, you can face groups of enemies scattered around, you can do Riddler Challenges - whom are a bunch of mini puzzles scattered around the Asylum that involves the use of Batman's Detective Mode, these range from finding a specific item found in the area or marks that require the Detective Mode to find and a "Complete the Mark" type of game that involves you scanning the area from specific places to complete a full mark, etc - Riddler trophies, and a bunch of case files to find out more background information on Batman characters and villains (as well as the history behind Arkahm Asylum) that are often very well realized and fun to hear. The Detective Mode & Gadgets: You'll be using these a LOT on your trudge through Arkham Asylum. Ranging from the standard Batarangs and Grappling hook (used for mundane objectives such as getting to and pulling out vents from hard to reach places, etc), the Explosive Gel (Used a lot to surprise enemies, to find weak walls to find trophies and secrets and to progress in the story as well!) and a bunch more. The Detecive Mode helps you analyze weak walls to use your Explosive Gel on and other gadgets as well as analyze enemy/allies conditions and, more important later on in the game, to find out which enemies carry weapons or are special enemies.).So in general, if you ever wanted to know and feel what a life in the day of Batman is, this is definately your game, more so than the sequels (imo). From the excellent assets and sound to follow it up with, and the pitch perfect gameplay to go along with it, this sits as one of my favourite video game experiences and currently my best experience playing as the legendary Dark Knight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												Well, I finally played Arkham Asylum, and I'll be damned if that isn't the great video game adaptation of the Batman cartoon from the 90s. We have the most important VAs (Kevin Conroy as Batman and Mark Hamil as The Joker), we have a gloomy to creepy atmosphere, and we have a goofy but well-written plot that is dark only for specific values of dark. And that's where it lost me.See, I really like Arkham Asylum: A Serious House On Serious Earth. It's a solid graphic novel with gorgeous, disturbing art and a really interesting set of villains. I love Joker's motivation, to prove to Batman that he is just as crazy as his adversaries and belongs in Arkham right beside them. I love the concept of an Arkham doctor as a malefactor who turns Two-Face into a useless wreck. The game has hints of parts of fragments of the ideas which make the graphic novel so awesome.But it's not fair to judge the game as an adaptation of the graphic novel it's named for, no matter how much the opening credit sequence built my hopes up for a Joker who was as clever as he was wacky.On its own terms, the game is a great adaptation of the 90s Batman cartoon. It feels like it was written by the same team. The character designs range from solid to fantastic, with Scarecrow being a particular standout. The locations are gorgeous and grimy, laid out by a madman who no doubt had Amadeus Arkham and his madness in mind. All of the signs, the lighting, the color palettes come straight out of the 90s cartoon. In terms of gameplay, Arkham Asylum is polished and smooth. The freeflow combat system has that balance of easy to learn/hard to master. The predator missions are unique and enjoyable, compelling the player to find new and different ways to prowl and hunt. Games with an open world element depend on character mobility, and getting Batman where you want him is a satisfying affair. Remarkable, no, but satisfying. The only fault I can make note of in terms of gameplay is the boss fights. The first true boss is satisfying and fun, but using that same mechanic in half the big fight scenes in the game? It rubbed me wrong, though that's a matter of taste. What I consider pretty much unforgivable is using a glorified mook rush as the final boss fight.Overall, I enjoyed the gameplay in Arkham Asylum. The freeflow fighting system has more than taken off in the years since it came out, and the predator sequences are steath combat done well. It's a visually stunning game with great character design and solid, consistent writing. But at the end of the day, I feel like I missed out on something with this. I feel like I'm either too old or not in tune with the nostalgia frequency this game is broadcasting. It's a blast from someone else's childhood. I hope it's yours.

content:
Posted: August 7, 2014
												Well, the Batman Begins game did well and WB wanted to make a game for The Dark Knight, but after the passing of heath ledger they felt, for various reasons, this would not be a good endevour. the game was given to newcommer "Rocksteady" and to focus on a new plot and use mostly the voice cast of Batman: The Animated Series. Emmy award winning batman writer, Paul Dini, was brought on the write the project. The game takes place around the early 1990s batman comics but set in a unique universe with loose ties to the comics, animated series and nolanverse. Paul Dini took the early 1980s batman comics and adapted them into the emmy award winning animated series in a way no one else had done, modernising the stories, tieing them loosely into the films of the time and the comics and also making a dark, gritty and serious world while still keeping it sutiable for children. Paul Dini once again deliverse in this, tying the story loosly to the comics and the curent films and modernising the  90s stories but now the story is geared to a teen to adult audience and paul dini's story telling genius is back in full force. An amazing game for anyone thirteen and up!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												I know I'm very late posting this review, but I'm going to do it anyway.TL;DR:Pros:- Smooth combat system (choice of beat-em-up or stealth)- Be the Batman. Use his gadgets.- Learn more Batman lore than you knew existed- Engaging and new plot- Dynamic Dialogue- Appealing art style and graphicsCons:- Controls on Mac were a little hard to get used to, but you can change your keyboard bindings, and I believe you also have the option of playing with a gamepad.Breezy's full review: Batman: Arkham Asylum is hands down the best video game based on a comic that I've ever played and one of the best games overall in my collection. I remember playing the demo at my local GameStop and being sort of skeptical as it just seemed like another beat-em-up. Flash forward to about 5 years later and I'm so glad that I was wrong.    The story is refreshing and encapsulating. The dialogue is great (a lot of times humorous, a lot of times epic, only sometimes corny). Like everyone else says, the combat system is the most fluid I've seen in a video game, though I much prefer the "Predator" style of combat (taking out enemies stealthily) in the game. Being the Batman and getting to use all his gadgets (Batclaw, Detective Mode, explosive gel, batarang (in the form of the normal, multiple, explosive, and remote controlled)), and appearances by both the Batmobile and the Batwing were definitely a treat.   I honestly have to say that the Riddler trophies were my favorite part of the game. When the trophies were first introduced in the game I really had no intention of collecting all 240 of them. But the developers did something very clever and linked character backgrounds to most of the trophies. Some of the trophies take the form of interview tapes with Arkham inmates, Chronicles of Arkham (cryptic messages left by Amadeus Arkham to be found and deciphered), or simply scanning the environment as a visual answer to one of the Riddler's riddles. Of course, there are actual trophies you can find, but I much prefered the ones that would provide some background on the characters. Before this game, I had minimal knowledge of the Batman universe. When I discovered that the trophies could actually unlock character bios (and some nice viewable character trophies), I became obsessed with finding them. Through the character bios and other various forms of the trophies, I became educated on more of the Batman universe than I thought I would want to know. But don't get me wrong, every detail about a character or asset in the Batman world interested more than the last.   Actual gameplay wise, I probably beat it in about 12-13 hours. However, as you can see from my hours played, I spent a lot more time in the game than that. What was I doing? Collecting trophies, of course. Also, I spent several hours in the challenge maps where you rack up points by seeing how long of a combo you can get on enemies or you complete predator challenges, where you must knock out enemies in a specific way (i.e. break through a glass ceiling to take out an enemy). The GOTY Edition DLC  offers you the choice of playing as the Joker in these challenge maps, and it's pretty awesome and a nice change of pace from playing as Batman. End note:My only real prior knowledge of Batman came after Christopher Nolan's Dark Knight Trilogy and that was about the extent of it (besides watching a few episodes of the animated series growing up). The movies were great, expecially the Dark Knight, but they didn't really expand on the Batman universe, but instead focused on dark realism. This game, however, seemed to capture the wonder and atmosphere of the Batman comics and various animated series. I guess you could say that Batman has gained a Batfan. Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												Every now and then there are games that achieve every single ambition their designers had. Arkham Asylum is among them. It both redefined the action adventure and is among the best representations of Batman, comics and movies included. Batman is possibly the only superhero I still find interesting in any way. This is because he fits the tormented hero archetype without simply repeating it. He also has no superpowers which make other superheroes so limited. Instead he uses his brain and never kills anyone. There are two extremes to the character: the Brooding Batman wallowing in human misery and the smart-as-a-whip Gadget Batman. Here he is somewhere in the middle and this works well.The other thing that makes Batman so interesting are certain villains. The conflict between Batman and The Joker is always interesting and has inspired many creative minds. Mark Hamill delivers one of the best VA performances yet, equal to Jack Nicholson or Heath Ledger. There are far too many villains in the Batman universe and the game veers dangerously close of being a Con Air stuffed with supercriminals. This more-is-more tendency also extends to the silly collectibles, but thankfully there are clever puzzles involved so they are tolerable. Scarecrow is used to the fullest of his potential as well. Robin is one of the most unnecessary characters in comics history (and there are many contenders) and I thank the makers that they left him out completely.The close combat system was an instant classic in game design and no subsequent effort can escape it's influence. Clearing rooms of gun-wielding thugs has many alternate routes and the entire "moving puzzle" idea is always fresh. The Gothic asylum setting is also interesting to explore, and the various Bat-gadgets are fun and natural to use. Graphical presentation is incredibly detailed and life-like, and every single sound I heard was just-so as well. There is simply no reason to skip this 15-hour adventure.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Visiting "Batman: Arkham Asylum" six years after the shift it created for the WB Interactive brand, if not the creation of licensed games as a whole, I found it too easy to get hung up on more lacking aspects like the ugly array of secondary colors lifted from the NES "Batman", and how at too many times Paul Dini seems to bring his B-game. None of which, I hope, detracts from how much this game earns its marks. Along with being great, it's a compulsively interesting study on how eclecticism can influence an adaptation of a fictional character's exploits.Much has already been made about how "Arkham Asylum" moves gracefully between different Bat-genres while giving new dimensions to them, as well as how Rocksteady gave the bread-and-butter combat roots in the rhythm-game genre. What the game reminded me the most of, and the influence I found the heaviest, was a dungeon-crawler RPG. That influence is in the long corridors marked with puzzles and action events, connected by an (undercooked, I would say) overworld. It's in the pattern-based boss fights, and how Batman expands his arsenal with devices that change what parts of the environment can be accessed. And I especially see it in the way every punch connected and riddle solved levels Batman up to make him an even more capable fighter. That's the framework I applied to the various moments of sophisticated brawler action and terse stealth encounters that comprise this game, the moments many other players have celebrated, and it makes the game an imaginative tableau. As the combat parts are defined by their button-pressing elegance, the ability to administer surprise neutralizations from above and from behind in the stealth sections is what refines them into their own complete experiences. It overrides how, at their worst (e.g., the mission with the rigged gargoyles), they're the tedious tests of "just move already!" patience that could stop the flow for good in earlier sneak-based titles. All the playstyles work very well, Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill are old pros, and the Bat-story makes the game an intimidating depiction of what's already one of Gotham's scariest corners - something that gives it an advantage as an adaptation. What being menaced by the Scarecrow in the robust hallucinatory segments (and to a lesser extent, Killer Croc in the sewers) does most of all is round out one of the central ideas to this whole series: that there are parts equally scary, unsettling, and ultimately escapist about being Batman. Keeping that idea so prominent, and with such gameplay as it has, makes "Batman: Arkham Asylum" something of a standout in the franchise.
