content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
 Click Here for the Full Review! [monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com]Synopsis: A great game that combines, at about a 2-1 ratio, melee heavy combat with stealth focused areas. Comparing this game to Zelda seems rather apt, as you'll find that you can only explore a portion of a current zone (i.e. dungeon) until you uncover the one key item you need to get to the boss, which will allow you to unlock a bit more of the somewhat open world. Combat is fun, as you deal with multiple enemy types when engaged in melee, requiring you to attack stun baton enemies from behind, knife wielding enemies to be stunned with your cape first, and generally paying attention to which of the dozen enemies you're fighting will be attacking you first. Plenty of collectibles out there is you feel like solving some of the Riddler's puzzles, and while the game is focused on the Joker vs. Batman rivalry, the game does a great job of bringing in a variety of major Batman villains.Expect about 16 hours to get a 100% completion on the story side. I've rated it an 9/10, and recommend picking it up at $10 or less, though you can probably find it at $5 during a major sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Gameplay: This game has a mix of platforming, fighting and puzzle-solving. The platforming is basic, but made interesting with the addition of gadgets; which you can use to pull down walls, get to un-reachable places and more. The fighting system is very deep, and trying to get high combos is always fun. The puzzles are consistently unique, though normally relatively easy.Story: Arkham Asylum is written like a comic-book, with many classic characters scattered throughout the narrative. There are a few surprising plot twists and occassionally emotional parts.Graphics: The entire island is very well detailed, filled with easter eggs and secrets. Each area has a great atmosphere and looks very unique. Sound: The music is on par with the Batman movies (by Nolan) and voice acting is very good.Re-playability: There are heaps of collectables and lots of extra challenges to attempt.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I have already beat and played the meatloaf out of Arkham City, and Origins.  That being said, Batman: Arkham Asylum is kinda far off.Let's not get anything wrong here.  Playing as Batman is simply amazing.  You really get that feel of Batman as you glide from gargoyle to gargoyle, and dangle people from a rope that's attached to the gargoyle.  However, Arkham Asylum's controls and game mechanics are far off than City's.  Gliding is practically non-existant, and when there is enough space to glide, you can't grapple onto anything mid-flight.  This is rather frustrating, because you often can't get the drop on a baddie unless you flop on the floor first, then grapple.  The fighting is almost identicle.  You can land hits from 20 feet away, and just punch those baddies until they drop.  The biggest con I found however, was the story.  I had a hard time following the story, and there hardly was one.  The ending felt empty and un-rewarding, unlike City's ending which made you feel like crying into your pillow.This is a nice addition to the other two, and it's where the series started.  I highly recammend this title, except not for the $30 price range.  Wait until it's on sale, around $10.  You will get all the thrills of being The Batman, however not as much as you would playing the other two additions to the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This game is amazing. It's semi-set in a Batman: The Animated Series universe, but it's probably some sort of spin-off. This is a great jumping-in point for the Batman series even if you're not familiar with it. You encounter a lot of rogues, and there's also a lot of references and explanations of Batman characters and big events for exploring the environment. This is essentially a Metroidvania game, taking place on Arkham Island, going between different areas of the Asylum and getting gadgets. Besides exploration, combat is split-up between predator rooms, where you are the night and effortlessly disable a room of goons using traps, and hand-to-hand combat which is sort of rhythm based and something a lot of games have since tried to copy. A true classic, and in some ways superior to its sequels due to its focused linearity and stripped-back nature.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												I bought Batman Arkham Asylum on a steam franchise sale at 75% off, but I was only barely into it when it became clear that purchasing this at full price would have been well justified. Arkham Asylum is a really solid game that combines platforming, combat, and light puzzle solving with break up the action nicely and gives you time to sit back and enjoy the game. Strong game play elements combined with a near fetishistic obsession with Batman trivia and voice acting by many of the folks who made the Batman Animated series make this an absolute joy for any Batman enthusiast. Countless hours into it and the combat is still fun, the pacing is solid, and the side quest style content still hold my attention. My one gripe is that the character designs are a little over the top; the attempts to make an “adult” Batman game with even-more gruesome villains and over-sexed vileness's makes me feel like I’m playing “Todd McFarlane presents Batman.” Arkham Asylum is a fun game and one of the few non-co-op games I keep feeling motivated to come back to.~ Strategy Artist

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												The original and still the best in the series.It's more focused environment leads to a more tightly crafted game that just begs to be explored. While the later games in the series offer a more open ended approach with arguably more things to see and do, in practice they seem to offer little more than filler between heavily scripted events. While collectibles, secrets and side missions often feel like chores in the later games, they feel like meaningful reasons to fully explore the asylum with appropriate rewards on offer. Each area is filled with unique assets and small, rememberable details. The riddlers side missions task you with photographing scenes that are unique to various characters from the Dark Knight universe which helps to direct the player toward these specially crafted, and unique in-game assets.The combat system, while arguably too simplistic, is a delight to control as you see Batman stringing insane combo's together effortlessly disarming, and countering incoming attacks. Every kick, punch, grapple and counter is animated well making fights seem appropriately realistic and violent. The combat is assisted by some excellent audio leading to some satisfying crunches, cracks, and smacks as bones break and fists collide with faces.The metroid-vania aspects of the game are implemented well, with each upgrade offering the oppertunity to revisit locations throughout the game.The story is well told and the voice acting is excellent throughout, although I felt the final parts of the story were anticlimactic with the final boss fight in particular being tedius and frankly, rather silly. Seeing the Joker turn into a roid-raged meathead seemed rather out of character, and a little far-fetched - even for a comic book super villain.On a technical level, the game still looks great to this day and runs exceptionally well. A mid-range pc should be able to run this game on maximum settings with a solid 60fps.All-in-all it's a ground breaking game and in my opinion one of the best games of it's generation. A true masterpiece.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2013
												Batman Arkham Asylum is an action\adventure "super hero" game.So after many average and horrible batman games is Batman Arkham Asylumworth trying ? well I can answer your question right away.You start the game when batman caught the most famous villian the Jokerand sents him back to prison ( Arkham Asylum ) where he should be belong,even though the guards should be able to do the rest, batman sense that something isn't quite right and that he should keep his eye on Joker after all Joker gave up so easily almost without a fight. After what it seems that the Joker well be sent to his place, Joker escaped killing the guards in his way and somehow controlling all the asylum in a blink of an eye. Now it up to batman to stop Joker and find out what was Joker's planning all this time.Gameplay : the combat is great and fluid almost perfect, it combines stealth approach, puzzles and riddles and of course brute force. This is the first game that will make you feel that you are the batman that you are in cotrol of your gadgets, fighting style and detective's skills.I can rest assure you that Batman Arkham Asylum gameplay is one of the best there is to offer.Story : its been a long time since I was so interested in a game's storyline,the cutscenes\dialog\twists are just great. You will be suprised and thrilled by what will come next, also lets not forget about the characters which all of them are amazingly done. Graphics : What can I say ? beautiful,amazing,outstanding and perfectly fit to the batman's art style. One of the best I have seen in 2009 and even today its just plain impressive.AI + difficulty : this is where I think that Batman Arkham Asylum could be better,while the game has diffrent enemies and every boss fight is unique, still the gameis too damn easy even on the hard difficulty, only the challenges gives the feeling that I might actually lose.Music + Sound : I can't say too much cause the only thing that comes in my mind is the word "Perfection" Summary : Batman Arkham Asylum trully deserves the "Game of the year" title of 2009, one of the most suprising,impressive and outstanding games there is to offer and God help those who didn't play the game yet. The only thing that bothers me was the difficulty which was too easy for me, but overall I'll give this game a 9.5\10

content:
Posted: June 22, 2011
												Being a fan of Bruce Tim animations, open worlds and upgrade collection, Arkham Asylum scratched an itch.  This is one instance where a license appears to have been handled correctly with a competent product.  Hearing the old cast, wielding Batman's arsenal and using stealth to take down enemies were all immensely satisfying.However, I had two problems with the game:1) Arkham Asylum traps the player inside boss battles.  Want to explore and upgrade?  Tough.  The game decided to autosave.  You're stuck playing a frustrating minigame with questionable resemblance to normal combat.2) Enemies don't respawn.  When solving riddles, this is good for decreasing travel time.  However, I didn't learn the bulk of the combat basics until the final battle.  I focused on stealth, rarely counterattacked and made it through with a low combo count.  By the time more advanced techniques were necessary, I had removed every opportunity to experiment from the story.  Practice in the challenges.

While later games added features, sometimes at the expense of everything working exactly as planned, Asylum lives up to its early hype as a solid, rhythmic action game with plenty of engaging and entertaining distractions. content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Batman: Arkham Asylum was the best action game of 2009.  I originally played this game on Xbox 360, but revisited the PC version and enjoyed it again even more with crisper graphics.  While the game does have some beat 'em up elements to it, it won't tire you out on them.  Though, if you do enjoy them, like I did, the game offers a challenge mode that lets you enjoy the wonderful contextual combo system.  Much of the appeal is the puzzle-like approach to clearing a room, or getting to your next objective by sticking to the shadows and using the fear tactics that Batman is known for.  The story is compelling, and the gameplay offers just enough variety to keep it from feeling bland.  There is a pleasant mixture of brawling, stealth action, story sequences, and detective work to keep your attention.If you haven't yet played Batman: Arkham Asylum, I would highly recommend the PC version using either mouse/keyboard or a 360 game controller, especially before the sequel arrives!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
 Originally posted on December 25, 2010 I didn't really expect Batman AA to be all that good. I picked it up on steam for $10 and was really pleasantly surprised.Graphics-The game runs on the Unreal 3 engine, and it actually looks quite good. The outdoor sections are a little less impressive, but the character models, lighting, and effects all look great. This game won't blow anyone away with it's mind blowing visuals, but it's very pretty. Furthermore, the art style is phenomenal. You wouldn't think being faithful to the comic books would be a good thing, but it really works here. It's a comic book world, but the artwork is dark, moody, and beautiful: it really draws you in. Little touches like the way Batman gets little rips, tears, cuts, and scratched over the course of the game just add to this.Sound-Voice acted by the cast from the animated series, the voice acting is generally quite good, with Mark Hamill's Joker being my personal favorite. I wasn't a fan of Harley Quinn's voice actress, but it is a matter of preference. All in all, the characters really come to life as a result of having long term actors on the series involved. The music and sound effects are all great, very moody. The audio diaries add to this, although I thought the script for some of them could have been a little better, but again it's a matter of choice. Bioshock did something similar, and I preferred it to Arkham's, but that's not to say the audio diaries here aren't fun.Gameplay-The game is a brawler and stealth game, mixing different elements of the two genres. I really think it's at it's best when you are given freedom to move: gargoyles and the like, with a variety of ways to take down armed enemies. Of course, there are definitely sections where you must fight mobs of guys with your fists. The fighting is easy to grasp the basics of, but hard to master, and it takes skill to really get a hold of it, which is a good thing in my book. The gadgets, upgrades, and complex under the hood sort of bits of the gameplay really add to the depth, and I'll admit I still didn't realize some of the creative ways to take guards down after I'd beaten the game- I saw them online. My biggest gripe with the gameplay was the sections where the camera was shifted. Parts of the game (first appearance is in the scarecrow section) will take the camera from behind batman and put it farther back in a fixed but tracking location. While this is meant to give you better visibility, on the PC I found that it was incredibly frustrating to deal with, because the controls in these sections are clearly designed for consoles. wasd doesn't control your avatar based on the way hes facing, but it is instead tied to the camera. The result is a clumsy control interface during these sections.All in all though, the gameplay is really solid, and beyond the campaign there's a good amount of replay value in the form of challenges and collecting batman memorabilia.Pros:great visual designincredible comic book aestheticgood voice actingreally intuitive, fun gameplaygood replay valueCons:a bit sloppy as a PC port in placesUE3 engine doesn't look great at medium to long distances.Ultimately, this game is great and is well worth playing for anyone, even someone who isn't a fan of brawlers like me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a third person action-adventure game that puts you in control of the famous Caped Crusader.  Up until this game came out in 2009, there were very few, if any, good video games based on comic book super-heroes, but Rocksteady really nailed this one.The game follows Batman as he delivers his arch-nemesis, the Joker, to Arkham Asylum, a facility for the criminally insane located on an island off the shores of Gotham City.  As you might imagine, all hell breaks loose and you square off against many of your well-known super-villains and their thugs as you try to restore order.The island is quite large and you get to (eventually) access all the buildings situated there.  Loading times are magically kept to a bare minimum.  The game uses the checkpoint save system, but they are fairly generous with those saves and you are rarely faced with having to replay very much after an unfortunate failure.  There are three difficulty choices for the game and they do an excellent job of slowly introducing you to the moves and gadgets.The storyline is well-written and gives great purpose to your actions.  There are many short cutscenes and the performances by the voice actors are superb throughout, especially fan favorite Mark Hamill’s Joker.  So many quotable lines and wonderful humor make this a joy to experience.  The graphics are also excellent including the animation of the action.  You really feel like you are Batman, whether brawling with goons or using your grapple to soar around the island.  The number of moves you can perform is staggering.Since you are Batman, gadgets are an important part of the experience.  No shortage here as you have quite an array of items to choose from including batarangs, explosives, hacking devices, zip lines and more.  The Batmobile even makes a brief appearance.This game is meant to be played with a controller although the traditional PC keyboard/mouse setup works just fine.  In fact, I played it without a controller against the advice of family and friends and felt completely in control, even with my abysmal gaming skills.Collectors and achievement junkies will be in heaven as there is much to do, adding to the story’s gameplay.  The Riddler has planted puzzles galore for you to find and solve and much of it unlocks interesting facts about the story and the characters.  There are also challenges that are best tackled after the campaign is complete (so all gadgets are unlocked).  These involve rounds of combat and stealth challenges in different settings.  Depending on your gaming abilities, it could take over 30 hours to master all the challenges and collectibles in the game.The GOTY Edition can usually be found on sale if you have patience and it is definitely a great value if you have any interest in the world of Batman.  Even after a few years, it holds up very well.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Arkham Asylum is, for the most part, great.Starting from the beginning, it has a simple plot in the typical Batman settings. There's not much unique to that. If you like Batman, you're likely to enjoy the game in that regard, if you don't like Batman, well, it's not bad either way. For one reason or another you're trappen in the Arkham Asylum, the one place in Gotham City where every crazy demented criminal goes to waste. The Joker has taken control over the place, and as Mario jumps till he reaches Bowser, you fight thugs and sneak around to get to the Joker.The good part about the Arkham settings is that it makes the perfect excuse to introduce a lot of known Batman's villains, because, well, they were all jailed in there. This makes the game a whole lot less monotone that it coudl've been if the whole plot was centered around one villain, as it's the case with Batman movies and comic issues. Regarding the gameplay, let me start with saying it is wonderful. There's mostly two sides to it, The sneaky parts and the action parts, those often come in tandem, sometimes it's your choice which one will reflect a specific section of the game, and sometimes you're forced to walk either path. This actually helps the flow of the whole storytelling a lot, since the tension of the Sneaky Sections contrast nicely with the, well, action of the Action Parts. The sneakaround parts come with a ton of gadgets that characterize the Batman, most of them giving you that extra mobility to navigate a given level in a varied array of directions. These sections of the game truly give you freedom to approach them however you want with easy to understand mechanics and a ton of possibilities. It reminded me of one of my favourite games ever in that regard, Metal Gear Solid 3. The Action bits, though, are completely different from MGS3. It's a whole lot more like an spectacle fighter than anything else I can think of. In all honesty, I dont have enough experience with that kind of games to be able to gauge it against a titan of the genre. That said, the combat flows wonderfully, you get a great sense of motion and control when you start getting a big combo against several enemies.The melee combat is pretty simple, you mash the hit button till a visual indicator tells you it's time to counter, and you do that aiming to the direction of the upcoming treat and hitting the counter button at the right time. That said, there's a bunch of things you can do mid combat depending of the gadgets you have acquired and the types of enemies you're facing.But more than the blunt melee combat itself, what I enjoyed the most where the handful of levels that allowed me to set up the arena before engaging into inevitable combat. You can plant explosives, bait enemies, make surprise aerial kicks from afar, knock 'em down silently, distract them with noises, hanging them upside down from a gargoyle in the roof, and a bunch of other stuff as well. There are some levels that allow you to bring down every single enemy without them detecting you, Dark Knight Style. The enemy AI is decent enough, and its quite satisfying hearing them talk to each other and ramble in fear because The Bat Is Here.The Content - Ive beaten the game in about 15 hrs. playing on normal difficulty.There's enough extra content to pump it maybe to 20 hrs if you're a completionist.I bought the game on a steam sale, paying 4.99 USD for it and it was totally worth it.Of all the side missions and extra content I'd say the most noteworthy for me where the Riddler's Challenge. I spent a few extra minutes on each level that had one trying to figure them out, and you get to feel pretty clever when you find one of the hardest ones out.Regarding the game visuals, It has a pretty visceral, almost gross look to it, and I think that fits pretty well with the grittiness of Gotham, and even more with Arkham. Not a fan of the Joker's design on this one, but that's about it.Going back to the gameplay part a little, the boss fights strike a weird place in the whole concept. It's almost as if they were done by a different team. They're usually good, don't get me wrong, but they lack the freedom and thinkering every other level has that makes you feel like you're the Bat. Each boss is usually beaten one way and one way only, It's pretty intensive and some of the encounters are pretty hard until you figure out how the enemy actually works and what you're supposed to be doing. You also get to see the Genius Detective at work in these ones, but it usually happens in a cinematic and it's usually the part where the boss gets beaten. There's a lot of extra lore to learn and listen from the secrets you find in each level, though I wish they'd just done whats has been proven to work in games like Bioshock and let you listen to those "interview tapes" while you keep playing - having to stop in a menu to listen to them sometimes really screws the pacing over and while you *can* play the tape and exit the menu to listen to it while you play, any enemy dialog that accidentally comes to play will stop the tape, making you sometimes have to replay the tape completely just to hear the 2 last words you missed. Pretty annoying.TL;DR? - It's a good game, if it's in a sale, definetly worth it. If it's not on sale and you can afford it, make sure it's your type of game, then sure. It has my recommendation.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Arkham Asylum, A serious house on Serious Earth. This game understands batman, as it tries to undo every other batman game that has come before. Arkham Asylum in this game is not just a setting for which the story takes place in a lot of ways it is the story. This entire game plays out like a crucible of sorts for the dark knight. You are thrown into a situation where the inmates have taken control of the asylum, and you are forced to explore the Asylum in its entirety in order to deduct the real reason your in this situation. You will quickly discover things are not as they appear. Gameplay is relatively simple a rhythm-based combat system, and the plot is pretty straight forward. Along the way you'll have levels and experiences that challenge and aim to psychologically ruin the dark knight, but its all made very enjoyable, and there are an exceptional amount of characters and cameos. Based on the time this game was released I'd say its worthy of a perfect 10 point score

Ran into a few crashes and a couple of points where I had to validate the games files in order to continue on, but overall pretty stable.  GOTY? No, Good game? Yes. 7.8 outa 10

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												So i decided i would try to get into the Batman games, and gave this one a go. i found it very fun. I fully expected a game in which you went in all guns blazing and just killed everything, but what i got was a game where you had to sit up high above everyone, and think about how to tackle a situation. I played this game on normal difficulty and finished it in 12 hours. However that was just the main story, if i went back and found all of riddlers trophies it would take considerably longer, normal difficulty was certainly very challenging, dying many times and getting very frustrated. I played the game with the mouse and keyboard, but would advise on the gamepad if you have access to one, as it can get a bit fiddly when facing multiple enemies.Overall this game was very fun, i got it on humble bundle with Arkham City which i will start playing straight away.There is a free roaming element to this game, however it's mostly indoors, with one outdoor area, that isn't entirely massive.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												Portraying Batman as equal parts detective, ninja, and asskicker, Arkham Asylum integrates a compelling story with addictive gameplay, resulting in an overall great production. The addition of cast members from The Animated Series was a welcome touch. Combat has some faults, and Arkham Asylum isn't the most spacious playground, but you'll likely be too busy punching, kicking, prowling, and searching for Easter Eggs to allow the game's shortcomings to hamper your enjoyment of this quality title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 4, 2015
												Ah, Batman Arkham Asylum. The beggining to a fantastic series, and the greatest Batman videogame series of all time. Simply a masterpiece.Where do I start?Arkham Asylum is unique compared to the other 3 games (I include Origins, no hate), because it's not open world. So you don't have a huge playground to play around with. It also has the most difficult stealth and combat, and other things, due to lacking double counters, double takedowns, knockout smashes, quickfire gadgets, the dive bomb, and most importantly, quick escapes with the Grapnel Boost/Accelerator or the Smoke Pellet. Here, armed men actually pose a challenge. That makes you think more tactically and plan ahead, more than the other games.Definitely recommended.I recommend to play the whole series in this order : Asylum, then City, then Origins, and finally, Arkham Knight. Trust me.9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												Arkham Asylum tossed me straight back to the original SEGA Genesis Batman game I loved. Everything feels so weighty - you know you're The Batman. The combat, the easy (but nonetheless well-themed) puzzles, the riddles, and especially the writing and incredible voice acting screams Burton Batman mixed with the best of the animated TV series and comic books.Mark Hamil as the Joker is incredible as always, and Kevin Conroy is the Bruce Wayne we've all come to know and hold dear. The gameplay and navigation is fine tuned and a pleasure to play. This is definitely a comic-book/animated Batman world, not too much like the Nolan movies, but still a Dark and Terrifying place to be.Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the finest third person brawlers I've ever played. If you don't like cartoon villians and heroes and prefer something perfectly realistic, this may be the only reason to avoid the game - I treasured it.

content:

												Surely you've already heard how good this is, right?  I'm usually more of a first-person-shooter fan, but I'm glad I listened to the hype on Arkham Asylum.  It's a Batman game done right and if you haven't played it, then you should.It's an even darker and grimier take on the Batman universe than even that portrayed in the new films (if you can believe that), but it works.  Mark Hammil reprises his "Batman: The Animated Series" role as The Joker and doesn't disappoint.  The atmosphere is great, the combat is generally awesome, and of course there are all those wonderful toys!  (Plus, it's got collectibles and achievements for the 100%'ers like me out there.)

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Now that Windows Live has been extracted from Batman: Arkham Asylum, there's no better time to get it.An amazing game. You don't have to be an avid Batman fan in order to enjoy this game. The game has a lot of lore you can discover about the specific characters in Gotham.The game has a great free flow combat system: easy to learn, yet difficult to master.You'll be constantly switching from beating up a bunch of criminals in the open to being stealthy and trying to take out armed criminals with your gadgets.There's a lot of collectibles in this game ranging from trophies to audio tapes of some of the most deranged criminals of Gotham.The visuals are stunning even if the game itself is half a decade old; there's a lot of great atmosphere, even making some parts "scary".The achievements aren't ridiculously hard either; you'll be playing this game for a while if you decide to go 100%, which I highly recommend to everyone.Overall, this game is a must get especially when it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												Story (9/10):Batman: Arkham Asylum is one of the best games I have ever played.  You play, as the title suggests, as *dramatic pause* Batman!  Armed with many iconic gadgets like the batarang, grapple, smoke bombs, and many more, it is your mission to put a stop to the Joker's plans within the Asylum.The story is exciting, and unique.  As you progress, you must adapt and master new skills as objectives become more difficult to complete.  Iconic characters will make appearances as you progress.  Most will try to kill you, some will try to pull a fast one and try to backstab you, still one in particular will even try to eat you.  You will be in danger from start to finish, captivated by the eerie environment and developing story.Visuals (10/10):Arkham Asylum is a bit dated now, so the graphics are not considered as stunning as they once were.  However, maxed out, it still looks very good.  The asylum is true to its comic book origins, meaning it is dark, depressing, and gives off the feeling that something more sinister is lurking behind the walls than just the criminally insane.Gameplay (10/10):The world of Arkham Asylum is free exploration, but to stay interested and invested in the game, you can't really deviate from the story because the story is linear and without side missions to distract you.  Personally, I am not bothered by this because there is quite a bit of problem solving and each area you enter presents a new challenge that require different approaches, so you aren't doing the same thing over and over.The main story is fairly long probably about 15 to 20 hours depending on the difficulty.  On top of that, you have a couple of miscellaneous “missions” like doing all of the Riddler Challenges and examing the artifacts found in the Asylum.  While many find these boring, I personally enjoyed going back and doing these because they offered sereral easter eggs by referencing events and characters from the comics that I enjoyed.  If this isn't your kind of thing, it is easily skipped.This game is in third person, so it relies on a very effective free-flow combat system based on combos.  It mixes classic fighting with silent takedowns and special combo moves that create the classic Batman that can take anyone in a fight.  Included in the fighting system are the gadgets.  The gadgets create a whole new host of ways to creatively finish off opponets in both direct and indirect combat.  Many complain about the fact that the Batmobile and Batwing are not present in the game except for short stints, and are not even player operated.  While this is unfortunate, the nature of the game taking place inside a small, finite area really defeats the use of either one. Sound (8/10):In terms of music and sound effects, Arkham Ayslum employs them to great effect.  While the soundtrack isn’t really memorable, the small things like dripping water, metal clanking against metal, and other small things add to the immersion.  The environmental and combat sounds are actually quite good.  Unfortunately the dialogs are hit or miss, which sometimes hurts the characters.Replay value (9/10):While the plot is linear and there aren't any choices which would change the story in any way, the game provides countless hours of fun as probably the best batman simulator on the market.  If the story mode gets boring, there are always the numerous challenge missions that are not part of the story that are fun to play.Conclusion (9.2/10):Batman: Arkham Asylum is a very good game, with an unforgettable setting, an engaging plot, and a loose ends that set up future games.  Overall, it is definitely one of those games which you have to play at least once and I highly recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a piece of diamond among the action games. As a Dark Knight, you will be forced to fight your way througout the mass of enemies and DC supervilllians. Combat is really enjoyable and game itself is pretty much fluent - there is always something going on and you just dont stuck at one place...not even for a while. I recommend this game especially for Batman fans, since you will encounter many villians you are familiar with. In addition with a great dark and intense atmosphere of the Arkham Island, you really gonna believe that you are Dark Knight himself, totally consumed by the great story and characters. As a fresh addition to game, you are able to scout the island and explore all dark corners of it - finding more content like Riddler´s mazes and messages related to history of Arkham City and also background of mentioned Supervillians. In summary, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a natural choice for every fan of action games and keen admirers of a Dark Knight. What else to say? Maybe just...Riddle me this, riddle me that. Who s afraid of big black bat?Pluses + Great atmosphere and fluent story+ Enjoyable combat and option to improve your Dark Knight (gadgets, armor, battle technics)+ Decent graphics+ Nice music, soundtracks and audio in generalMinuses- You are practically locked up in one place all the time. Although the island itself is kinda interesting and offers a several places to go, the world could be a little bigger.- Bosses battles (fight strategy and flow of the battle) are kinda repeatable.Overall: 9/10

												After playing this on console quite a lot, and being a big Batman and DC fan, I decided to buy this for PC.It captures Batman as for what he really is; a badass hardened by traumatic experiences and many close death encounters.The story is executed to a very good standard, encorporating a lot of the classic Batman villians such as the Joker (of course), Harley Quinn, Killer Croc, Scarecrow etc. It is also a rather simple story to understand as it features a standard plot to take over Gotham brought up the Joker, but in a way that truly shows off his evil genius.The combat is rather fluid, if not unimpressive but it works. You have the basic combo chaining attacks with an element of counters.The lack of some iconic characters such as Two-Face, Mr. Freeze and The Penguin allows the game to immersify the player into the other characters a lot more; making it feel not so crowded.Graphics are superb, with near to no lag found within my first few hours of playing, even when loading into the main island.There is an element of search and explore aspect, as you look to find certain Riddler Trophies as part of a sidequest to accompany the main story. There's also a stealth aspect as you look to avoid armed minions who can deal fatal damage, thus you have to intelligently pick your moment to take them out from above.The voice acting and audio in general is rather brilliant, with many voice actors reprising their roles from some of the older cartoons.The tone of the story is rather adult, as it should be for a Batman game. Featuring traumatic situations and murder.All in all, this is a good game I'd seriously recommend whether you're a Batman fan or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2015
												This is still today one of the best games i have ever played. This game proved that a comic book based videogame can be great, instead of a lot of movie tied videogames that tend to suck. It has a mix of classic and modern gameplay, that blends together well. You start the game by bringing Joker again to Arkham Asylum, but soon he breaks free and takes control of the entire island. The story in this game is superbly written, and the villains fantastic, like Scarecrow with fear gas, Poison Ivy with plants, and of course Joker, the main villain star. The gameplay is breaked into 3 types: exploration, where you progress through the asylum, discover new places, enjoy the graphics, relax, and find collectibles and solves riddles, with plenty of easter eggs. But not everything can be collected right away, you'll need to obtain new gadgets and come back later. The combat is simple and fluid, using a button to attack and another to counter mainly, with a few more tricks. But the enemies aren't varied, with only 2 or 3 that will require another tactic, and a mini-boss that's very recicled. Lastly there's the stealth sections, where you must plan and take down Joker goons in a room without being detected. It sounds cool, but it's more random than i would like. It's still enjoyable though. In the end, this isn't exactly an open world game, but more of a linear, focused story that works very well here, although it's a bit short. But after finishing the story and collecting everything, there's still the challenge mode, where you will face some combat challenges where you need to keep a combo to earn a high score, or face some stealth sections where you must take down Joker goons with some extra requirements. This challenges are harder than the story mode, but still doable. This game is a must buy on sale, but the game have crashed 2 times and there's a bug where the game exits if your internet connection gets cut off. This last one is annoying, because you will lose progress, and get frustrated. While this game no longer has DRM other than Steam, it seems that some code is still unintendedly present. But despite that it's still a great game, and while the core mechanics are much improved in Batman Arkham City, this one has the best story and villains, because it's more focused.

content:
Posted: February 22
												This game started the entire Arkham series off with great style and flow! This game started a great time to be a Batman fan. The gameplay is amazing, the looks of the game back in the day were amazing and still hold up well now 7 years later! The story was also an amazing immersive world with loads of lore and backstory all over the place with collectibles challenges and more to try throughout Arkham Asylum. There was a lot of depth for the first outing as the caped crusader. He was brutal, calculated and smart giving a very large dynamic of things to do throughout the game. The biggest innovation was the combat system Rocksteady created, and they held up thsi combat system with small changes here and there to improve it and alter it slightly. The gameplay is changed up with the addition of gadgets that allow a whole different set of combo's for you to change up the gameplay with. The world is amazing, the detail is amazing and this game is amazing. Worth a buy!Tl;dr, amazing game, buy it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2012
												Arkham Asylum presents a fun experience based off the comic book series. As a whole, this game is comparable to The Dark Knight in terms of quality story, art, and cinematics. The storyline is a series of twists and turns as Batman has to stop Joker while facing off against other supervillains in order to reach Joker. The game is set on Arkham Island both inside the asylum and on the outside grounds. Batman has to fight, sneak, solve, and explore his way using various different actions in the game. As a result, there's a bunch of action and solving gameplay rolled into one. Graphically, the game looks realistic and dark while retaining the comic book quality of each character. Some characters look noticably huge while others have a slimmer trim. The music matches the serious tone well by applying the tenseness of the situation. Batman: Arkham Asylum provides a good blend of comic book storytelling with the multiple playstyles and enveloping graphics and music to the feel of the comics.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2013
												Batman Arkham Asylum is an action\adventure "super hero" game.So after many average and horrible batman games is Batman Arkham Asylumworth trying ? well I can answer your question right away.You start the game when batman caught the most famous villian the Jokerand sents him back to prison ( Arkham Asylum ) where he should be belong,even though the guards should be able to do the rest, batman sense that something isn't quite right and that he should keep his eye on Joker after all Joker gave up so easily almost without a fight. After what it seems that the Joker well be sent to his place, Joker escaped killing the guards in his way and somehow controlling all the asylum in a blink of an eye. Now it up to batman to stop Joker and find out what was Joker's planning all this time.Gameplay : the combat is great and fluid almost perfect, it combines stealth approach, puzzles and riddles and of course brute force. This is the first game that will make you feel that you are the batman that you are in cotrol of your gadgets, fighting style and detective's skills.I can rest assure you that Batman Arkham Asylum gameplay is one of the best there is to offer.Story : its been a long time since I was so interested in a game's storyline,the cutscenes\dialog\twists are just great. You will be suprised and thrilled by what will come next, also lets not forget about the characters which all of them are amazingly done. Graphics : What can I say ? beautiful,amazing,outstanding and perfectly fit to the batman's art style. One of the best I have seen in 2009 and even today its just plain impressive.AI + difficulty : this is where I think that Batman Arkham Asylum could be better,while the game has diffrent enemies and every boss fight is unique, still the gameis too damn easy even on the hard difficulty, only the challenges gives the feeling that I might actually lose.Music + Sound : I can't say too much cause the only thing that comes in my mind is the word "Perfection" Summary : Batman Arkham Asylum trully deserves the "Game of the year" title of 2009, one of the most suprising,impressive and outstanding games there is to offer and God help those who didn't play the game yet. The only thing that bothers me was the difficulty which was too easy for me, but overall I'll give this game a 9.5\10

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Now that Windows Live has been extracted from Batman: Arkham Asylum, there's no better time to get it.An amazing game. You don't have to be an avid Batman fan in order to enjoy this game. The game has a lot of lore you can discover about the specific characters in Gotham.The game has a great free flow combat system: easy to learn, yet difficult to master.You'll be constantly switching from beating up a bunch of criminals in the open to being stealthy and trying to take out armed criminals with your gadgets.There's a lot of collectibles in this game ranging from trophies to audio tapes of some of the most deranged criminals of Gotham.The visuals are stunning even if the game itself is half a decade old; there's a lot of great atmosphere, even making some parts "scary".The achievements aren't ridiculously hard either; you'll be playing this game for a while if you decide to go 100%, which I highly recommend to everyone.Overall, this game is a must get especially when it goes on sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Great game based on one of the greatest superheroes of all time--Batman. The combat is immersive; if you ever played Spiderman, the combat mimicks that of Spidey and counter measuring your enemies is very satisfying. Nothing beats dodging and throwing Mike Tyson punches and spin kicks to thugs. Majority of buildings and structures are mountable with your Batlaw to scout areas for enemies or to strategize how to pick them off one-by-one. The latter will apply to situations when there are enemies with machine guns as bullets take a good chunk of Batman's health. Yet this is where it gets fun; you as The Dark Knight can use the Batclaw to mount on a gargoyle and press Y button to hang an unsuspecting thug onto the gargoyle while he screams "Let me down!" Others nearby will hear their comrade and rush to him. What do you do? Grapple to the next gargoyle and repeat. You can also take them out silently by sneaking behind them or using certain gadgets. For enemies with only fists and melee weapons, you can just zerg in and counter when necessary. Graphics are amazing as are the movie-like cutscenes. The voice acting is superb. I recommend playing with Physics on. I played with the GTX 295 with Physics set to High and it was outstanding. The game is very fun. Only part what I viewed as tedious was Croc and his lair. Scarecrow was literally creepy and disturbing. Poison Ivy was, well, hot! The final battle to the game's conclusion was a great experience. Simple but challenging. I'm now playing Arkham City. Plan is to play the whole trilogy and Arkham Knight as soon as it releases.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Still one of the best super hero games of all time, heck I'd even call it one of the best action-adventure games of all time.I had originally completed this game on the Xbox 360, never really considered revisiting it after that. Bought it on steam as it was on sale for dirt cheap, and boy did I love playing through it again.My favourite game in the series still remains Arkham City (completed thrice on Console) but this comes a close second. Asylum is a slightly different game from it's two successors as the Map size it self is smaller and contained. But that leads to a fun Metrovania style of going back to different locations, progressively armed with superior gadgets and skills.Some of the best parts of the game are the Scarecrow missions where the games changes into a 2.5 D stealth platformer and provides a good change of pace from the action sequences. And the stealth sections are also slightly more challenging than future titles (By Arkham Knight Batman a little overpowered for these sections to feel genuinely difficult).Asylum's story is also top notch and the laser sharp focus of the story makes it feels more like a single issue hardcover versus the multi-issue comic series it's successors would feel like. Joker is a singular threat with a chemical super weapon. Everything else and all other villians tie into that.The only con would be the terrible boss fight that closes the game as it feels like a cop out from a genuinely awesome Batman vs Joker showdown (Arkham Knight sort of nails this with its 'Joker' sequence at the end).All in all it a revolutionary title that showed others how a licensed property should be treated. And it lead to two stellar sequels and an okayish, slightly cash-grabby Prequel.9/10P.S.: If you are playing this game with a recent Nvidia GPU you might run into a some problems with frame rates in the PHYSX heavy sections of the game. Originally the game recommeneded using a secondary NVIDIA GPU as a dedicated Physx card. If you are on a fairly modern GPU (like the GTX 480 onward) that is not necessary, just download the Rigid Bodies patch (rrb.dll) from Nvidia's website.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												Still one of the best super hero games of all time, heck I'd even call it one of the best action-adventure games of all time.I had originally completed this game on the Xbox 360, never really considered revisiting it after that. Bought it on steam as it was on sale for dirt cheap, and boy did I love playing through it again.My favourite game in the series still remains Arkham City (completed thrice on Console) but this comes a close second. Asylum is a slightly different game from it's two successors as the Map size it self is smaller and contained. But that leads to a fun Metrovania style of going back to different locations, progressively armed with superior gadgets and skills.Some of the best parts of the game are the Scarecrow missions where the games changes into a 2.5 D stealth platformer and provides a good change of pace from the action sequences. And the stealth sections are also slightly more challenging than future titles (By Arkham Knight Batman a little overpowered for these sections to feel genuinely difficult).Asylum's story is also top notch and the laser sharp focus of the story makes it feels more like a single issue hardcover versus the multi-issue comic series it's successors would feel like. Joker is a singular threat with a chemical super weapon. Everything else and all other villians tie into that.The only con would be the terrible boss fight that closes the game as it feels like a cop out from a genuinely awesome Batman vs Joker showdown (Arkham Knight sort of nails this with its 'Joker' sequence at the end).All in all it a revolutionary title that showed others how a licensed property should be treated. And it lead to two stellar sequels and an okayish, slightly cash-grabby Prequel.9/10P.S.: If you are playing this game with a recent Nvidia GPU you might run into a some problems with frame rates in the PHYSX heavy sections of the game. Originally the game recommeneded using a secondary NVIDIA GPU as a dedicated Physx card. If you are on a fairly modern GPU (like the GTX 480 onward) that is not necessary, just download the Rigid Bodies patch (rrb.dll) from Nvidia's website.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This is where it all began - one of the best action games I've come to play, and still perhaps my most favored of the Batman trilogy. It's not as big or as long as the Arkham City or the Origins, but it feels complete, which its successors failed to accomplish - at least in my opinion.The game is very loyal to the comic books and anyone familiar with Frank Miller's Batman stories - Batman: Year One and Dark Knight Returns - should find themselves right at home with this game. The voice actors have done a superb job with their roles and I can't praise Mark Hamill enough for his role as the Joker; the man is simply amazing - hard to believe the same voice belongs to Luke Skywalker. Graphically the game has aged well, and I still find myself impressed with what they've done with the environments and the characters themselves, and let us not forget the music - it has a very Tim Burton's Batman type of sound and enhances the experience even further.So yes, I'd say this is a must buy to anyone who considers themselves a Batman fan.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2014
												Gameplay: This game has a mix of platforming, fighting and puzzle-solving. The platforming is basic, but made interesting with the addition of gadgets; which you can use to pull down walls, get to un-reachable places and more. The fighting system is very deep, and trying to get high combos is always fun. The puzzles are consistently unique, though normally relatively easy.Story: Arkham Asylum is written like a comic-book, with many classic characters scattered throughout the narrative. There are a few surprising plot twists and occassionally emotional parts.Graphics: The entire island is very well detailed, filled with easter eggs and secrets. Each area has a great atmosphere and looks very unique. Sound: The music is on par with the Batman movies (by Nolan) and voice acting is very good.Re-playability: There are heaps of collectables and lots of extra challenges to attempt.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I have already beat and played the meatloaf out of Arkham City, and Origins.  That being said, Batman: Arkham Asylum is kinda far off.Let's not get anything wrong here.  Playing as Batman is simply amazing.  You really get that feel of Batman as you glide from gargoyle to gargoyle, and dangle people from a rope that's attached to the gargoyle.  However, Arkham Asylum's controls and game mechanics are far off than City's.  Gliding is practically non-existant, and when there is enough space to glide, you can't grapple onto anything mid-flight.  This is rather frustrating, because you often can't get the drop on a baddie unless you flop on the floor first, then grapple.  The fighting is almost identicle.  You can land hits from 20 feet away, and just punch those baddies until they drop.  The biggest con I found however, was the story.  I had a hard time following the story, and there hardly was one.  The ending felt empty and un-rewarding, unlike City's ending which made you feel like crying into your pillow.This is a nice addition to the other two, and it's where the series started.  I highly recammend this title, except not for the $30 price range.  Wait until it's on sale, around $10.  You will get all the thrills of being The Batman, however not as much as you would playing the other two additions to the series.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												When it comes to video games about superheroes Batman: Arkham Asylum ranks very highly on the list providing a unique experience unlike any that came before it, quite possibly making it the best Batman game ever created.In Arkham Asylum you play as the Batman who is bringing the Joker back to the asylum from his last escape, however things do not feel right and as sure as bat senses tingle the Joker escapes but this time to take control of the asylum with the help of Harley Quinn and various other supervillains in a widespread plan to cause chaos, and now that the inmates run the asylum it is up to Batman to stop them.Plotwise this game works very well, the story has dark tones to it that you come to expect from Batman these days and introduces a bevy of supervillains that Batman must take down all while exploring the more psychological side of heroes and villains and by the end of it the story will leave you satisfied despite the twist and turns that had happened along the way.The gameplay in Arkham Asylum is masterfully done, using many elements from an amazing combat system that lets you pull off flashy moves and counters with single button presses, a stealth system that is done much better then most stealth games seem to do, allowing you to feel as if you are the Batman, hunting these criminals from the shadows ready to pounce, and also has an odd Metroidvania aspect to it where Batman will get upgraded gear along the way that lets him into more places as you explore the island, and the Riddler has hidden things in the environment for you to find such as trophies and solving riddles by finding things hidden in the background.With how well designed this game is there are a few things I could nitpick, such as how sometimes the platforming controls get a bit wonky having you fall off if you are not careful, or how the game can at times feel a bit too easy even on the hardest difficulty, but all of my nitpicks are vastly overshadowed, the game is a tight fifteen hours or so to beat with more time needed if you want to do everything such as find all the riddles and complete the combat and predator challenges that will truly put your skills in the systems this game has to the test.Overall Arkham Asylum is an amazing game, the graphics are top notch and the PC version shows them off even better, with a music score very reminiscent of the Christopher Nolan films, if you have any interest at all in Batman, superheros, or character stealth-action games, this game is ranked highly by me and I recommend it to just about anyone.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												If you add up the time spent in all my games across all my platforms, you will find that I have sunk the most time into this game. Regular, game of the year, special 3D, They all serve for excellent excuses to replay this game. If you're wanting to get into Batman then this is actually a great jumping off point as the lore and characters are so incredibly accurate to the canon of the Dark Knight. I will admit that the physical gameplay is rougher than in the later games so if you go from Arkham City to this then you will feel like you're moving through syrup at times. But this is the game that started the others off and cemented the Arkham games in the public spotlight, and you can tell why while playing, even the collectibles feel fun and interesting to the very end. Stealth, combat, and story all come together to make an unforgettable game that truly makes you feel like the Batman.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Thouroughly enjoyed this game, I had previous experience with this game a few years ago but only now had the motivation to complete the story. The combat is fluent but can be repititive but still manages to stay satisfying, especially when using the batclaw for finishers and extended combos. Graphics are great for the time it was released and showed very little graphical errors (though some pixelation during the final cutscene). The riddler adds a lot of exploration and keeps your eyes open for anything and everything, not to mention spending a hell of a lot of time circling your camera around rooms in detective mode to find riddler trophies. The main plot had little depth but the riddler and the colectibles you gather than tell individual character stories are very promising for anyone who enjoys a thourough story. I'm yet to try any of the other modes but I can definitely recommend the game for its generally satisfying gameplay and interesting start to the Arkham game series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2011
												Batman: Arkham Asylum was the best action game of 2009.  I originally played this game on Xbox 360, but revisited the PC version and enjoyed it again even more with crisper graphics.  While the game does have some beat 'em up elements to it, it won't tire you out on them.  Though, if you do enjoy them, like I did, the game offers a challenge mode that lets you enjoy the wonderful contextual combo system.  Much of the appeal is the puzzle-like approach to clearing a room, or getting to your next objective by sticking to the shadows and using the fear tactics that Batman is known for.  The story is compelling, and the gameplay offers just enough variety to keep it from feeling bland.  There is a pleasant mixture of brawling, stealth action, story sequences, and detective work to keep your attention.If you haven't yet played Batman: Arkham Asylum, I would highly recommend the PC version using either mouse/keyboard or a 360 game controller, especially before the sequel arrives!

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM ASYLUMAs I have mentioned in my review of Portal 2, I am behind the times when it comes to the latest games, and one of the many games on my ‘to-play’ list was Batman: Arkham Asylum. Finding it cheap in a store was great, as it meant that I could finally give it a go. But would I find it any good?In Batman: Arkham Asylum, Batman has caught the Joker (again), but, suspicious at the ease at which the Clown Prince of Crime allowed himself to be captured, Batman decides to escort the Joker to his cell. Unfortunately, the Joker was counting on this. Not only was he planning on being caught and returned to Arkham Asylum, but he planned on Batman being there as well. Batman must fight his way through the asylum, confronting some of his most persistent adversaries, from Bane to Poison Ivy. But what is the Joker after? What is Titan? And can Batman stop the Joker’s plans?While I’m not that big a fan of the Batman comics in particular, I have read many of the graphic novels, including one that seems to be an inspiration for this game: Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth. That was an intelligent but harrowing mind-screw of a book that clearly inspired more than a few elements. The story, while not at complex epic levels, is good for what it is: a comic book story transferred to a computer game. I’m surprised that, given how Paul Dini (of the serious but still kid-oriented animated series) wrote it, how adult the game seems. Which goes to show my ignorance. Graphics-wise, the game is beautiful. I am sure that there are more games out there that look better (including Arkham Asylum’s direct sequel, Arkham City, which I am currently playing), but I am not a person who wants their game’s graphics to be ultra-realistic, as long as the graphical style is enjoyable, and that it is. The character design, for the most part, is actually quite excellent, though I am a little bemused at the rather fetishized appearances of Harley Quinn and Poison Ivy, even compared to their comic book versions.Sound-wise, it is quite immersive and atmospheric. The voice acting is enjoyable, with particular, if predictable, praise going to Mark Hamill as the Joker. I know him more as Luke Skywalker, so to hear him play the Joker is a revelation. The sound effects all work, and the music helps give an edge of dread, without it missing the Elfman/Zimmer edge of the Batman atmosphere.Gameplay wise, the game is somewhat mixed, although this is partly because this game was developed first and foremost as a console game rather than a PC game. I played on easy simply because of an apprehension I had about the control scheme, and I still found the game challenging, partly because I used a keyboard and mouse as opposed to a controller. That being said, the combat is enjoyable, if a little repetitive, and the Predator Sequences (sequences where one must attack stealthily) are challenging, but in a mostly good way. The gadgets all lend not only to the gameplay, but to the feeling that one is actually Batman. There’s even a few sequences where the World’s Greatest Detective (as Batman is hyped as) actually does some detecting. The sidequests of the Riddler Challenges are actually quite enjoyable and taxing, and nothing beats that little thrill of satisfaction when you beat one of them, and while Riddler accuses you of looking them up on the internet, you actually just found almost all the solutions on your own. My only real complaint, other than the control scheme, is that, even with the Riddler Challenges, the game was over rather swiftly.Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is an enjoyable game that is really how Batman should be played. Flawed, but still enjoyable and highly recommended.RATING: ****

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												With Batman being back in the film news I finally got the inspiration to start going through the Batman games. First on the list is Arkham Asylum, which is now over 5 years old. The good news is, the game didn't feel old at all. Looks and runs great!The game takes place in the island of Arkham Asylum where Joker and his mischievous friends escape and it's up to you to put an end to his plans. Featuring the original "arkham style combat" that is now a coined phrase for games like Shadow of Mordor, it plays well and is challenging enough to keep it interesting while providing some fun tools to experiment with.I do have a few complaints towards the options system. You can only edit your keys before starting the game and there is no option to edit mouse sensitivity. You have to go tweak some config files to change the sensitivity values around which is rather slow to finetune.Batman Arkham Asylum is a good game that functions well as an introduction to the series. It provides a fun and dark playground to mess around in. There's a good chunk of the core gameplay but also a bunch of collectibles and optional content that can keep you going longer if you so desire. Definitely checking out Arkham City next!Beat the game in 12 hours.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
Batman: Arkham Asylum really stands out as one of the best superhero video games out there (another one being its sequel, Arkham City, but more about that in another review). The gameplay is rock-solid in a Metroidvania-esque fashion, the voice-over work is fantastic with many classic voices returning (like Mark Hamill as the Joker and Kevin Conroy as the Dark Knight himself), and the story is well-written and satisfying for the most part.The whole game takes place on Arkham Island, where the Joker has gained control over the titular insane asylum. The location is really atmospheric and is a very believable setting for a Batman story, in a little contrast to the setting in Arkham City which had a little more creative freedom applied to it (again, more on that in the future).The main story is a bit on the short side, but combined with the Riddler challenges and the combat/predator challenges, it will keep you busy for a good 20-25 hours for 100% completion. Not too shabby.It isn't possible to review Arkham Asylum and not mention the simple, yet satisfying freeflow -combat system. It takes little skill to beat up the bad guys, but racking up massive combos takes some work and is very enjoyable. What's even more pleasing than beating them up directly is the stealth, or "predator" sections, where you use your environment to your advantage and take out your enemies without being seen.You might enjoy this game even if you don't like Batman. Under the Batman -shell is a rock-solid game that is without question worth picking up. Who knows? Maybe you'll start to like the series after playing this?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2014
												A good plot, interesting villains and of course the ability to beat the living daylights out of various thugs while proclaiming "I'M BATMAN!" What more could you want? A gun that shoots shuriken and lightning? Don't be absurd, you know Batman's rules...If this is your first foray into the Batman Universe beyond the Christopher Nolan films, you might find this Batman and his villains to be less "gritty" and "realistic". However, if you even consider this to be a flaw, you'll soon forget about your gripes as the writing and voice-acting draws you in and makes you forget that there ever could be a different Batman.The main storyline is top notch and the various collectible items side quests keep you playing well beyond beating up a Titan-enhanced Joker with explosive fists .Overall a well-crafted, immersive game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												Arkham Asylum, A serious house on Serious Earth. This game understands batman, as it tries to undo every other batman game that has come before. Arkham Asylum in this game is not just a setting for which the story takes place in a lot of ways it is the story. This entire game plays out like a crucible of sorts for the dark knight. You are thrown into a situation where the inmates have taken control of the asylum, and you are forced to explore the Asylum in its entirety in order to deduct the real reason your in this situation. You will quickly discover things are not as they appear. Gameplay is relatively simple a rhythm-based combat system, and the plot is pretty straight forward. Along the way you'll have levels and experiences that challenge and aim to psychologically ruin the dark knight, but its all made very enjoyable, and there are an exceptional amount of characters and cameos. Based on the time this game was released I'd say its worthy of a perfect 10 point score

												Let's begin with the battle system. Obviously, it's more refined in the sequels but for the start of a series the mechanics are pretty solid. I was surprised at how much contend the game actually has: there's a lot there for completionists too, with the Riddler's... riddles and other collectibles. The graphics mostly hold up today, though if you're used to ultra-modern graphics you might notice a difference.As you might expect, it's pretty dark stuff, especially the Scarecrow sections (moreso if you have a fear of needles like me) but I don't think it's particularly off-putting. Anyone above the age rating should have no problem with it.When it comes down to it, you'll want to play this for the story, if nothing else - it introduces Titan which I believe is a major plot point in Arkham City as well, so it's best to start at... well, the start.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												After playing this on console quite a lot, and being a big Batman and DC fan, I decided to buy this for PC.It captures Batman as for what he really is; a badass hardened by traumatic experiences and many close death encounters.The story is executed to a very good standard, encorporating a lot of the classic Batman villians such as the Joker (of course), Harley Quinn, Killer Croc, Scarecrow etc. It is also a rather simple story to understand as it features a standard plot to take over Gotham brought up the Joker, but in a way that truly shows off his evil genius.The combat is rather fluid, if not unimpressive but it works. You have the basic combo chaining attacks with an element of counters.The lack of some iconic characters such as Two-Face, Mr. Freeze and The Penguin allows the game to immersify the player into the other characters a lot more; making it feel not so crowded.Graphics are superb, with near to no lag found within my first few hours of playing, even when loading into the main island.There is an element of search and explore aspect, as you look to find certain Riddler Trophies as part of a sidequest to accompany the main story. There's also a stealth aspect as you look to avoid armed minions who can deal fatal damage, thus you have to intelligently pick your moment to take them out from above.The voice acting and audio in general is rather brilliant, with many voice actors reprising their roles from some of the older cartoons.The tone of the story is rather adult, as it should be for a Batman game. Featuring traumatic situations and murder.All in all, this is a good game I'd seriously recommend whether you're a Batman fan or not.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I have already beat and played the meatloaf out of Arkham City, and Origins.  That being said, Batman: Arkham Asylum is kinda far off.Let's not get anything wrong here.  Playing as Batman is simply amazing.  You really get that feel of Batman as you glide from gargoyle to gargoyle, and dangle people from a rope that's attached to the gargoyle.  However, Arkham Asylum's controls and game mechanics are far off than City's.  Gliding is practically non-existant, and when there is enough space to glide, you can't grapple onto anything mid-flight.  This is rather frustrating, because you often can't get the drop on a baddie unless you flop on the floor first, then grapple.  The fighting is almost identicle.  You can land hits from 20 feet away, and just punch those baddies until they drop.  The biggest con I found however, was the story.  I had a hard time following the story, and there hardly was one.  The ending felt empty and un-rewarding, unlike City's ending which made you feel like crying into your pillow.This is a nice addition to the other two, and it's where the series started.  I highly recammend this title, except not for the $30 price range.  Wait until it's on sale, around $10.  You will get all the thrills of being The Batman, however not as much as you would playing the other two additions to the series.

												Batman Arkham Asylum is an amazing, third person, action game. The gameplay is very fluent and fun once you get the hang of it, and I have absolutely no complaints about that. The gameplay is probably my favorite part about this game, the story on the other hand was interesting as well. The story seems to reflect the way the old Batman comics used to be, and definitely feels like a Batman story, which is good. Overall, the game is definitely worth the money and is loaded with hours of beating up criminals and grappling around the place. It did not feel very repetitive at all, in fact, it did a lot of things right to make sure you enjoy the game such as little hidden unlockables, different enemy types and environments, and fun bosses. Pick this game up right now if you can, or wait until a sale because it goes on sale pretty often.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2012
												What is there to say about the famous Batman that has not already been said? Batman is my favorite hero, hands down. Maybe that makes me slightly biased in this review, but Batman: Arkham Asylum is exactly how a Batman game should be for long-time or even newly-born fans. I am not inclined to lie about him being a "super" hero, because he ultimately does not have super powers. His gadgets make him a super being, BUT he does not have super-human abilities, unlike his nemesises or other "super" heroes in likeness of Superman and whatnot. He drives a Batmobile; I mean, who does not love this guy? The two main parts about this game that stood out to me the most are not only the constant action throughout the entirety of the game (fighting mechanics, flying mechanics, and the like), but the Scarecrow and the Joker are what make this game what it is. Without spoiling the game for anyone who has not indulged in this experience yet, Scarecrow plays an epic part in this game; it is one of my favorite parts in gaming history. The Joker is hilarious; he kept me laughing consistently, which is a plus in any game. This game is stunning, graphics wise; the gameplay is absolutely one hundred pecent fun, one hundred percent of the time; the story-line is full of character, as there are an extensive amount of villians in it; basically, this game is perfection at its finest hour. Everything about it is exhilerating. Sometimes, more so than not, games are disappointing when they are hyped up, but this one is as pleasing as pie, unless you are into cake. It is not by any means a short game either, so if you enjoy a decent amount of gameplay, this is your match. You will not be disappointed, trust me! I have played over 1,000 + games, and this is one of my favorites.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game has been released for a long time and only at this time of my life I had the chance to play this game. And all I can say is "Let's get this party started!"Ding d-ding, dong! First of all, I really love the environment and the character models, specifically on their details. Voice acting is also great, especially Mark Hamill[www.imdb.com]. Profoundly speaking, the perfect voice actor for Joker – "He’s crazy, you know" – but the secondary characters and enemy henchmen have poor variety in voice-overs. Speaking of henchmen, with the freeflow combat system you can really ”Eat punks like these for breakfast.” You can seamlessly chain together unlimited combos not just with your barehands but with your “bat prefixed" gadgets as well. And speaking of gadgets, it’s pretty sweet if you will be able to utilize all of these in the game especially on solving the puzzles and of course with the help of the Detective Mode – I mean why wouldn’t Batman have a detective mode? He’s the WORLD’S GREATEST DETECTIVE! Plus to that, the hidden challenges and unlocking the secrets of Arkham Asylum really spice it up for Batman for being a detective. Another thing I also love is the silent takedowns – that pretty sums up Batman being the "Dark Knight" – and the convenience of hiding from the henchmen. They’ll just be surprised that you came out of nowhere and say, "That guy freaks me out.” Well, I finished the game on normal. I’ll have another go on hard and see if it will be more difficult for me to hide from the henchmen. And the last thing is about the boss fights. It’s pretty good they have some different variations. But somehow, for me, they kinda seem littler easier than the fights with the mobs LOL. Especially the final battle!All in all it’s a 9/10! See you in Arkham City, Bats!
