content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
 Click Here for the Full Review! [monthsbehindreviews.blogspot.com]Synopsis: A great game that combines, at about a 2-1 ratio, melee heavy combat with stealth focused areas. Comparing this game to Zelda seems rather apt, as you'll find that you can only explore a portion of a current zone (i.e. dungeon) until you uncover the one key item you need to get to the boss, which will allow you to unlock a bit more of the somewhat open world. Combat is fun, as you deal with multiple enemy types when engaged in melee, requiring you to attack stun baton enemies from behind, knife wielding enemies to be stunned with your cape first, and generally paying attention to which of the dozen enemies you're fighting will be attacking you first. Plenty of collectibles out there is you feel like solving some of the Riddler's puzzles, and while the game is focused on the Joker vs. Batman rivalry, the game does a great job of bringing in a variety of major Batman villains.Expect about 16 hours to get a 100% completion on the story side. I've rated it an 9/10, and recommend picking it up at $10 or less, though you can probably find it at $5 during a major sale.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												Every now and then there are games that achieve every single ambition their designers had. Arkham Asylum is among them. It both redefined the action adventure and is among the best representations of Batman, comics and movies included. Batman is possibly the only superhero I still find interesting in any way. This is because he fits the tormented hero archetype without simply repeating it. He also has no superpowers which make other superheroes so limited. Instead he uses his brain and never kills anyone. There are two extremes to the character: the Brooding Batman wallowing in human misery and the smart-as-a-whip Gadget Batman. Here he is somewhere in the middle and this works well.The other thing that makes Batman so interesting are certain villains. The conflict between Batman and The Joker is always interesting and has inspired many creative minds. Mark Hamill delivers one of the best VA performances yet, equal to Jack Nicholson or Heath Ledger. There are far too many villains in the Batman universe and the game veers dangerously close of being a Con Air stuffed with supercriminals. This more-is-more tendency also extends to the silly collectibles, but thankfully there are clever puzzles involved so they are tolerable. Scarecrow is used to the fullest of his potential as well. Robin is one of the most unnecessary characters in comics history (and there are many contenders) and I thank the makers that they left him out completely.The close combat system was an instant classic in game design and no subsequent effort can escape it's influence. Clearing rooms of gun-wielding thugs has many alternate routes and the entire "moving puzzle" idea is always fresh. The Gothic asylum setting is also interesting to explore, and the various Bat-gadgets are fun and natural to use. Graphical presentation is incredibly detailed and life-like, and every single sound I heard was just-so as well. There is simply no reason to skip this 15-hour adventure.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
REVIEW: BATMAN: ARKHAM ASYLUMAs I have mentioned in my review of Portal 2, I am behind the times when it comes to the latest games, and one of the many games on my ‘to-play’ list was Batman: Arkham Asylum. Finding it cheap in a store was great, as it meant that I could finally give it a go. But would I find it any good?In Batman: Arkham Asylum, Batman has caught the Joker (again), but, suspicious at the ease at which the Clown Prince of Crime allowed himself to be captured, Batman decides to escort the Joker to his cell. Unfortunately, the Joker was counting on this. Not only was he planning on being caught and returned to Arkham Asylum, but he planned on Batman being there as well. Batman must fight his way through the asylum, confronting some of his most persistent adversaries, from Bane to Poison Ivy. But what is the Joker after? What is Titan? And can Batman stop the Joker’s plans?While I’m not that big a fan of the Batman comics in particular, I have read many of the graphic novels, including one that seems to be an inspiration for this game: Arkham Asylum: A Serious House on Serious Earth. That was an intelligent but harrowing mind-screw of a book that clearly inspired more than a few elements. The story, while not at complex epic levels, is good for what it is: a comic book story transferred to a computer game. I’m surprised that, given how Paul Dini (of the serious but still kid-oriented animated series) wrote it, how adult the game seems. Which goes to show my ignorance. Graphics-wise, the game is beautiful. I am sure that there are more games out there that look better (including Arkham Asylum’s direct sequel, Arkham City, which I am currently playing), but I am not a person who wants their game’s graphics to be ultra-realistic, as long as the graphical style is enjoyable, and that it is. The character design, for the most part, is actually quite excellent, though I am a little bemused at the rather fetishized appearances of Harley Quinn and Poison Ivy, even compared to their comic book versions.Sound-wise, it is quite immersive and atmospheric. The voice acting is enjoyable, with particular, if predictable, praise going to Mark Hamill as the Joker. I know him more as Luke Skywalker, so to hear him play the Joker is a revelation. The sound effects all work, and the music helps give an edge of dread, without it missing the Elfman/Zimmer edge of the Batman atmosphere.Gameplay wise, the game is somewhat mixed, although this is partly because this game was developed first and foremost as a console game rather than a PC game. I played on easy simply because of an apprehension I had about the control scheme, and I still found the game challenging, partly because I used a keyboard and mouse as opposed to a controller. That being said, the combat is enjoyable, if a little repetitive, and the Predator Sequences (sequences where one must attack stealthily) are challenging, but in a mostly good way. The gadgets all lend not only to the gameplay, but to the feeling that one is actually Batman. There’s even a few sequences where the World’s Greatest Detective (as Batman is hyped as) actually does some detecting. The sidequests of the Riddler Challenges are actually quite enjoyable and taxing, and nothing beats that little thrill of satisfaction when you beat one of them, and while Riddler accuses you of looking them up on the internet, you actually just found almost all the solutions on your own. My only real complaint, other than the control scheme, is that, even with the Riddler Challenges, the game was over rather swiftly.Overall, Batman: Arkham Asylum is an enjoyable game that is really how Batman should be played. Flawed, but still enjoyable and highly recommended.RATING: ****

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												Reasons why I loved this game:    1. Story and Character development: In this game you meet the basic characters that are mainly focused on in the comics (Joker, Harley Quinn, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy, Scarecrow, ect.), but you feel like you know them after you played the game or a few scenes with them. Not only that, but you can listen to tapes that are found all around the game, containing background information of the character. Whether its Killer Croc's moody attitude and the passion he has to kill Batman (and every other person who helps run the prison), or Harley Quinn's bipolar disorder and her over affectionate personality toward Joker. All and more can be found in the game. It does an excellent job of doing this, slowly revealing every character's strong suits, or weaknesses (Joker's desperation and depression).    2. Easter Eggs: There are so many Easter eggs in this game I can't even count it...   From characters to plans for the next game (Arkham City), anything you can think of is in the game. Changes in simple things (like a mannequin) can be leads for where the game is going. Even three different alternate endings to the game if you watch the credits. There are so many more but I don't feel like listing them all...    3. Gameplay: Simple controls tie in really nicely to the game.   Combat is simple, and you don't have to really know all of the quick fire actions to get the job done. Playing with a controller (Xbox One) is highly recommended though, remembering everything on a keyboard is considered impressive to me.    4. Vent Simulator: 2009.   There are so many vents in the game you have to climb into, it should be considered a crime, but it's not a negative. You don't have to climb into all of them all of the time. Sometimes vents are used for strategizing your next move or plan. Although annoying, they're useful.    5. Great for people who follow the comics. This game has been praised several times for being accurate to the comics. I personally never read a Batman comic, just followed the old TV shows and movies, but after playing this game I want to read one, badly.6. Graphics on the highest setting it can go for, plus constant 60 fps for a game that was released in 2009, makes the game looks like that it just was released yesterday. FYI: If you can run it on the highest settings, you don't need the remastered version of it (Batman: Return to Arkham).  Thanks for reading my review, it was a fun game, and I still play it time to time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												This game is AWESOME!PROS:-Combat system and Stealth system is easy to understand, but takes awhile to truly master-Stealth Missions make you think and can get very challenging. This is easily the best part of the game.-Combat and Stealth is equally spread accross the game.-Character and level design is perfect. Every character sticks to the original character design while still being new and refreshing.-Voice acting and music is a huge aspect of this game. Every voice is exactly how imagine each character to sound like. Every line and song sets the tone for the level (especially during Scarecrow levels).-Game does not restrict you enough to feel open, but still gives you enough direction to make it feel linear.-Collecting all the trophies, solving all the riddles, and looking for every other collectible is definitely a tedious but rewarding task. Each riddle is cleverly crafted and does take quite a bit of thought.-Boss fights are very interesting, clever, and difficult. Bane, Harley Quinn, and The Joker are your typical beat-em up style bosses. Scarecrow implements a stealthy platformer level at the start of his boss fight. Poison Ivy is like a Legend of Zelda style boss. The Croc is the most creative fight, you need to navigate a maze while avoiding him.-There are a lot of bonus challenge maps.CONS:-Literally nothing to do in the aftergame. No post story or anything.-Scenes when Batman is talking to characters are like Fallout talking scenes and it looks very derpy.-The world, although it feels open, still feels a bit small.

												This game really makes you feel like you're the Batman. The combat is simple, but fluid and satisfying. Getting high combos while utilising Batman's gadgets feels so rewarding.There are some stealth areas in the game. content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is simply a must-buy.It provides the perfect beginning to some of the most impressive Batman games we've come to see in recent years. From the innovative free-flow combat system to the gadget assisted stealth of the Silent Knight challenges. You'll see some nostalgic clashes with some of Gotham's most feared. Arkham Asylum places Batman into a gritty, intense and industrial-esque environment as he relentlessly pursues The Joker, whose murderous trail of havoc has laid waste to some of Arkham's finest. Batman is trapped, not just physically in the Arkham complex, but also by a sense of duty to stop this madman in his tracks. From hunting Riddler's tough-to-find Trophies, to exploring the Island, you'll be battling your way through hordes of inmates whilst using an array of gadgets and brutal martial arts.Be ready to be immersed in a well crafted storyline as you step into the Dark Knight's titanium boots. I'm excited for you because you're gonna' love every second you play...as well as every bone you shatter!

												I'm not even a big fan of Batman (the only thing I was fan of is was the first 2 movies of the Dark Knight Trilogy and the animated series) but still the game got me hooked from the first moments. Still awesome game, I'm sure every batman fan would love it. Also I didn't bother with the Riddler trophies, nothing really good to collect.After playing Arkham City this falls short (because AC is practically perfect haha) but still this deserve 8/10 for me even by comparison because it was revolutionary and made me want to know more about the lore but even the first time I played it I felt like it needed more gadgets and more enemy variation (which the sequel provided).

content:
Posted: October 16, 2015
												After a while now, I've been thinking of Batman: Arkham Knight's motto "Be the Batman". Truth be told, Batman: Arkham Asylum already lets you be The Batman.I could say something like: "Basically, you're Batman and you're stuck in Arkham Asylum, now run by the Joker" and it wouldn't be wrong, but it's just more than that. There's this feeling of claustrophia, locked up with the most psychotic criminal ever faced by Batman, sometimes just going wherever He wants you to go, solving riddles for Edward Nigma, because well, He is obsessed; Killer Croc trying to eat you; Bane wants to break you; Scarecrow bringing your worst fears, and not just Batman's, also yours.Then you have Batman's gadgets and of course what is probably the best combat system that I have ever seen and played, just allowing you to feel like Batman... wait I stand corrected, just allowing you to BE The Batman.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												Batman Arkham Asylum is a thirdperson action-adventure game devloped on the Unreal Engine by Rocksteady in association with Eidos and Warner Bros Entertainment. It follows masked superhero "Batman" AKA Bruce Wayne as he attempts to track down his nemesis "Joker," after a break out attempt in Arkham Asylum.Arkham Asylum succeeds in what many other video games have tried to do but ultimately fail at: It manages to tell a comic book story, with comic book characters, and a comic book level of grandeur, and yet still manages to stand apart as not only a fantastic gameplay experience, but also as a terrific narrative experience, even if you've never heard of these characters.I have to admit even, that it's almost intimidating to write about the game, as it accomplishes what it needs to so well that it almost exists on another level of video-game perfection, and writing about what makes it a masterpeice is difficult if not impossibl to me because of how many things there are to report.So instead I'll list off all the problems I have with this game, the most predominant of which is that Batman's "Detective Vision" is far too overpowered and there's absolutely no reason to play the game without it. I think that the game couldn't have been harmed if the keyboard and graphical settings could be accessed from an in-game menu as opposed to a seperate program, I feel like the encounter with "Killer Croc" was underwhelming and overly tedious, and I feel like the opening gives you too small of an arsenal for what the player would expect to have when stepping into the shoes of a superhero.I feel like, although atmospheric, the setting can get a little drab at times. The final boss feels like a disservice, and all of the other bosses feel overly generic and easy to beat. The combat may be solid but at times it can feel clunky when a move doesn't work right, and an Auto-Run would have been appreciated considering how slow Batman moves. The disposal of "Harley Quinn" is kind of uninteresting considering the build-up. The attack from Poison Ivy doesn't have anything to do with the plot and sort of haults progression. The structure of the story gets a little repetitive and predictable after a while, and the stealthing, while fun, can get somewhat uninteresting after a while.The logic involving riddles and their answers can range from incredibly obvious to irrelevent to the scenery. The riddler trophies can become uninteresting to find when the majority of them are obtained in only a few key ways. The detective mode can hurt your eyes after a while, and the normal visuals tend to repeat their style from area to area. The maps inside buildings are always much bigger than the building are outside, and overall this the greatest superhero game I've ever played.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												For a long time i have been putting off playing the Batman: Arkham games, idk why but I just have, so recently I decided that I wanted to finally sit down and play through them all, so obviously I saw it fit to play through the games as they were released. Batman: Arkham Asylum, is a great game, though fairly linear. (it is techincally "open world" but basically keeps you on the path of the story line, exploration is basically just to find riddler secrets) that being said the story is very interesting and will keep you hooked for your whole playthough, although it will not take very long at all to finish, just shy of 11 hours and thats including taking time to stealhfully take out the enemies one by one, and going off ocassionally to back track to a riddler secret that at the time I first noticed it I didn't have the right gadget to get it. So the game is short but is for sure worth playing through! With the game being almost 7 years old the graphics are very beautiful and the characters look detailed and wonderful. Note that this game does have an fps cap at 62 fps (I know strange, why not just 60?), so don't be expecting to get 200 and so on here, but that doesn't matter. the game plays smooth the whole way through and no problems with crashing or any of the sort! So happy I got around to playing this game and know I understand all the hype surrounding this series!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Played through on Hard first try, got about 80% of all of the collectables and secrets (there are hundreds). Very well made game, and rife with awesome Batman info/lore.The ONLY complaint I have with this game is the combat system. The combat isn't very complicated because there are many parts where you need to neutralize enemies in stealth, as any good Batman should. The problem here is that, because the combat is stretched so thin between straight up fighting and stealth, it does neither perfectly. STEALTH - Stealth is a very wishy-washy thing in this game, and because everything in a room is illuminated the same, you don't know if you are in hiding or if a gargoyle you've perched on is not actually putting you in the shadows. You can't fight enemies with guns straight up, so you are frequently forced into the stealth role.HAND-TO-HAND - Much of the straight up combat in this game is luck-based. Not all of it, but enough to be minorly frustrating in Hard mode. There is a 'counter' button while you're fighting that can counter an enemy's basic attack, but the prompt to counter shows up only 50% of the time, and even at that rate, it is very unlikely that you hitting the correct button will actually counter the enemy's attack because you're already in full swing of your own attack.And here inlies the main problem with this game - the 'difficulty'. Because of these certain flaws in the combat, the way the developers ramped up the difficulty was by not making certain enemies harder, but just simply putting more enemes in the combat with you. That isn't very good game design, in my opinion. Because not all attacks are properly counter-able, the more enemies you're fighting, the more you're at the whim of the randomness of the game and how the enemies approach you. I have often found myself having to replay some battles where I play noticeably worse, but win the overall battle becaue of the random way certain enemes approach or attack you.Yes, this is a fantastic game, but it's minor flaws turn into glaring ones during certain parts of the game. I would still highly reccomend it, but maybe not for a scaling challenge, but more for batman and adventure / collect-em-all fans.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is not only an excellent Batman game; it is an excellent game. Structured as a metroidivania, Batman AA offers a refined gameplay formula of the genre. Everything is finely tuned, the pacing, the encounters, the story segments and it all fits together nicely in what is probably the best game of 2009. Unreal Engine 3 is put to good use as the game looks very good. The free flow combat engine makes use of contextual animations and at the time of the game's release it was groundbreaking. The original voice actors of Batman and the Joker are used in the game. All in all, this is THE best superhero game ever released, in my opinion. If you want to be Batman, play Arkham Asylum.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2016
												I'm not even a big fan of Batman (the only thing I was fan of is was the first 2 movies of the Dark Knight Trilogy and the animated series) but still the game got me hooked from the first moments. Those Batman and Joker voices, the totally spot on atmosphere, the combat (that was a bit clunky at times, specially to evade enemy) and the villains, gosh...The game succeeds in making you feel like the badass Batman is, the gadgets are great and stealth is really good but a little to forgiving and easy maybe. The story is really good and hearing Joker throughout the game was really interesting haha.Only problems I have with the game is that the combat and stealth mechanics felt a little unpolished in some parts (but very minimal), I sometimes climb a ledge I didn't want to or jump down from one and it was hard to even some enemies. Still awesome game, I'm sure every batman fan would love it. Also I didn't bother with the Riddler trophies, nothing really good to collect.After playing Arkham City this falls short (because AC is practically perfect haha) but still this deserve 8/10 for me even by comparison because it was revolutionary and made me want to know more about the lore but even the first time I played it I felt like it needed more gadgets and more enemy variation (which the sequel provided).

content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
 You Don't Play Batman...You Are Batman  Batman: Arkham Asylum  is brilliant in almost every way. From a technical perspective: the game looks great, the animations work mostly well, the textures look great and the audio is brilliant (especially the voice acting). The game mechanics give the players the feeling that they are Batman instead of only playing a character who can be replaced by another. The player can easily take out multiple unarmed enemies, via the freeflow fighting system, but needs to be careful when they are armed (predator mode). These gameplay modes give the game more variety and are incredibly well made. The items are based on Batman's utility arsenal and can be used in a variety of different ways, next to their original purpose. The only thing that could have been better is the story, which is very comicish (even for a game that is based on a comic book), but leads to the better story in  Batman: Arkham City . Rating: 5/5

content:
Posted: June 10, 2015
												This isn't the kind of game I'd usually try out, but having picked it up cheap I decided to give it a go. Overall it turned out to be a great experience. A great game with a lot of variation between the different modes and situations Batman finds himself in. I especially liked the stealth missions and riddle solving. The combat was more of a mixed bag, and I found myself sincerely hating several of the fights, mostly the titan hencman fights, which I found a lot harder than most of the boss fights. Doing those fights with a mouse and keyboard was useless, requiring me to connect a game controller to my system for the first time ever. With the controller, those fights were doable (but still frustrating), but playing the rest of the game with it was really awkward. In the end I ended up switching between mouse/keyboard and controller as the situations saw fit. More or less requiring a controller to complete the game is a big drawback in my book, but overall this game still deserves a recommendation.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												This is a great game. I'll try to keep this simple. Batman has been a favorite "super hero" for a very long time. The idea is intriguing for several reasons, mainly being he's completely human. Rich, but human.If you love Batman, you'll love this game. Granted, the Arkham series has a very dark spin on pretty much everything. But who doesn't want to run around and beat up violent inmates anyway?The gear you have access to is reasonable, plausible, and very batman. The enemies you face are simple, laughable, and generally fun to battle. The "boss fights" are repetitive, simple, and yet challenging to complete.Strategy, tactics, and skills do come into affect, as well as your ability to maneuver quickly and quietly before anyone sees you.Punching it out with a band of inmated never gets old. All the "riddler trophies" adds hours of gameply even after you've finished the main story.

												Batman: Arkham Asylum is the greatest comic book videogame of all time. This is an adult Dark Knight story that is well-told, packs some truly fun gameplay elements, has topnotch voice talent, and feels like it's part of Batman canon. If I have to nitpick, I wish the cutscenes looked better as they can distract from the tale and that the AI was a bit more responsive, but those are tiny flaws that shouldn't distract from the big picture.Rocksteady nailed what Batman is supposed to feel like. Fans, rejoice.

												The gameplay was pretty good, it made me feel like I was Batman because I got to use the cool stuff he got to use. The story was also pretty OK too, as I didn't get bored  often. The game features a 'freeflowing' combat system. If you play it, you'll know what I mean. It's hard for me to explain, but basically, you can beat the crap out of one guy, counter another guy, and then do a flip and kick a guy in the stomach. That sorta thing.Storywise, you'll like it if you like Batman, or the Batman comic books. I am not really a fan of Batman, but I still kinda liked the story. You won't get 40+ hours with this game, I'll tell you that. I got 10 hours on Normal without looking for secrets, but I guess, if you look for ALL of the collectibles, it should take you and extra 2-3 hours.Graphics are pretty good, I guess.If you want to get it, make sure you get it with the bundle before it's too late!www.humblebundle.com

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												Remember the broken launch of Arkham Knight and the marketing saying "Be the Batman." This and its sequel Arkham City ultimately do a better job of immersing you in the world of the Dark Knight. Unlike Arkham Knight this game runs well and feels like a competent port. I played through this game on PS3 and have picked it up here on Steam as well. The game is fairly linear in its structure but its narrative is tight as you explore the Arkham facility in an effort to thwart the Joker's nefarious plot. Along the way you will battle countless thugs who melt beneath well timed counters and combo attacks. The game has a nice balance of both melee combat as well as stealth sections that allow you to utilize Batman's various gadgets and tools. See a guard walking underneath where your perched on a Gargoyle? Drop down and sweep them up and let them hang. One of the more novel mechanics is a detective mode that has you scanning the environment for clues. Its also useful in detecting enemies and identifying their movement patterns. As you progress you earn XP which can then be used to unlock various upgrades. Speaking of Unlocks, the game has a hearty helping of them ranging from interview tapes to riddler challenges and trophies to find and collect. Being the first in the series its an excellent entry point for newcomers and bat fans alike.

												I played this on the 360 and loved it. Some years later I played it on the pc and still loved it.Pros: decent graphics, nice plot progression, reasonably good storyline, nice variety of settings (within reason, it is all set in the one place after all), no bugs or glitches that I found. And it makes you feel that you ARE Batman.Cons: If you boil it right down, you can virtually play the whole game just pressing the Y button on your controller and it can seem repetitive, but....IT MAKES YOU FEEL LIKE YOU ARE BATMAN!! Worth buying just for that alone.(My only gripe with the game was that by the time I got some of the gadgets/upgrades, it was a bit late and I didn't really need them by then (but did earlier!) but that's just a personal thing).

content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
Batman: Arkham Asylum is easily one of the best superhero games ever made.Pros: Graphics, Sound, ControlsCons: Gameplay, RealismBatman: Arkham Asylum is the first Batman game to truly glimpse into the adventures of the Dark Knight.  From the gritty, dark atmosphere to the nervous, superstitious ramblings of the inmates, every detail creates a sense of not just playing Batman, but being Batman.  Simple controls allow for excellent combat sequences or tight, stealthy getaways.Although some parts are truly innnovative, such as those with the Scarecrow, others are much more monotonous.  Finding all the Riddler trophies (not the actual, more interesting riddles) can sometimes feel like a glorified pixel hunt.  Some mechanics simply break the realism: Gotham should have spent more money on the concrete walls that are literally being pulled apart instead of the indestructible laser gates right next to them.Still, Batman: Arkham Asylum truly captures what it feels like to be the Dark Knight.9/10

content:
Posted: November 26, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is simply a must-buy.It provides the perfect beginning to some of the most impressive Batman games we've come to see in recent years. From the innovative free-flow combat system to the gadget assisted stealth of the Silent Knight challenges. You'll see some nostalgic clashes with some of Gotham's most feared. Arkham Asylum places Batman into a gritty, intense and industrial-esque environment as he relentlessly pursues The Joker, whose murderous trail of havoc has laid waste to some of Arkham's finest. Batman is trapped, not just physically in the Arkham complex, but also by a sense of duty to stop this madman in his tracks. From hunting Riddler's tough-to-find Trophies, to exploring the Island, you'll be battling your way through hordes of inmates whilst using an array of gadgets and brutal martial arts.Be ready to be immersed in a well crafted storyline as you step into the Dark Knight's titanium boots. I'm excited for you because you're gonna' love every second you play...as well as every bone you shatter!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is an incredible game. Great story, memorable characters, an absolutely hilarious villain, and awesome gameplay.Gameplay: 10/10Arkham Asylum is plain fun. The combat is easy to pickup and entertaining to watch. Sneak missions are amazingly fun. Nothing like going into a room with 10 armed guards and taking them out one by one, while they're wondering what the hell is going on. Seeing as this game came out a while ago and was the first Batman game of this series, I didn't expect much and was very pleasantly surprised. Each upgrade is useful and all the different gadgets are used throughout the game in different games. Unlike other games, you will constantly used each of these gadgets, not just use them once and never touch them again. Story: 10/10If you asked me to say what I thought about the game in one word, it would be dark. The story is pretty dark, and the world is pretty creepy at times. Every once in a while, Batman is taken to a world where he has to defeat a villain called Scarecrow, bringing back horrifying memories about the death of Bruce Wayne's parents. These parts were deep and you could really feel for Batman. I found the story itself a good length and it was a nice story itself. World: 10/10The world of Arkham Asylum is well-crafted. Riddler shows off his genius once again, and he mocks you each time you solve one of his cleverly hidden riddles. The AA world is riddled with Riddler's trophies, puzzles, and maps. These are just side missions, but I have to admit, the riddles give a sense of accomplishment when you figure one out. The Arkham Asylum island is not open world. It is pretty small, so after you beat the story, you can do some of the challenges, solve some puzzles, or just find some collectibles around the island that give you some insight on Batman lore, which is nice.I really enjoyed this game, and I recommend to those who like smooth combat mechanics, a good story, and just superheroes or Batman in general.

content:
Posted: February 7
												This game really makes you feel like you're the Batman. The combat is simple, but fluid and satisfying. Getting high combos while utilising Batman's gadgets feels so rewarding.There are some stealth areas in the game. The stealth mechanics are pretty good and many ways of taking down these armed enemies stealthily. These many ways of stealth takedowns are enabled by Batman's gadgets. So you can get creative during these stealth areas. Graphically Batman Arkham Asylum still looks good. Have to keep in mind this game initially released in 2009. The best part of Batman Arkham Asylum are the Riddler Challenges. Riddler has hidden many of his trophies and riddles around the island for you to find. If you are a Batman fan, then solving the Riddles will be very satisfying. I played this few years ago on the ps3 and now I played this on the PC. I still had fun with this game. So I would also recommend this game to people who already played this on the ps3 or xbox360.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Once having the vile GFWL attached, Arkham Asylum now is free of that... thing and has Steamworks. Yay! So how is the game? Great! Unlike it's sequel, AA is a (mostly) linear game where you run around as Batman punching people while trying to stop the Joker from doing what he always does. The combat is superb as are the stealth sections: it makes you feel like you are actually playing as a badass fighter/detective like Batman without it being too easy. Negatives are the boss fights, which are highly simplistic and quite uncreative, and the writing which isn't so much bad as it just doesn't match up with the high quality of the rest of the game. Overall, if you like superheroes, and Batman in particular, get this game. It is worth it. :D

content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												The gameplay was pretty good, it made me feel like I was Batman because I got to use the cool stuff he got to use. The story was also pretty OK too, as I didn't get bored  often. The game features a 'freeflowing' combat system. If you play it, you'll know what I mean. It's hard for me to explain, but basically, you can beat the crap out of one guy, counter another guy, and then do a flip and kick a guy in the stomach. That sorta thing.Storywise, you'll like it if you like Batman, or the Batman comic books. I am not really a fan of Batman, but I still kinda liked the story. You won't get 40+ hours with this game, I'll tell you that. I got 10 hours on Normal without looking for secrets, but I guess, if you look for ALL of the collectibles, it should take you and extra 2-3 hours.Graphics are pretty good, I guess.If you want to get it, make sure you get it with the bundle before it's too late!www.humblebundle.com

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Played through on Hard first try, got about 80% of all of the collectables and secrets (there are hundreds). Very well made game, and rife with awesome Batman info/lore.The ONLY complaint I have with this game is the combat system. The combat isn't very complicated because there are many parts where you need to neutralize enemies in stealth, as any good Batman should. The problem here is that, because the combat is stretched so thin between straight up fighting and stealth, it does neither perfectly. STEALTH - Stealth is a very wishy-washy thing in this game, and because everything in a room is illuminated the same, you don't know if you are in hiding or if a gargoyle you've perched on is not actually putting you in the shadows. You can't fight enemies with guns straight up, so you are frequently forced into the stealth role.HAND-TO-HAND - Much of the straight up combat in this game is luck-based. Not all of it, but enough to be minorly frustrating in Hard mode. There is a 'counter' button while you're fighting that can counter an enemy's basic attack, but the prompt to counter shows up only 50% of the time, and even at that rate, it is very unlikely that you hitting the correct button will actually counter the enemy's attack because you're already in full swing of your own attack.And here inlies the main problem with this game - the 'difficulty'. Because of these certain flaws in the combat, the way the developers ramped up the difficulty was by not making certain enemies harder, but just simply putting more enemes in the combat with you. That isn't very good game design, in my opinion. Because not all attacks are properly counter-able, the more enemies you're fighting, the more you're at the whim of the randomness of the game and how the enemies approach you. I have often found myself having to replay some battles where I play noticeably worse, but win the overall battle becaue of the random way certain enemes approach or attack you.Yes, this is a fantastic game, but it's minor flaws turn into glaring ones during certain parts of the game. I would still highly reccomend it, but maybe not for a scaling challenge, but more for batman and adventure / collect-em-all fans.

												Batman: Arkham Asylum is the greatest comic book videogame of all time. This is an adult Dark Knight story that is well-told, packs some truly fun gameplay elements, has topnotch voice talent, and feels like it's part of Batman canon. If I have to nitpick, I wish the cutscenes looked better as they can distract from the tale and that the AI was a bit more responsive, but those are tiny flaws that shouldn't distract from the big picture.Rocksteady nailed what Batman is supposed to feel like. Fans, rejoice.

												The must play for Batman fans. This game keep the dark atmosphere, comparable to Batman The Animated Series and picture Bruce Wayne as who he really is - a dramatic character. 												First, if you haven't played BM:AA, then do it. You don't need this review.You're Batman. The good Batman, from the animated series, with the GOOD Joker...you know, from the animated series. Batman gets locked in Arkham's grounds and goes around beating up mentally unstable people with the most fluid and dynamic fighting controls ever put into a game. My only criticism is that Batman's "detective" mode is monochrome, and super useful, so that large portions of the game will be played with that viewpoint on. The game itself is so lovely and detailed that I hated using detective mode because I felt like it was taking me out of the game.I think if the developer's had used it as an augmented reality type view, it would have worked better.Oh, also, buy this if you love beefy beefcake weightlifters and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ schoolgirls.10/10, would be Batman again. And again.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
												When I bought this game, I thought it would be funny to write a review of this game with just the words "I'm batman", but after playing, I realized that this game deserves a better review. So let me sum up a few pros and cons of this game.under these pros and cons I will explain them a little.+nice storyline+decent controlls+third person view+character bios+nice graphics+variation of opponenents+amazing joker+second batcave?+riddles+decent voiceacting+after-death-cutscenes-stable internet connection required-last bossfightHere the more in-depth explaination:The pros:The reason why I like the storyline is because you can see that the developers thought about it. the Joker pretty much creates some fun in the game while you're busy fighting his little ♥♥♥♥♥es.When I first saw the controlls, I thought they were somewhat odd, but after half an hour of playing I understood why they were made this way, and they actually feel really nice once used to it.I usually prefer to play games in first person view, but the third person view really fits this game. That way you can anticipate on attacks of henchmen and you will be able to counter them. It's also just nice to see the movements of Batman's cape.Another nice feature of this game is the character bios. The developers wrote a small background of pretty much every important character in the game. It also shows some facts of the characters, like when they first appeared and what their real names are (if known). But most of all I like the character bios because of the interview tapes you can collect in the game. They are quite funny and give you a little more information.Even though I played this game on a laptop with an intel pentium 4 processor and an on-board videocard, the game looked really great. Better than I expected.Another cool thing is that the Joker is not your only oppononent. You will also come across Harley Quinn, Scarecrow, The Croc, Poison Ivy, Bane, and Victor Zsasz. All of those have to be fought in another way, which brings some variation in the game. They also have different types of henchmen. The unarmed will have to be fought directly and with brute force, while the armed will have to be approached sneaky. There is also a difference between unarmed henchmen. Some will be really unarmed, while others use knives or kind of tasers. I also really love this Joker. They created him like a combination of Heath Ledger and the guy who played the Joker before him. Some may like it, some may not, but since this game is not in Gotham, Batman will not have it's batcave in this game. To give the feeling of a batcave, the developers made a secret second batcave on Arkham Island.To make it a little harder to complete this game, they created some riddles. Some are easy to solve, but since there are more than 200 riddles, you might take a while to actually solve all of them, mainly because most of them are actually not easy to solve.I'm a guy who loves to hear things and does a lot with his ears, so I hate it when there are crappy voiceactors in a game. Batman: Arkham Asylum actually uses decent actors, which makes it a lot more nice to play for people like me.In a lot of games you die, and you just resurrect, but in Batman: Arkham Asylum you die, and you get a little cutscene from an opponent, who's captured you and acts like he's about to kill you, which makes it less boring to die.Now the cons:When you play this game with an unstable connection, the game will suddenly stop once the connection is lost, and it will bring you back to the main menu. This caused me to start over a few times. It's really annoying when this happens mid-bossfight, because you will have to do everything from the bossfight once again. A serious problem which shouldn't be necessary since this is not an online game. The last bossfight against the Joker is pretty dull in my opinion. you pretty much have to do the same thing 3 times which is not really something the Joker would let you do.I overall rate this game 9.3/10

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												A powerful story of forbidden love as two clinically insane patients at an asylum dress up as a clown and a bat and try to rekindle their love before the island is rendered uninhabitable by a bad case of weeds. A great 3rd person metroidvania style game that requires you to think like the Batman and use all of his tools in order to progress. I found the parts with Scarecrow to be very well designed and spooky at times. It is worth noting that as this was Rocksteady's first foray in the world of Batman, you are never in a position where the Batmobile is being forced down your throat. Also, the performance of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill are fantastic as usual.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
												Игра класирана в Книгата на рекордите на Гинес в номинация игра за супергерои и получи най-висок рейтинг в историята на компютърните игри. Екип от разработчици от Rocksteady Studios управляваните успя да направи една игра, която е добре приета, дори и тези, които в действителност не са фенове на Батман - преди това играта не може да се похвали с такъв успех и популярност. Rocksteady първоначално се приближи този проект с акцент върху качеството, с особено внимание и грижа, като се вземат предвид всички малки детайли и подробности Девет години история на комикси и адаптации на Батман, и по този начин се създаде ново ниво на качество в областта на компютърните игри. В Arkham Asylum ние сме свидетели на един доста брутален Батман, тактичен, разумно хищен и наистина мрачна ситуация. Тъй като това допринася за доброто съвпадение звуков компонент. В играта има отлична система за борба, има елементи на стелт, изкуствени опоненти и разузнаване в режим на хищник е доста добър. Решавам пъзели на Гатанката, много забавна игра. В играта има своя собствена индивидуалност, целостта на сюжета и неговата доставка. Игра на 2009 г., която ще надмине много съвременни занаяти.Rocksteady поставила за цел, да направи най-добрата игра на всички видео игри на Батман и те успяха.Шедьовър! 10 от 10.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2016
Product received for free
												Ah yes, the one that started it all. Batman: Arkham Asylum. Or as I like to call it, Batman: Begins. Begins to actually make good Batman games that is! Man, I remeber playing Batman on the SNES and whoo boy, that a pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ I mean, it was pretty damn bad. You didn't know what to do half the ♥♥♥♥ing time and the graphics looked liked somone was trying to make an homage to the earlier Mortal Kombat games(I thought they were better to be honest). So granted, my first experience with a batman game with 2-D fighting controls was a bummer. Lo and behold though, it would be years later when the DC franchise would pull itself up by the bootstraps and finally implement a fighting scheme that would not only complement the amount of enemies on screen, but also give inspiration to other games later as well. Not saying it's wholly original, nothing ever is, but it did refine it and give it nice shoe polish. Punching feels good and your attacks have impact. You actually FEEL like a super-duper detective in a skin tight suit(Schumacher fans will be disappointed), enacting your hero fantasies of yore. I never really thought stealth could be done in a batman game, but Rocksteady has proven me wrong. Takedowns from the highest perches to the lowlyest floor grate always feel smooth and satisfying. Snipers feel a bit cheap though, even when you're busy doing doing full nelsons to avoid enemy fire, or when you unexpectantly got shot from the back because you didn't see somone line up a perfectly placed shot in the guard tower adjacent to you. In short, it's a short game; took my only about 7-8 hours to beat, but well worth the experience. If you enjoyed Kevin Conroy in the 90's Batman animated show, bleed your fan-boy heart out.

content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												Finally got around to playing this, and I don't know what took me so long. This is brilliant. Batman as he always should have been. The game plays out like a 3D Metroidvania, rewarding exploration with tons of secrets to find, most of which you won't be able to get until Batman gets new abilities. The fighting system is fun and fairly intuitive, but the stealth mechanics are my favorite - the experience of being Batman has never come more alive than when I stalked my enemies from the shadows. The music never really spoke to me, but the art and presentation is excellent. The acting is exceptional on all sides, but Mark Hamill's Joker steals the show - as he should.BEST PART - Picking off a group of thugs one by one while they have no idea where I am, and the baddies left standing get more and more terrified.

												Ever wanted to be vengeance, or maybe the night, or maybe Batman?Ever wanted to be all of the above?Then this game is for you.If you're a Batman fan you will love this game (Then again if you're a Batman fan you probably own it already) and if you're not a Batman fan then you will be after playing this game.The game is especially great if you're a fan of the excellent Batman: The Animated Series, as a lot of the voice actors are the same.This game is the first game that really let you be and feel like the batman.The story is excellent, the combat is great the game runs smoothly and without any issues.And it no longer uses Games For Windows Live, which is another plus.All in all the game is a great Batman game, a great Action-Adventure game and it sets the standards high as far as doing the source material justice. It is the game that Batman deserves.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2014
												I was skeptical about this game when my friend first told me to get it. I'm not a fan of fighting games, and while I think Batman is both on of the best superheroes and one of the most interesting ones, I didn't really think a game like this--developed originally for the Xbox 360 and ported to PC--would do well. Boy was I wrong. Not only are the graphics surprisingly good, the audio (voice acting, fighting sounds, etc.) makes me feel like Batman. In particular, the voice acting is definitely some of the best I've heard in a video game. The fighting, though rather redundant, is still incredibly fun, though I did notice that countering enemy attacks was difficult. I may have been bad at it, but since I'm fine with it in the sequel to this game, Batman: Arkham CIty, I think it may have just been a minor issue in this game. The boss fights, while redundant, are quite fun and actually quite challenging. Furthermore, the story of this game is remarkably good. I never felt like I was playing through a fighting game with a story tacked on; it felt like a fighting game built around the story, in a good way. The atmosphere was top-notch and made me feel like Batman. To summarize:Pros-great atmosphere, solid gameplay, good graphics and audio, surprisngly good story, delivers an authentic Batman experienceCons-Issues with countering, boss fights can be redundant, hard to get used toOverall, I'd highly recommend this game.

												The start of it all...Over time this game has grown to be my favourite title in the Arkham series thanks to the great combat, tight focus, brilliant atmosphere and plenty of exploration and opportunities for creativity. This game really defines what a superhero game should be, great villains, tight comic-book like story and having our hero do what he does best. Yes the game has some minor faults and it's beginning to show its age but sod it, I've played this game several times before and I know I will be playing several more times again.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2013
												This is still and perhaps always will be, at least in my opinion, the Batman game fans deserved. Set in a closed space, the Arkham Asylum, which is pretty significant to fans of the Batman universe, the game is also filled with references and characters from the series and the adventure feels like a high quality one-shot graphic novel.The atmosphere is palpable, the combat system is designed to flow smoothly with combos and the design also encourages the use of stealth and detective abilities.This game is closer to a Batman comic than any live action movie to date, with the great voice talent of Mark Hamill as the Joker, so if this doesn't feel like Batman, nothing ever will.(I would also recommend Arkham City to a somewhat lesser extent and to an even lesser extent but still worth your time, for the retro games fan in you, check out The Adventures of Batman & Robin on SNES and Genesis.)

												After a many, really many reincarnation of Batman on game scene it finally looks, that we have a decent adaptation, which makes same honor to game industry as Nolan did for movies with his Dark Knight. However a game is based on comic book and not trying to hold Batman universe so much realistic as this director. A story comes from Paul Diny who earned five Emmy awards and already worked on the others Batman projects. Game takes you to Arkham Asylum (as title suggests) where offers a unique dark adventure. You'll feel like a real Dark Knight with all his modern technique, great moves and personal charisma. Joker has no chance even with all of his henchmen. 89/100

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a pioneer which changed the landscape of superhero genre in the gaming industry. Story is well written, as you will feel tension in the atmosphere. Joker pulls all the strings and you must fight the odds. It starts off with Joke being escorted to his asylum under Batman and Arkham Asylum's watchful eyes but Joker manages to escape and turns the asylum into his playground. You must save the people in the asylum and stop this madness that Joker had planned all along. The voice acting is top-notch. One can listen to Joker or the Riddler talk all day. The Scarecrow bit in the game is one of the best gaming moments ever. I loved the tone of many super-villians in an asylum with Batman. This game changed the whole landscape for the superhero games.You will feel like Batman as you will owerpower most of the thugs. Different gadgets are used to solve puzzles and move ahead in the story. The sleath mechanics are well done too and one of the best parts about stealth is how after you take out one of the enemies the fear slowly grips other enemies as they become aggressive but as soon as the numbers start dwindlling they start to panic, this machenic is one of the best in the gaming history. Boss fights on the other hand were a bit too easy and lackluster. Also there is some odd detective work which was nice. Of course, there is the good old fashioned brawling there too. Graphics and atmosphere are good as they capture the tone of the dark and gritty world. Art-style is also very good. Environmental design is brilliant and there a twisted sense of character in every area you’ll discover. This claustrophobic cove of madness oozing terror has to be one of the best settings in video-games.It has everything you would like from an immersive world, great storyline, sleath, detective work and old fashioned brawling. What else do you want? So, are you a Batman fan? buy this game, even if you are not one you will still love this game and is inarguably one of the best superhero games ever.

 NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA. . .BATMAN!      You guys know Mark Hamill does the voice for the Joker right? So that's pretty awesome. Anyways, this game is just plain fun. Does a great job of making you feel like your Batman.  The mechanics are fluid enough, though the gameplay does get repetative after a while, but that isn't necessarily a bad thing. Running around fighting familiar villains and their goons is pretty damn fun. Being limited to Arkham Island seems like it might feel a little stagnant at first, however, the map is a decent size and you keep pretty busy with the story. The graphics look pretty damn good, especially for a game that was released in 2009 and the graphics customization works great. Overall, I don't have any complaints for the game. 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 11, 2013
												Okay, so when was the last time you picked up a game nowadays and there wasn't shooter mechanics involved? Batman: Arkham Asylum just so happens to be proof that the action-adventure genre can still survive and do extraordinarily well in terms of profit amidst a plethora of other games that do the same old thing all over again. A lot of the gameplay reminds myself of older adventure games, and mixes it up with brawler action stuff which is good, but those with less than an average competence with button-press timing may find that the flow of combat is often interrupted and can at times be infuriating. The narrative is pretty much standard Batman with the twist that you face multiple of his most notorious villains, with Joker being a sort of pseudo-kingpin with a master plan. Add on the voice talent of Kevin Conroy and Mark Hamill reprising  their roles as Batman and Joker respectively, and you definitely feel like this is an authentic Batman experience. All in all, if you haven't played Arkham Asylum by now, you really REALLY should, as it is (and was) a refreshing change of pace to the usual product. P.S. Kudos to whomever was in charge of putting those collectibles in the right places. Solving a puzzle to get the shiny thing is way more rewarding than just running around everywhere to find a feather perched at the top of a random building.

content:
Posted: August 4, 2016
												Just got this today along with Arkham City. $5 bucks each!! Wow... Almost 7 years old and this game feels as great as it did the first time I played it back in the Peasant Station 3's golden days. It's a game that never bores you from beginning to end and it encourages you to find every unlockable.What to say about Arkham Asylum? This game revolutionized the way we play games. It brought so many innovations to a time when games were starting to feel so repetitive, uninspired, buggy and generic. The surprising thing was that this game was based on a DC superhero world; something that was considered a stigma in the gaming world. Almost no superhero game has ever been good, or interesting enough to engage people who are not into comics. Yet Batman Arkham series threw this misconception away and brought a magnificent piece of gaming software at the same time.So many games have tried to copy the Free-Flow system, but non have succeeded. This combat system is the 'pièce de résistance' of the Arkham series and will have you craving for fights. And I love how the game does so well at not overdoing it. It gives you just enough fights throughout the game so it is always exciting, without falling into repetitiveness. And still,  at the end, it rewards you with a mode were you can beat as many henchmen as you like.Appart fromt he wonderful combat system that it's such a treat to watch and perform, the game also engages you in stealth as well as playing the detective. It manages to wrap all this into an immersive story with a very dark style never seen before in a Batman game. It even manages to sneak some horror elements, which does fantasticaly well! Definitely a surprise for the first-timer.I really can't find any negatives on this game. It plays brilliant, looks wonderful for being a 7 year-old game, amazing soundtrack and sound effects. great voice acting (we've got the official Joker's voice: Mark Hamill), gorgeous and badass character designs, engaging story even for the non comic fan, and the list goes on.This game is a classic on its own right and it will go into history as one of the greatest and most influential games of the past gen.Graphics: 8/10 It's a 7 year old game but it still looks fenomenal. The PC version benefits from sharper textures, light effects and 60fps. It almost does not look as old as it really is.Sound: 7/10 The soundtrack alone is epic! But it suffers from volume spikes. Cutscenes are too loud. Something that many games suffer from.Controls: 9/10 You got to play this with a controller. Once you do, you find yourself with one of the most responsive, smooth and intuitive controllers there is. Developers really put an effort in them.Gameplay: 9/10 This game is in a league of its own. Back when it came out, there was nothing like it. Brilliant fighting mechanics! Great ballance between stealth, beat'em up, exploration and even horror, making this game feel interesting from beginning to end.Story: 8/10 Simple, but engaging. That darker, more mature Batman game no one really asked for, but oh boy, thank the gods we got!

content:
Posted: June 3, 2014
												Let’s just start with the obvious: one does not have to be a comic fan to enjoy this game. And in that extremely impossible case that you somehow missed all the movies (even Nolan’s ones) here’s a quick recap. Bruce Wayne whose parents were tragically murdered is insanely rich, dresses in a suit that resembles a bat and beats the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of all kinds of bad guys while using cool gadgets. In a devilishly insane logic of superhero comic villains caught by our hero all end up in a special kind of jail which happens to be also a madhouse. It’s Arkham Asylum. Obviously, it turns out badly; asylum is overrun by criminals, and it’s up to Batman to stop them. That’s it without spoiling too many details. After all the game is set in a separate universe which tends to follow the usual canon, but also steps out of the bounds here and there. And this is a big deal for those, who can distinguish Earth-2 from say Earth-15.The plot revolving around events of one night and set in one place results in a rather tense game. First in the series Arkham Asylum may lack the extent, size and polish of its successors, but it has that unique feeling of being trapped inside an insane maze. These corridors, buildings, underground and open air sections are so tightly stitched together, that there’s practically no room to make a breathe, unless developers intended to let you. This is non-stop rollercoaster ride accelerating to the limit and beyond it, until you finally fall in the abyss of total madness, lose all sense of time and spend sleepless night with the game. Rocksteady Studios not just break the fourth wall with this game, they destroy it with a power of nuclear explosion. Carefully crafted props, marvelously fluid animations, diverse gameplay varying from famous “flowing” combat to stealth, puzzle solving, detective mode and beyond that. And ultimately the story. I won’t spoil you the exact scenes happening in the middle of the game, but they are simply outstanding in their ability to convey a feeling of lunacy overcoming Batman in this nuthouse.Gotham Knight’s labyrinth path expectedly twists and bends in way that returns the player to previously visited areas with a new set of toys. That differs in tone and simplicity from most of the hard-core metroidvanias. Rather than just giving tools to overcome some obstacles game gently pushes you in the right way making sure you won’t struggle with trying to figure out what to do next. It’s not a game about exploring, though there are some clever hidden optional areas containing secrets and unobvious puzzles; but that’s for those who just can’t get enough of Arkham Asylum. When it comes to the main progression route the game won’t let off your hand. And while in general that would be a major flaw in my eyes, this time it isn’t. One can say that it’s just a matter of perspective, matter of taste; that you can’t just drop off the player in the middle of nowhere nowadays and hope, that’s he’s clever and curious enough to figure his way from the starting point towards the ending. That may be true… it actually is true, I must say, but that’s beside the point. That’s the matter of taste. Back again to perception of it. Here we have that idea of lunatic luna-park, the goal of filling player with madness. And you can’t just stop and let player wander without breaking that feeling and pace. You ever had that weird nightmare where you run in circles seeing same place again and again not being able to comprehend how many times you did it, not being able to break the cycle? Even if you haven’t, I think you can get it. And that pardons Rocksteady Studios.This was a breakthrough for the video games back in 2009, and it still is a stellar interactive experience whether you care about Batman comics or not. And the actual secret for this success turns out to be rather simple. It doesn’t matter if player is a fan of Bruce Wayne, it matters that developer is. It’s that special attention to the tiniest of details like animation of the main character’s coat or getting original voice-artists from Batman: The Animated Series (including genius Mark Hamill, playing Joker). And this passion just won’t leave anyone indifferent. At least when it’s accompanied with such brilliant execution of gameplay mechanics. Let’s just say that a fair number of games released since then simply copied Arkham Asylum freeflow combat system. And none of them came even close.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												Well it´s been a while since we enjoyed a good Batman game  OST HARDLY RELATED  but this game is quite interesting...Rocksteady Studios brought us this game in 2009, thats 3 years after Urban Chaos their first game (which was quite good IMO) so i´ve been waiting the Goty Edition of this game for a while and it´s time to talk.It uses the Unreal Engine 3, built by the awarded Studio Epic Games, and it uses very well the LCPP (Lightning Calculations Per Pixel) and the HDRR (High Dynamic Range Renderer) allows you to behold all the scenery created for the game.The plot is awesome, a twisted Joker instigate an elaborate plan to gain the control of Arkham Asylum, trapping Batman inside with all the maniacs and foes that he has been imprisioning all these years. As you see it´s simple but full of shades among the different corridors of the Asylum. During the game you´ll find some of the most famous villains, and every boss fight hides messages as references for their comic-story.As for the gameplay. Actually its fun, it has some fails of course but you can still enjoy the combat. You can counter, attack or stun your enemy with the Freeflow combat, this system also allows Batman to move fast between your targets, chaining different combos with your gadgets in order to get over with.If you don´t want to fight all day you can use predatory tactics. The predator combat is based on the stealth, silent knockbacks, takedowns, drops or even using your gadgets (like explosives) to destroy walls or roofs in order to tilt the odds in your favor.After this you´ll be rewarded with XP, which are used to:-Improve your physicall armor.-Unlock combat moves & Gadgets.-Get Health upgrades.What about the enemies? Well, they react to your own acts as Batman. If they find inconcious allies their "fear" will raise, altering their behavior. And this means that they´ll change their patterns. They can shoot on sight, disable your predator points (gargoyles for instance), move to another part of the scenario, stay together with their allies forcing you to change your tactics.The design is hilarious and was complete in 2 years, one of the developers spent these years just designing Batmans Cape, just for make it move realistically. It´s not about the cape, it´s about the work, effort and love that this developers made to make this game shine. Even the writing, they though that more characters (like Freeze) will not fit into this game, due to discrepancies with Joker and because he doesnt have personal grudges against Batman. They though this with nearly every antagonist and they only use the ones who makes sense with their plot.Talking about characters...the developers WANTED the voices of the Animated Series made by Paul Dini. In fact Dini was helping with the writing of it. So they took Mark Hamill as Joker and Arleen Sorkin as Harley Quinn respectively...and Kevin Conroy for Batman. Nothing more to say guys 10/10 in dubbing.Finally, the game also has a lot of content even when you finish it. A lot of riddles, Joker Teeth, Riddler Trophies, Chronicles of Arkham, Patient Interviews (audios talking about the different stories of the villains) and combat Challenges.Must Buy Guys.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Bueno, ha pasado un tiempo desde que disfrutásemos de un buen Batman OST HARDLY RELATED pero este juego es algo interesante...Rocksteady Studios nos trajo este juego en 2009, es decir 3 años después de su primer juego Urban Chaos (decentillo IMO), así que estuve esperando un tiempo hasta pillar el formato GOTY y es hora de hablar.Su motor gráfico es el Unreal Engine 3, usado por el aclamado estudio Epic Games, y usa muy bien sus características como el LCPP (Lightning Calculations Per Pixel) y el HDRR (High Dynamic Range Renderer) permitiendote contemplar toda la escenografía y efectos creados para el juego.La trama es increíble, un Joker retorcido que instiga un elaborado plan para hacerse con el control del sanatorio mental de Arkham, atrapando a Batman dentro con los maníacos y todos los enemigos que ha ido encerrando estos años. Sinceramente es una trama simple, pero creada para que de juego con todos los matices que quieren ofrecerte en el juego. A lo largo del juego encontrarás a algunos de los villanos más famosos de Batman, y todos esconden historias más allá de sus peleas referentes al cómic.Hablando del modo de juego. Es muy divertido, aunque con fallos de respuesta en contadas ocasiones que ciertamente no te evitarán disfrutar del juego. Puedes contraatacar, atacar o usar stuns en un modo desarrollado por Rocksteady llamado Freeflow combat. Este sistema permite moverte a gran velocidad entre los enemigos, encadenando diferentes combos con tus artilugios para superar los encuentros.Si no quieres estar luchando todo el día, te entiendo, puedes usar otra variante del combate conocida como depredador. El modo depredador se basa en el sigilo, ataques sigilosos y derribos sin alertar a los enemigos, usar puntos altos para agarrar a tus enemigos o usar los utensilios para destruir paredes, techos, etc... para inclinar la balanza a tu favor.Después del combate, serás recompensado con puntos de experiencia, que son usados para:-Mejorar tu armadura física.-Desbloquear movimientos y utensilios.-Desbloquear mejoras de salud.Acerca de los enemigos. Reaccionan a los actos de Batman. Si encuentran a un compañero inconsciente o son alertados por un superior su nivel de "miedo" aumentará haciendo que adopten diferentes patrones y alterando su comportamiento. Podrán disparar a discreción, destruir puntos altos (como gárgolas), moverse en grupos, explorar el escenario, etc...El diseño tampoco se queda atrás, fue completado en tan solo 2 años. Para que entendáis el empeño del estudio. Uno de los programadores pasó estos 21 meses de desarrollo programando solo la capa, porque necesitaban un movimiento realista y que quedase resaltado por el UE3. Incluso el guión fue cuidado hasta el punto de no incluir más villanos de los necesarios, porque muchos de ellos desentonarían en el ámbito que se desarrolla en Arkham Asylum o por discrepancias con Joker(como Freeze). Y hablando de personajes, los desarrolladores QUISIERON las voces de la serie animada de Batman, si aquella de los 90 que tanto molaba, que hizo Paul Dini. De hecho el mismo Dini acabó ayudando en más de un aspecto del desarrollo. Así que debido a esto tomaron a Mark Hamill y Arleen Sorkin como Joker y Harley Quinn respectivamente y a Kevin Conroy como Batman. Un 10/10 en doblaje.Para finalizar, el juego tiene además una gran cantidad de contenido cuando lo superas. Acertijos, trofeos, mandíbulas de joker, diarios de audio para aprender más de los personajes, etc...Este juego es uno de los que deben jugarse.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												Batman: Arkham Asylum is a 2009 action-adventure video game based on the DC Comics superhero Batman. It was developed by Rocksteady Studios and published by Eidos Interactive in conjunction with Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment for the PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360 video game consoles, and Microsoft Windows. It was released worldwide for consoles, beginning in North America on August 25, 2009, with a Microsoft Windows version following on September 15.Written by veteran Batman writer Paul Dini, Arkham Asylum is based on the long-running comic book mythos. In the game's main storyline, Batman's archenemy, the Joker, instigates an elaborate plot to seize control of Arkham Asylum and trap Batman inside with many of his incarcerated foes. With Joker threatening to detonate hidden bombs around fictional Gotham City, Batman is forced to fight his way through the asylum's inmates and put an end to the Joker's plans. Most of the game's leading characters are voiced by actors who have appeared in other media based on the DC Animated Universe; Kevin Conroy, Mark Hamill, and Arleen Sorkin reprised their roles as Batman, the Joker, and his sidekick Harley Quinn respectively. The game is presented from the third-person perspective with a primary focus on Batman's combat and stealth abilities, detective skills, and gadgets that can be used in combat and exploration.The game received critical acclaim—particularly for its narrative—and won several awards, including Best Action Adventure game, Best Game, and Game of the Year from different media outlets. It held the Guinness World Record for "Most Critically Acclaimed Superhero Game Ever". A Game of the Year edition was released on March 26, 2010, and an OS X version was released in November 2011. Arkham Asylum '​s success launched a series of Batman: Arkham sequels, beginning in October 2011 with Batman: Arkham City.

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
													Arkham Asylum is a solid game with a rich, atmospheric world. The visuals are good, the gameplay is decent, the environments are packed with detail, and the story is interesting.	The characters are portrayed very well. Even though I tend to have a serious, do-good demeanor (does that remind anyone of a particular Dark Knight?), the Joker's off-the-wall humor cracked me up on several occasions. Every main character's performance is on point, but Mark Hamill's Joker is absolutely superb.	Stability-wise, Arkham Asylum seems very well-tested and bugfixed. I've yet to encounter problems more serious than some clipping and physics weirdness, and my perusals around the internet revealed nothing diabolically game-breaking. It seems to be a wonderfully solid game in terms of technical stability, which is infuriatingly uncommon in games these days.ISSUES	Some of these "issues" are subjective, since I had to dig deep to find anything particularly bad about this game. It goes without saying, but that is a very good thing.	The facial animations look slightly robotic. They're not the worst I've seen by any means, but sometimes they're a little too stiff and mechanical.	Arkham Asylum is one of those games with no "after the final boss" scenario. You have to restart at the last checkpoint before the final story sequence, and you can never actually reach a permanent "finished" state. This is a game with many secrets and collectibles; if you want to find them all and haven't by the end of the game, you have to ignore the final boss and leave the game in a state of limbo while you try to get the rest of the collectibles.	That said, when you've beaten the game once, the final boss is no longer a primary objective when you reload the save. As a result, while you can never reach a finished "after-the-end" gameplay state, at least it indirectly acknowledges that the game has been finished before.	There are hidden scenes/objects that you have to visually scan to prove you've found them, as part of a secrets/collectibles sidequest. Some of these scenes require a ridiculous amount of zoom and a pixel-perfect perspective to actually register. Unless the camera is in the perfect position, the game will complain about bad alignment or zoom, even though it's obvious that you've figured out the puzzle. Fortunately, this isn't a huge problem; only a minor occasional annoyance.	Arkham Asylum has a slight case of consolitis. Most of the options can only be changed with a launcher, buttons have multi-layered functions that can easily compromise your control (I'm looking at you, Jump/Run/Activate/Dodge button), the UI is a little messy and oversized, and there are a few other symptoms. However, given its third-person viewpoint and relatively small focus on intuitive camera movement, I actually recommend Arkham Asylum to be played with a controller. It can't beat the intuition of mouse control in some situations, but a controller works very well most of the time.SUMMARY	Overall, Arkham Asylum is a very nicely made game. I give it an 8/10.	Strengths: Stability, gameplay, environments, graphics, sound	Weaknesses: Replay value (almost everything is scripted), consolitis

content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												At the start of the game I couldn't help but dislike the character of Batman himself, being a tank of meaty flesh but with the grace of a ballerina. However, the longer you play, the less you notice those chiseled butt-cheeks, and the more you appreciate the game itself.The environments are beautiful and suprisingly diverse, especially for being in one asylum and do not lack in detail. Along the way, you can find many hidden dossiers and tapes of villains from the DC universe and of course those famed riddler trophies. I remember staying up all night trying to get all of those darn things. ;)Of course a major seller of the franchise is the combat, which seems to have formed a new kind of standard. At the beginning it can feel repetitive and a bit like button mashing, but ultimately the way Batman fights does depend entirely on the player. You can unlock new abilities to mess with the npcs even more.Overall I recommend this as a solid game, which will engage the player for a good deal of hours.
