content:
Posted: September 6, 2016
Product received for free
												I got this game mainly because well, IT'S BATMAN! (No more need to be said there)If you like stealth games and action adventure games you will find this game quite enjoyable.I haven't completed this game or started any other game in the arkham series, but as far as I've gotten I've enjoyed it. I really like the stealth missions, once you take one person out the rest just start squealing and I fricken love it. I also like when you die the person who killed (or the man behind your death) comes and mocks you... Yes, I enjoyed that part.My favourite parts of the story is when Scarecrow gives you drugs and you start tripping. Just the whole platforming minigame on a nightmare where scarecrow torments you just brings me happieness (Don't judge me)My one main complaint is the personality and character being batman himself, he's a wimp! Not in the way that he's scared of anything, no no, he's a complete bad@$$, just he doesn't actaully kill anyone. Now I'm not some 6 year old kid complaining about how it's "Not Violent Enough" no way, in fact to see a game with alot of time and effort put into to it that isn't a VIOLENT MURDER SIMULATOR WHERE THE WATER IS MADE OF BLOOD AND EVERYTHING YOU SEE SHALL DIE!!! kinda game is nice every once in a while, but back to my batman point, he doesn't kill anyone, just knocks them unconscious, and again, I'M NOT COMPLAINING THAT IT'S NOT VIOLENT ENOUGH, but the fact that everyone he knocks unconscious would kill batman with little to no regret is either really nice on batman's part or really stupid. Now for the actaul human beings, FINE, they were human and batman is all about the murder-lifestyle. But when those mindless monster enimies that would tear batman limb for limb carelessly, come charging at batman and he only knocks them unconscious, that's dumb, that's really dumb.But all and all, even though the motives of batman's ways with enimies isn't very smart, it's a great game, and remember, this is coming from someone who hasn't finished the game or played any other arkham game.8.75/10, would recommened

content:
Posted: January 18
												This game is very good. It starts off where Arkham Origin left off with Batman driving the Joker to Arkham Asylum where the Joker escapes and takes over the Asylum and frees the inmates.The gameplay is quite fun and enjoyable. The combat is your basic "spam X/Left Click until you have to press Y/RMB to counter" for the most part, but it does eventually introduce enemies that have certain weaknesses you can exploit or certain strengths you have to avoid, for example, you mightn't be able to attack certain enemies from the front. The base stealth mechanics are good, but the advanced mechanics are quite interesting. For example, one of the missions has you rescuing Asylum staff, but if you are detected the staff die. But, if you take out any of the inmates, the suicide collars they are wearing go off, which also causes the staff to die. The game runs very well for the most part, but whenever it loads and render in new sections in an area it has noticeable frame drops. This could possibly be fixed by installing onto an SSD, but I think the problem lies within the rendering method employed by the engine. My 1060/6600K rig can hold a locked 60FPS or a locked 144FPS for the entire duration excluding the aforementioned framedrops, though, even at 2560x1440.  See here for how to change your max framerate and other video options that aren't in the options menu [pcgamingwiki.com] . Scroll down even further to find out how to install the ex-PS3 exclusive DLC among other fixes. The levels load quite quickly, even on a 7200RPM HDD. The game has controller support for the XBox 360 controller and autodetects it when it is plugged in. I used DS4Windows to use my PS4 controller for my playthrough of it, though I used mouse and keyboard for a while and found the default binds good and the fact you could rebind each key even better.There are a few puzzles you have to solve, but nothing too major or difficult. You just keep looking from different angles and eventually there'll be a path or solution staring you in the face.The characters are a little dull and boring and don't have any real depth to them, except maybe the Joker. You can  feel  the crazy.Overall, I can highly recommend this game as a must play for anyone who likes the Batman universe or anyone who likes 3rd person combat/stealth games.

Posted: June 28, 2015
												This is one of the best Batman games of all time. It's VERY Batman with voices from the TV show, including Mark Hammel reprising his role as The Joker! This is a fantastic game that should be used as a way to tell other people who make games based on pre-exsisting intellectual licences how to get it right.Though Arkham Island isn't as big as locations in the later games, it is filled with a very rich and beautiful areas with many different characters to run into from the infamous ones like Scarecrow or Bane to the more obscure ones like Zassaz and info on many others that sadly don't make an appearence.The end boss fight is something many people dislike and I can understand why, but it fits the story and the overall game is really awesome too. I'd highly recommend it if you didn't own it already.

												By itself this game is wonderful. If you've played Arkham City though, there is no going back. Arkham City improves on every aspect of Arkham Asylum. Especially the fighting. The range of the beat-em-up combat which once felt flawless in Arkham Asylum now feels constrained after exploring all the combat options Arkham City brought forth.So if you haven't played any of the Batman: Arkham games, start with this one because once you've played Arkham City, you can't go back. By itself, it's one hell of a game with a hell of a story and one of the most enveloping first five minutes of a video game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Arkham Asylum, at the time of this review, is a bit aged (released in 2010, this is 2016), yet still manages to hold it's own admist the newer generation of gameplay and graphics.Already being a fan of Batman and DC since a child, I was extremely excited to try out the first real Batman game, and I was pleasantly surprised with a game that actually is better than many other games, even given it's semi-un-original content and linear storyline based on plot information that most people, even non-DC/Batman fans already know.The game takes place in Arkham Asylum, an island in the city of Gotham, Bruce Wayne/Batman's domain.  The island goes under quarantine after Joker escapes his captivity and leads the various villains and criminals to control the island.As previously stated, the story-line, is semi-unique.  It hasn't been told exactly before (afaik), but it's fairly predictable if you're familiar with the universe.  Even so, the story is rich, characters have backstory and development and well-done voice acting and dialog in general.The combat system is the classic Assassin's Creed II combat system.  Lots of hand to hand and "press Y to counter" combat, with lots of gadgets, specials, combos, score multipliers and other abilities.  The combat is very fluid and fun, but may get a bit repetitive for some after a while.The game world is semi-open.  You have free reign over the island and it's buildings to do the missions, or go explore for collectibles (a lot of these by the way).  This is of course permitting you've reached the story points that allow access to the locations in question.The collectibles, while there are an abundance, are all useful.  Collectibles unlock backstore to the creator of the Asylum and it's history, cell-tapes from various villains, backstory on villains or important characters, concept art and challenge maps.The graphics, for a 2010 game in 2016, are still pretty damn good, so nothing to worry about here.Keyboard and mouse controls are a bit clunky/confusing and don't work to well, due to the console -> PC porting of the game, unfortunately, but with a controller, the gameplay is stellar, and goes without a hitch.Definitely worth picking up, although at $20 for a 6 year old game, personally, I'd wait for a sale, even though the game is very good and still likely worth $20 for most.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												Batman Arkham Asylum: Game of the Year EditionPositives:+ The game has an interesting selection of gadgets to use. There's the batclaw, which is used to pull vent grates off walls, explosive gel to destroy structurally weak areas and the cryptographic sequencer, which allows Batman to overload security terminals and gain access to restricted areas. There's also batarangs and the line launcher, which is a portable device that fires a zip line for Batman.+ The characters are good, they all have personality except for Batman himself, who seems to be very straightforward and lacking in emotion. Joker is a particular standout and the audio tapes found around the Aslyum shed light on various inmates who are Batman's foes.+ Decent graphics.+Game length is anywhere between 20-30 hours or so, depending on how many riddles you solve and your desire to play beat em' up challenge mode.Mixed:~ The combat can be fun, but also borderline infuriating at times. Using unlockable Waynetech upgrades, Batman can perform takedown moves, throw enemies and do more critical damage. However, the combat is very unresponsive with regards to countering and in this respect Sleeping Dogs did a far better third person combat system. The fact Batman: Arkham Asylum doesn't detect your counter effectively really lets it down.~ The Riddler's hidden mini puzzles and items add a nice distraction and diversion to the main story, but at the same time they can be a bit boring if you want to complete them all, even if you discover a Riddler secrets map. It was a nice idea and it does add an element of exploration to the game, but 240 Riddler challenges is a bit excessive. My main gripe is that Batman's detective mode is required to find a lot of these trophies and it's quite annoying to be running around all over the map in black and white vision.~ The story is not bad, it's just not fantastic either. It's a bit difficult to follow, despite its simplicity. I know that sounds like a contradiction, but it's true. It just seems that at some point I lost focus on the big picture, there were a couple of confusing parts regarding the titan formula which weren't clarified. There is no in-game journal which explains the story.Negatives:- The boss fights are more or less the same, using evading dives and batarangs to stun. This pattern is repeated throughout many of the boss encounters, nothing really exciting.- Downloadable content is a joke, it doesn't add anything extra to the story or any new levels. It merely adds more beat em' up challenges..Overall Score: 7.5/10Batman: Arkham Aslyum is definitely not a 9/10 game as Metacritic would claim. But it's still good and it's still fun (plus a little irritating too lol). As the first game in the series I'd say it's well worth playing this, be sure to pick it up on sale where it regularly goes down to $5.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2016
												What is there to say really? This is a phenomenally good game.It has an interesting story, great villains, good combat system, sweet gadgets, enticing collectibles and is actually pretty bug free from what I can tell.You play Batman in 3rd person and you're here to stop the Joker (and various other super criminals), who has taken over Arkham Asylum. On your mission you will be able to explore a relatively open world (The Arkham Isle as well as several enclosed "levels"), in which you can find well hidden trophies and solve riddles by the Riddler, which unlock more lore information and give you some points for your next level up, but nothing really essential. It's a great way to break the monotony of "run, fight, repeat". You will also get several gadgets over the course of the story, unlocking even more ways to fight your enemies and reach new locations.The combat system is just fluent, attack, block, special attacks against certain enemies. A good player would be able to not take a single point of damage in this game, since the system is pretty much flawless and any damage you take is definitely your fault. There is no cheese here. Enemies attack you in succession, but don't swarm you, so you can always block. This is how the system is designed and it works very well. Fighting better and upgrading your combat capabilities means taking out enemies faster.The upgrades usually provide some quality of life changes and some new ways to play the game or make you more resilient. It's not spectacular, but not bad either.You also have access to a "detective mode", which lets you see things you can interact with, such as destructible walls or trophies, etc. The problem is that this mode is so important to actually seeing stuff that you're basically playing the whole game with it being activated and that kinda screws the pretty nice graphics over...My biggest gripe would be with the Batclaw (upgraded), because it takes ages to take down a barrier, while tapping A like a madman, and the "challenges", which are just a set of "fight this for x rounds" or "knock out all enemies in a room as fast as possible". There are about a Dozen of them or so, and they're not that easy to get a good grade on, but I found them rather dull, so I left them out. Apart from that the game is 100% for me, which happens very rarely.A must buy imho if you're either into Batman or 3rd person fighting games with some Metroidvania aspects.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												After finally finishing the story mode and most of the DLCs (above all, Scarecrow Nightmare), I have enough experience and knowledge of the game to make a bold review.The game, from start to end, tells you it's going to be about mysteries that need to be solved, places that need to be scouted, and enemies that need to be put down. And of course, there isn't only the Joker, you will have to battle a handful of other much more powerful (but not as intelligent) villains.At first I read the description; "explore every inch of Arkham Island", and I thought to myself "I am limited only to Arkham? Well that can't be big enough, this game is going to be short!”, On the contrary, the island is extraordinarily well designed, and quite extensive. A speedrunner can finish the game within 2 hours, but anybody that has ever played an Elder Scrolls game will squeeze the gameplay hours off this game. With most of the DLCs and all the story, I invested over 10 hours in this game.The combat system is simple, yet it never gets boring. The AI is beautiful, enemies actually feel smart, and combat can be tricky. But the best part is the Assassin’s Creed-like stealth part of the game; if you want to, you can take out enemies without even engage them in combat, one by one. The remaining enemies will react accordingly; they will get nervous, scared, terrified, and more aware of your current situation.I can go on for pages explaining how well designed, well written and beautifully set this game is. But that experience can only be truly known by playing the game. It’s a no-brainer; you get it whenever it’s on sale. Don’t be fooled by the old styled menus and by how obviously this game has aged, it is still one of the best third-person, action/thriller games. And of course, as serious and concrete I want this review to be, we can’t oversee the obvious appeal this game has; it’s Batman.

Posted: July 26, 2013
												The first superhero game that broke a "barrier" and an actual good and innovative superhero game, with all the elements necessary to make justice to the character, the reason this game was so good was because the game simply followed the comic books and tried to stay true to them. The enemies in the game be them bosses or not are well designed and like i said before true to the comic books, the easter eggs, the riddles, the challenges, all of that make the game even more worth it. The combat was the best aspect of the game, enemies would attack you at the same time and not wait for you to beat them one at the time, you could upgrade your character to perform better in fights and do a good variety of combos. This game also has a good stealth aspect which includes hiding, taking down enemies from gargoyles and other things. This is a worthy tribute to the Dark Knight.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												The Arkham series was one that eluded me till recently, I had always thought that comic book to video game adaptations were often very low in terms of quality having played quite a few of them growing up...I had the chance to get Asylum when it was released but turned it down in favour of Fallout 3. While I dont regret that decision now having Played Asylum I can definately say I regret not playing this Game sooner. It's a beautiful game oozing with stylization and razor sharp in terms of writing, trust me. The story is an absolute must for this game! all the Arkham residents are wonderfully designed and while I cant say Im utterly smitten With Harley Quinns redesign (I much prefer her original outfit) Everyone else has really had the loving touch put towards them with Mark Hamills Joker being an absolute design classic. Gameplay wise it's a mixture of Stealth and Strategy  Platforming. While I loved the Platforming elements (Planning how best to take down a room and using the guards against each other) the stealthier elements often left me feeling like it could have been a bit better. Add to this that controls can be a bit of a mixed bag in particular on keyboard and mouse the Dodge functions are frankly a bit rediculous and trying to platform in a 3D sidescrolling level can at times  be a bit messy. These are however small problems that are probably more me than the Actual controls.  For an '09 game the Graphics hold up remarkably well surpassing many of the games that came out around the same time. Thats before we even get to the fact that Batman is in this game. and as Pop culture will tell us. Batman. Is amazing. Highly reccommended easily one of the Best games 2009 has to offer. Pick it up if bored; you'll not be dissapointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
												Arkham Asylum, at the time of this review, is a bit aged (released in 2010, this is 2016), yet still manages to hold it's own admist the newer generation of gameplay and graphics.Already being a fan of Batman and DC since a child, I was extremely excited to try out the first real Batman game, and I was pleasantly surprised with a game that actually is better than many other games, even given it's semi-un-original content and linear storyline based on plot information that most people, even non-DC/Batman fans already know.The game takes place in Arkham Asylum, an island in the city of Gotham, Bruce Wayne/Batman's domain.  The island goes under quarantine after Joker escapes his captivity and leads the various villains and criminals to control the island.As previously stated, the story-line, is semi-unique.  It hasn't been told exactly before (afaik), but it's fairly predictable if you're familiar with the universe.  Even so, the story is rich, characters have backstory and development and well-done voice acting and dialog in general.The combat system is the classic Assassin's Creed II combat system.  Lots of hand to hand and "press Y to counter" combat, with lots of gadgets, specials, combos, score multipliers and other abilities.  The combat is very fluid and fun, but may get a bit repetitive for some after a while.The game world is semi-open.  You have free reign over the island and it's buildings to do the missions, or go explore for collectibles (a lot of these by the way).  This is of course permitting you've reached the story points that allow access to the locations in question.The collectibles, while there are an abundance, are all useful.  Collectibles unlock backstore to the creator of the Asylum and it's history, cell-tapes from various villains, backstory on villains or important characters, concept art and challenge maps.The graphics, for a 2010 game in 2016, are still pretty damn good, so nothing to worry about here.Keyboard and mouse controls are a bit clunky/confusing and don't work to well, due to the console -> PC porting of the game, unfortunately, but with a controller, the gameplay is stellar, and goes without a hitch.Definitely worth picking up, although at $20 for a 6 year old game, personally, I'd wait for a sale, even though the game is very good and still likely worth $20 for most.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I've never played super-hero games before...always was a Gordon Freeman type of guy.  I bought Batman: Arkham Asylum on a whim when it was on sale at one of the obscenely (sp?) cheap prices during the Steam Summer Sale.  I initially played it over a long week-end, and it turned out to be the best investment I've made in a long time.I mean, even if you're not a comics fan, who doesn't know the legend of Batman and his insanely comical adversaries  (Joker, Riddler, Scarecrow, Poison Ivy)?  The game ended up testing both my combat skills (acquired after long hours as Ezio in AC), and my stealth skills (acquired after long hours as Agent 47), and it ended up being one hella great week-end.Great buy, and at $5 for the GOTY edition, you can't go wrong.  Just pass on your next Big Mac, and you'll find a much more satisfying experience in this goofy offering that certainly caters to our current need for some kind of hero in the corrupt world we live in.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												I am going to make a confession, I wasn't really that interested in Batman before I got this game. However, I gave this game a shot and I have to say, I am happy I did. You play as Batman, (obviously) and he is sending Joker to Arkham Asylum, but it looks like he let Batman send him there a little too easy. It turns out that this was part of Joker's secret plan and he takes control of the Asylum killing many people in it. There is an amazing combat system in the game, easy to learn and get used to. There is also wonderful stealth sections, those were prehaps my favourite parts of the game. I haven't mentioned everything about the game, like the amazing Scarecrow sections, that is for you to see. Batman Arkham Asylum should take you about 10-15 hours on your first try, and I think it is worth the 20 dollars.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												Im not normally a fan of Superhero games in general.  But "Batman: Arkham Asylum" was really fun.  As long as you keep an open mind, and expect more of a comic book experiance you will have a lot of fun playing this game.dont expect the Christian Bale batman here, this is more like how batman is supossed to be, nearly super-human.  Extremly strong, fast, and intelligent with an unlimited supply of tech gadgets.From grapnel, to batarang, explosive gel and more you will use all your gadgets to foil the jokers plans here.  Some very tough but rewarding fights will be had as well.  this game really lets you step inside the shoes of the iconic batman character.Music and sound effects are excellent, but you would expect that with a big budget game.this game is a definate must try for anyone who is a fan of Superhero games, or fighting games in general.The only drawback ive found is that the main game itself (not the sidegames and challenge modes) is pretty short, clocking in at just over 10 hours of gameplay... and this game wont offer much in the way of replayabilityid give it a solid 8.5 / 10

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Playing only Arkham Origins I went into this game with high expectatiosn as I ahd been told Origins was the worst. My expection were just blown away by all the pros this game has. Pros	The Boss Fights- All up until the final fight were amazing and original in there own way, Croc was a stealth mission, Ivy was a dodge and throw, Scarecrow was just amazing with his fight, bane was fine knowing bane, I dont know if harley was a boss fight if she was well done that is exactly how she would have done it.Combat-The combat isnt as free flowing as in origins but knowing this came out in 2009 it is spectactular for that timeGraphics-Playing this in 2016 with a mentality that it was 2009 was pretty hard knowing all the good games with amazing graphics that have come out in that time, But I probably didnt need to because the graphics hold up fine today and for that time would have been amazing.Story-It was average story to say the least Batman gets trapped in arkham and joker has control of arkham, thats what I thought for a while then they added the Venom and then jokers plan then ivy's plane then crane's short lived plan. This provided me with knowing that the Joker had planned so well and put some good time into his plan. The story could have been adapted to a movie and it would have been fine/ Cons The Final Boss Fight-It was a letdown and to quick, Joker gives himself venom this has so much potential as a fight, But all he does is send his henchman in and when you defeat them you knock him down and punch him a couple times Overall	This is a spectactular game with amazing visauls for its time, great story, some great boss fights, and most of all it has Batman!

Posted: October 21, 2013
												Batman and Robin are camping in the desert, set up their tent and are asleep. Some hours later, Batman wakes his faithful friend. "Robin, look up at the sky and tell me what you see."Robin replies, " I see millions of stars.""What does that tell you?" asks Batman.Robin ponders for a minute."Astronomically speaking, it tells me that there are millions of galaxies and potentially billions of planets.Astrologically, it tells me that Saturn is in Leo.Chronologically, it appears to be approximately a quarter past three.Theologically, it's evident the Lord is all-powerful and we are small and insignificant.Meteorologically, it seems we will have a beautiful day tomorrow.What does it tell you, Batman?"Batman is silent for a moment, then speaks:" Robin, you idiot, someone has stolen our tent."

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Honestly, I expected better. This is yet another console port (are there native PC games anymore?!), with the usual problems of console ports. Like what? You name it: mediocre controls, especially during fights (there is something with timing and combat flow and all that, it basically means that you have to press the exact button at the right moment the game expects you to do so; more or less equivalent to the ideas behind QTEs); ultra-linear plot (go there, do that, rinse, repeat), repetitive gameplay (you will encounter two main types of ennemies: melee fighters, and ranged fighers. And quite rarely, a stronger melee figher type) with the same strategies all along the way, and so on.Of course there are worse games out there; but we're not searching for the worst game, are we? So to summarize, this game has an experience which goes from amusing to boring, with an average much closer to boring; can cause an impressive amount of frustration at times (especially when fighting, something which is not really interesting to begin with, given the small amount of strategy you can use; it's more of a standardized suite of buttons to press, as an answer to a visual stimuli the game shows you); it has an okay plot, and is worth playing once, provided that you stop playing as soon as you feel the frustration growing in you; and get back to it later. Not a game I would recommend to people prone to easy anger. In any case, the replay value is close to null, and to be honest (I'm writing the review as I do a second play-through, for achievements - I waited two years or so, since I did swear to myself that I would never touch it again, after the first one), I would advise anyone to avoid it at all costs. Too bad, a Batman game would have the potential to be so much better... =/Bottom line: More or less okay game, if possible get it on a sale, and play it once, with small sessions preferably.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2015
												Most superhero games aren’t very good. But Arkham Asylum changed that. It made people say, ‘Finally! A superhero game that doesn’t suck!’ Batman Arkham Asylum is about Batman (duh) getting trapped in Arkham Asylum (also duh). Unfortunately he is trapped with some of the most dangerous criminals in all of Gotham, including the Joker, Killer Croc, Poison Ivy and Scarecrow.The game controls aren’t too hard to figure out. You use the mouse to look around and to attack and block. Space to run, and ctrl to crouch. Every time you knock down a thug you get experience points. Get enough of them and you can level up. Levelling up allows you to pick an upgrade, such as armour improvements and new abilities. Obviously you can’t have a Batman game without gadgets, so throughout the game you will unlock many, including batarangs, grapple gun, and oh, did I mention explosives?The Boss fights/Areas are quite varied, from overcoming Scarecrows fear gas, to sneaking through the sewers trying not to be eaten by Killer Croc. Although one problem I had with the game was the fact that Bane wasn’t smart. Instead all he does is through things at you and ram you. But that’s pretty much my only problem with the game.If this game was a spoon, it would a good spoon.I’m giving this game spoon/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												This is a great batman game, when you play it, you feel like the batman himself. The game is very fun, but i wouldnt be biased and give it an honest review. The game's mechanics work well, the fighting is smooth, gadgets can be used easily. The story in my opinion is the strongest of the current 3 batman games, its dark and gritty atmosphere really sets the tone of the batman universe. It has some of the best batman characters, and bios about them, and recorded tapes. There is also these riddler trophies, there are items hidden through out the game. Although there are some really good things about this game, Lets not overlook some cons. The boss fights was disappointing to me, they were not really challenging, they were predictable, and bosses repeat the same thing over and over and over again, which is not really a bad thing, but the repetition isn't challenging. You might has seen complaints abou the enemy AI, but they get smarter as you progress in the game. These are the only parts I found dissapointing in the game, everything else worked well for me. If you are a batman fan, i suggest you go for it, but if you like good action game, I recommend giving it a try. FINAL VERDICT: 9/10

												In this game you're Batmen, The Knight of Darkness. The title of the hero is very misleading, as he isn't even a knight. He doesn't have a sword, he doesn't ride a horse, he never goes to the jousting area, he doesn't fight for the hand of the pure maiden. Instead he runs through some kind of hospital and then on the rooftops, throwing pieces of metal at everyone he doesn't like. Given how utterly ridiculous the "knight" is, I'd say there's no way this game isn't Japanese.His enemies include the Prankster (big boss but funny) and his girlfriend Hairy Quinn (complete rip-off of a name of Leauge of Legends champion. She doesn't even have a bird!), Searching-Lights Man (scary), that green enemy thing from Hulk (I love when they use the characters from the same universe) and many more. They are strong, but not as strong as Batmen. Maybe it's because I used cheat codes.I loved the initial metagame battle (most likely prepared by Prankster) of "Game for Windows". It truly made me feel like I'm playing a superior PC version. I laughed at the top of my lungs when I found out my randomly generared name was PrecutRainbow20. content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
												If someone were to ask me what was my favorite Superhero game. Arkham Asylum would pop into my head first. It's as close to being Batman(aside from it's sequels) as it gets.Game starts out with Batman having captured the Joker yet again and brought him back to the asylum. Shortly after bringing him in, Joker escapes custody and it comes apparent that he had planned this all along and Harley Quinn had taken control of the Arkham's security systems. So Batman sets out on the hunt for the Joker to stop him from whatever he is planning.The visuals are stunning and still hold up and they convey Gotham's dark Gothic scenery perfectly. The audio work is equally as good with solid voice acting from everyone especially Mark Hamill's Joker. The combat in the game utilizes a fluid simple to use but difficult to master system allowing you make to make combos from one enemy to the next. Batman also carries a wide variety of tools and gadget to allowing him to fight crime such as his trademark batarang for knocking out enemies and his grappling hook for reaching ledges from a distance as well pulling on enemies or opening new ways to go and  in his cowl he has system that allows him to detect pretty much everything around, like evidence, location of enemies and more. He acquires more as you play through the game.Aside from the main objective there are also a ton of extra things to uncover like riddles and prizes that the Riddler has hidden all over Arkham Island. There are also tapes with treatment sessions with some of Batman's greatest adversaries and markings left by a mysterious unknown called the Spirit of Arkham.Main storyline is great and involves many of Batman's greatest enemies and will leave you satisfied at the end when you beat it and when you do you'll have a ton of riddles and secrets to keep you busy for awhile longer.Gets my thumbs up!

content:
Posted: April 15, 2013
												Now here’s a game to remember. Batman: Arkham Asylum is a breath of fresh air for superhero games. Instead of leeching off the success of the Nolan films, Warner Brother Studios have managed to use the original comics as a great basis for developing a rich and intriguing game world. Batman Arkham Asylum is really a game that I consider to be a pioneer of the new “free flow” combat system. Third person combat has never been more fun for me. You can string together different moves and quickly move from one enemy to the next or even attack more than one at the same time. It’s incredibly satisfying.The story of Arkham Asylum is another star of the show. Focused around catching the joker after he escapes and proceeds to cause havoc on the Asylum, it’s up to Batman to save the island before things go from bad to worse. Along the way you get to meet (and in some cases fight) some familiar enemies from the Batman comics including Scarecrow, Poison Ivy, and The Riddler. Despite the focus being around the Joker, I found myself so engrossed in each of these villains back stories as they featured in their cameo appearances. Having more than one villain made the story more robust and gave it very good pacing. As I progressed through the game, I kept many memories of these great bad guys and the levels they belonged to. When a story is able to do that, you know it’s been well made.Speaking of memorable levels, I was very impressed with the level design as well! Each area of the Asylum has its own unique appearance and although they all share similar features that are needed for gameplay, they all feel different. You’re given a lot of ground to explore and extra missions to complete for unlockables and extras. The Riddler riddles are particularly well done, although not exactly deep. At times you’ll even get to re-visit areas you’ve already been through and use newly unlocked equipment to reach previously inaccessible sections.In addition to the main story, there are also challenge maps which are small test rooms to well…….challenge you. They focus on fighting, stealth, and even unique situations. Although a good way to spend more time after you’ve completed the story, I didn’t find them necessary. Because they lack the story of the campaign, I wasn’t as interested in playing them. It’s that part of the game that feels more like a game rather than an experience, and that’s not for me.Arkham Asylum doesn’t feel cheesy, it doesn’t feel forced, and it really sucks you in. Whether you’re a fan of the comics or not, Batman: Arkham Asylum is a thoroughly enjoyable experience.(now unlock the achievements Valve,  so I can go back in and get them all)

content:
Posted: April 25, 2013
												Batman Simulator 2009.Arkham Asylum is one damn good action game, surprising for a western-developed title, and one damn good stealth game, surprising for a modern video game (ded genre etc). The combat is simple but also somewhat complex, with quite a few gadgets and moves, and a LOT of ways to take down enemies. The stealth and combat in Asylum can be mixed together at will, (except when fighting armed enemies, in which case it is too dangerous to fight them openly) providing a lot of different gameplay possibilities for the player. While learning the advanced uses of moves and gadgets is not necessary for the player to truly succeed in the normal game, the challenge mode is where the game's combat shines. On top of the base game and the challenges, which are all reasonably difficult, the game also comes with a harder difficulty mode that will really wreck your♥♥♥♥♥♥ It's a little bit broken because the game's combat is very reliant on the appearence of shining attack indicators over enemies before they strike, which are gone when playing the hardest difficulty, but overall it remains one of the hardest action games I've played in the last few years.The stealth is also wonderful. It's very fast, and requires proper use of your gadgets and tools. There's never a moment in Arkahm Asylum's stealth where you're doing nothing or waiting for something to happen. It also has a very interesting system of fear tactics, where you can get various effects out of enemies with fear.Arkham Asylum features my favourite depiction of Batman and Gotham City, it being in my opinion a perfect blend of the style of the animated series and the more realistic versions of the live-action films. The art style (and graphics) is fantastic, and that's without even mentioning the amazing Scarecrow segments scattered throughout the game.The biggest problem with this game is probably the integration with Games For Windows Live, even on Steam. But if that doesn't bother you too much, you should definately give this game a try. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												This is the first game in the Batman Arkham series. I never cared for action games before this game, but Batman Arkham Asylum innovates with a new, original combat system that forms the very core of the Batman Arkham experience. Batman Arkham Asylum seamlessly blends action gameplay with a well designed stealth system (and reasonable, but not perfect AI) to deliver an extremely addictive gameplay experience. All in all, it takes about 6-10 hours to complete the main story, depending on how many side activities you complete. Also, this game has lots of post game things to do ranging from collecting and solving the Riddler's riddles to challenge modes featuring both combat and stealth challenges. If you are curious about the Batman Arkham series, then I strongly recommend playing this game first. The combat and stealth mechanics improve so much throughout the series (Arkham City and Arkham Origins) that it almost becomes difficult to replay this game. Hands down, this is one of my all time favorite games.9.5/10The 'sometimes' frustrating Ai is the only thing that prevents this game from getting a solid 10.

content:
Posted: March 11, 2016
Will update as I progress :)What I Like:- Hand-to-Hand Combat: "Easy to learn/hard to master combat system"- Beautifully designed game- Tutorials: Are very clear and interactive and the upgrdes are progressive- Replayability: Plenty of bonuses and riddles to find, some of which require items that will be unlocked later in the game- Steamworks Integration: Achievements, Trading Crads, etc- Side Missions: Stealth, and speed runs- The Joker: :) The character is designed and voiced nicely - Face your fears : Scarecrow missions- Upgrade weapons and skills as you progressNeutral:....Wish it had:- Custom Waypoints The option to add custom waypoints on the map would have been nice- GPS: An optional added visual GPS would assist some users- Fights: Some fights can be tedious and frustrating, especially with armed thugs thugs with electrical bats, and a combinantion of Titans and thugs - May cause you to Rage Quit :( Take a break try again :)- Drag Bodies: Batman is unable to drag bodies after a stealth takedown (contrast that with Far Cry 3)- More Driving Missions: The ability to drive around in the batmobile and bike (perhaps as a side mission), would enhance the gameplay options- Swimming: Batman is unable to swim :(My NotesJust some notes that I can come back to when I play later :)- Strike: LMB- Stun: MMB- Counter: RMB- Batarang: Q- Batclaw: C- Multiple Batarangs: 6- Use Objects: RMB then LMB- Detonate: RMB then MMB- Titans: Batrang when they are charging at you- Electro Melee: Evade and jump behind them, then attack - Armed: Gargoyles, inverted, silent, corner, etc

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Amazing. Do recommend. One of my favourite games for many reasons:Story -  a great story is present in the first installment of the Arkham games. You roam Arkham Asylum, the mental institute situated on an island not too far from Gotham City. Baddies keep trying to ruin your night and as Batman you need to stop them.Gameplay - The combat and flow of the game is smooth and amazing. You actually feel like Batman while pulling off amazing combos and using all your gadgets that are at your disposal.Graphics - Such a turn on. The graphics hold up well. The whole atmosphere is almost perfect for the setting.Length - I found the length to be great as well. Not too long not too short. You won't get bored because you keep unlocking new gadgets as the story develops.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2014
												This game is a revelation to many people, it shows that comic book games can be not just good, but AMAZING! It is the wake up call to every suit who thought about a quick cash grab,movie tie-in/comic book game, to try harder, or better yet dont even try because this game is a masterpiece. The story is actually original and it works well for the premise considering how insane the sequels get later on. This game laid the groundwork for the Arkham series and still holds up after all these years, dont let the slow start fool you, this game is intense and a recommended addition to your library.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Amazing first game in the Batman Arkham series.The atmosphere is dark adn creepy and left me with the light on at night. I  think this is the perfect atmosphere for teh arkham games.And the voice acting is great they got kevin conroy for batman and mark hamill for joker, teh same as the animated series I used to watch, it just adds to the feel of the game when you hear that iconic joker voice. And the story is great I beat it in 8 hours but it was in one playthrough could have last me a month. Basically jokers gets into arkham and controls everything,lets all the criminals wander the halls and stuff and you have to stop him while criminals are trying to stop you like harley quinn,scarecrow (which had a amazing boss battle every few thours),poison ivy, killer croc.bane and teh riddler. 9.7/10 amazing game.
